attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: We were parked at North Cargo 3 (BOS) undergoing servicing of the aircraft at the time of the event. Passengers had been deplaned, equipment offloaded, and the aircraft fueled. A request was made to have the lavs fully dumped to facilitate the winterization process as we were scheduled to fly to YYZ for an overnight. At 7:15, I was in the back of the airplane with several of my flight attendants when we felt something impact the aircraft. There was a loud bang as the plane shook wildly for several seconds accompanied by sounds of screeching metal. I immediately ran off the airplane down the stairs on to the tarmac. Seeing nothing to the left, I ran around the front of the aircraft to the right side where I saw a body sprawled out on the ground behind the right engine & Hector Ortega (Mech) running towards Pat Marz (Co Rep) and myself screaming for someone to call 911. I raced back up the stairs to the aircraft. At 7:16 I placed a call to 911 and instructed F/O De LaRosa to call ground control and relay situation to MassPort and instructed everyone else to remain onboard. Police, Fire/Rescue, Paramedics et al arrived on scene a couple minutes later.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: While I can only speculate, what I think happened is this. One Signature employee was backing a lavatory service truck into position on aircraft left as another man was marshalling him in. The driver may have left the vehicle in Reverse thinking in fact he had put it in Park. Attempting to get out of the truck and with it still moving, he probably panicked and accidentally slammed on the gas pedal, instantly ramming into the marshaller, the tail end of the aircraft and out the other side coming to a rest about 30-40 feet off to aircraft right. On a side note, I do not recall seeing extra wheel chocks lying on the ground near where the lavatory truck should have been had it been parked properly.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Accomplished March 2011 internal audit form MAM-109. Area of audit was Facilities and Equipment. The listed discrepancies were found: 1) AT HANGAR WEST WALL FOUND A FIRE EXIT DIAGRAM WAS NOT POSTED, IT WAS PLACED IN THE BREAKROOM DOOR V-FILE. 2) AT HANGAR WEST WALL FOUND THE AIRCRAFT DECAL SAMPLES SHADOW BOARD WAS NOT SECURELY ATTACHED TO WALL SURFACE. IT IS MISSING SEVERAL ATTACH SCREWS. 3) AT THE HANGAR MSDS INFORMATION STATION FOUND SAFETY REPORTS V-FILE WAS NOT SECURELY ATTACHED TO WALL SURFACE BECAUSE THE PLASTIC IS BROKEN. AT THE HANGAR MSDS INFORMATION STATION FOUND THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE GUIDEBOOK IS THE 2008 EDITION. 4) AT THE HANGAR NW CORNER FOUND FIRE EXTINGUISHER #16 PATH BLOCKED BY AIRCRAFT GROUND POWER CABLES AND ALSO SEVERAL COMPUTER EQUIPMENT ELECTICAL CORDS HANGING IN FRONT OF FIRE EXTINGUISHER. 5) AT THE HANGAR NE CORNER FOUND INSPECTION TAG MISSING ON THE FIRE EXTINGUISHING SYSTEM WATER HOSE VALVE. 6) AT THE HANGAR NE CORNER FOUND EYEWASH STATION BOWL/SINK HAS COME LOOSE AND IS BROKEN. 7) AT THE HANGAR YELLOW FLAMMABLE STORAGE CABINET FOUND SEVERAL SPRAY BOTTLES WITHOUT CONTENT ID LABELS AND THIS CABINET HAS FLUID SPILL INSIDE. 8) TOOL CALIBRATION PROGRAM, FOUND GMM PROCEDURE 8.6 TO CONTAIN AN ERROR AT ITEM 7.b., IT STATES THAT INDIVIDUAL CALIBRATION RECORD FILES ARE ESTABLISHED AND MAINTAINED FOR EACH ITEM IN THIS CATEGORY. THESE FILES CONTAIN A COPY OF THE LAST REPAIR ORDER AND THE CERTIFICATION RECEIVED WITH THE TOOL WHEN PURCHASED OR CALIBRATED. THESE RECORDS ARE KEPT IN THE QUALITY CONTROL OFFICE. THE ERROR IS THAT QC ONLY FILES THE ORIGINAL CALIBRATION CERTIFICATE AND NOT THE REPAIR ORDER. THE STOCKROOM KEEPS THE REPAIR ORDER AND A COPY OF THE CALIBRATION CERTIFICATE. IT IS ACCESSIBLE IN TRAX. SEE ATTACHED GMM PAGE 8.6.1 WITH HIGH LIGHTED TEXT. 9) FOUND CHECKLIST MAM-109 TO HAVE ITEM # 8 AND ITEM #12 ARE DUPLICATE.
Mon, 04 Apr 2011 14:57 Z NOTE ITEM #3- THE 2008 EDITION OF THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE GUIDEBOOK IS THE CURRENT EDITION.

category.name: Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
The following report was submitted to me by one of our reps in EWR, Jeff Gray, who was the assigned GSC for this departure:
[Jeff wrote:] "On a different topic, I want to bring something to your attention regarding LL330/27Nov EWR-RDU that I'm sure you'll know who should be advised of it at MAI. After my GSC duties on this flight at the Signature FBO at Newark, I of course stayed and assisted with the flight until taxi. AFTER the cabin door was closed and the stairs were about to be pulled, one of the ASIG ground staff that had been loading bags onto the aircraft, casually mentioned to me that they had loaded a "few more" bags in the aft compartment than we had originally planned for. I asked if he had advised the Captain of this and when he responded no I immediately asked how many more bags were loaded. He said that 70 bags were loaded in the aft compartment when we had been expecting only 40. On a light flight like this one, 30 extra bags may not sound like a tremendous issue but I know that any increase or decrease in cargo load should always and without fail, be reported to the flight deck. In this case, I had been standing next to the Captain when he advised this same guy to put the 40 bags in the aft hold and advise him (the Captain) if there were more. I had the airstairs kept at the A/C door and went up to tell the Captain of the increase; he advised me that no bag movements were needed and the additional bags loaded aft could be left there. He also wanted to know why he wasn't advised of this before the weight and balance paperwork was completed. While I realize this doesn't fall under the duties of the GSC, I know enough about airline operations and weight/balance to know that this failure of communication to the cockpit could have potentially devestating results so I felt I needed to call attention to it at MAI HDQ.
I can be reached for any additional information or comments once this message gets into the proper hands.
Thanks and regards, Jeff
Jeffrey Gray 305.778.3209"

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Due to lack of communication from the ground handler personnel to our crew members.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
My duty time started at 13:30 (ELP time)/ 15:30 (Miami time) when Maintenance Control told me the issue about 739 flying without a Preflight Transit being done.(12-29-30) From that time on I was preparing myself to work on the PT and the other issue of the APU being on DMI. The times are recorded in Maintenance Control (both shift), Hotel, and Cutter Aviation. I came back to the hotel and I only had time to take a shower and get ready for show time at 12:30 (ELP time). After I got the PT performed (2.50 hours), I started working on the troubleshooting of the APU (2.0 hours). I was my initiative to work on the DMI. When I was finished, I called Maintenance Control and gave the results of the TS being the APU ECU the possible defective unit. I told him that it could be an intermittent problem when I initially interrogated the FMC CDU recent faults of APU showed no defects at this time. The DOM & Maintenance Controllers were involved since I wrote an email early explaining that m At that time (21:30 ELP time), I was told to change the IGV actuator since this problem could be an intermittent one. When I was replacing the unit, I noticed that the six o-rings that came with the shipment were all the same. Each fuel line required 2 different o-rings. As per the AMM, once you take off the line you must replace the o- ring. Since all the o-rings shipped to me were different in size, I had no choice to call Maintenance Control and DMI the APU completely. This means that each leg the AC needs to use electrical & air power at each station. Let me clarify this: the order of o-rings was incomplete. Because of it, I encounter another problem when I removed the fuel lines from its original position and was that I need to have an identical new o-ring replaced in which I did not have. I had to DMI APU completely.
The duty time ended at SFB (12-30-13) when I had total of more than 22 hours. I did not rest at the hotel in between times because there was no time for it since I was working. When I arrive to SFB, I called Maintenance Control to let them know my status of fatigue. Let me clarify this: I was fatigued and I have nothing more to demonstrate the effort to stay alert, conscious, safe, and awake for a period of 22 hours. Not only that, I had in front of me another 5 other hours of flying and complete the APU DMI issue. We are talking about over 35 hours easily knowing the AC was running late.
DOM & Maintenance Control knew of this issue since I wrote an email early on 12-27-13 telling about my duty time of 16 hours by the time I get to PHX. Then the duty time will increase when I begin to work the APU DMI. I told the Captain Tom Osullivan about the issue at the gate in SFB, I did not want to leave without explaining my situation and why I was calling fatigued.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: After landing, tower directed us to taxi to the HAZ-MAT parking area located directly north taxiway B and north of runway 05/23. We taxied via tower instructions to the depicted ramp on the Jeppesen 10-9 page. As we taxied onto the depicted ramp, we noticed ground personal lighted wands and ground equipment headlights off in the far distance beyond the paved ramp (not depicted). The area beyond that was pitch dark and the aircraft taxi/turnoff lights illuminated tall overgrown grass. Asked tower, ground ops, and our ground handler if there was a different place to park and they said no. I then asked for a tug to be towed and shut down the engines do to my fear of ingesting or blasting FOD and damaging the aircraft while taxiing onto the overgrown area.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: Call for a tug to tow the aircraft.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: 1. Repave the area in question. 2. Find alternative parking. 3. Tow aircraft onto area

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Passenger became ill and stopped breathing while in level flight over Spain. Declared an emergency and diverted to LEMD airport were we landed over weight (69.7k).

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value:
Passenger became ill and stopped breathing. Flight attendants administered oxygen.
Declared an emergency and called dispatch. We advised them of the situation and recommended LEMD for our nearest suitable airport and they agreed.
Aircraft landed over weight and continued with out incidence. Passenger regained consciousness and medical team on the ground cleared the passenger to fly to his destination. Called the company and they stated it was alright for him to continue on.
A contract mechanic completed the over weight inspection and signed off the oxygen bottles were used. Continued on to destination with further incidence.

attribute.value: Today August 13, 2009 at 11:00 AM we had a fire drill and the announcement on the speakers didn't work on the Finance Department. We could not hear anything until they came over and told us to leave because of the fire drill.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: Fri, 14 Aug 2009 13:50 Z Upon completion of the fire drill MIS was called to check system to determine the failure of the paging system. It was discovered that the volume control on the speakers had been turned down. The volume control was reinstated to its proper position.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Upon recieving AC 753 on the ramp after flight, the maintenance foreman noticed that the pilot had turned off the #1 engine hydraulic pump. The foreman questioned the pilot if there was a problem with the pump. The pilot told the foreman he shut it down so that the towbar could be attached to the AC without the worry of hydraulic pressure damaging the towbar or personnel. The foreman had just come out of the 737 Fam class and was aware that shutting down the engine driven pump damages the solonoid, but as he is a new foreman here, he waited till the pilot left then turned on the pump and asked me about it this morning.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: The oxygen generators on N753MA were not replaced at the appropriate time due to an incorrect entry in Miami Air International's TLC spreadsheet which tracks the due date/times for this component.

attribute.value: ;Declared Emergency with ATC;Executed Go Around;Excercised Captain Emergency Authority;Landed in Emergency Condition;Operated in Degraded Conditions

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Part 91 ferry from KPIT to KBWI. Clear, moonlit night w/ unrestricted visibility. Fuel on board was 3.6 Kilos. Approaching COLUM (approximately 10 miles from Runway 10) on ILS RWY 10 at BWI, an unspecified/undetermined electrical system malfunction occurred that led to an unsafe landing gear indication in addition to various other system warnings, cautions and failures. The red "Nose Gear" landing gear indication was illuminated when the gear handle was placed in the down position. No other landing gear indication was illuminated (either red or green) with the gear handle in the down position. The aircraft sounded and flew as if the landing gear had been successfully deployed, but a go around was initiated to look into the problem. An emergency was declared and observers on the ground at BWI were asked to attempt to determine the landing gear position if possible. Several low approaches were flown and the observers on the ground noted the taxi light was on (demonstrating that the nose gear had deployed), and it was believed that, in fact, all the landing gear had deployed. There was no locked indication, however. With no indications of any failure of the hydraulic system or landing gear system, and all concurrent malfunctions were electrical in nature, which would not affect the deployment and subsequent locking of the landing gear, the aircraft was flown to an uneventful and successful landing on RWY 10 at BWI. The aircraft taxied to parking under its own power. Aircraft shut down with 2.5 Kilos. fuel on board. BWI airport authorities met the aircraft at the parking stand and asked whether there were any further problems and whether any further assistance was required. No further assistance was required.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value:
All procedures were performed in accordance with all applicable Operations and Flight Manuals. The electrical malfunction that occurred was the subject of several days of troubleshooting and consultation with the aircraft manufacturer as well as other 737-400 operators. As of this writing, an exact description of the failure has not been determined, nor has the aircraft flown since the subject incident flight. In addition to the unsafe gear indications as described above, the following observations were made in the 20 minutes or so prior to landing the aircraft at BWI:
Caution Lights Illuminated:
Both "Pack" Lights (Air conditioning system went into full cold and high flow) All "Zone Temp" Lights "Speedbrake Do Not Arm" Light "Speed Trim Fail" "Mach Trim Fail" "Auto Slat Fail"
Other things that did not work:
FO's artificial horizon (tube went blank) Standby Gyro tumbled and displayed all three "off" flags N1 and fuel flow indications went blank Oxygen indication went to zero Autopilot disconnect aural warning was inoperative Cabin call button was inoperative Intercom was inoperative Only one thrust-reverser deployed after landing
Things that did work:
Autopilot Autothrottle FMC MCP ILS and communication radios
Due to the short time from the malfunction occurrence to landing, there may have been other inoperative systems as well, but landing the aircraft safely was a higher priority than in-flight troubleshooting.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: While no one can predict when or why such a bizarre electrical system malfunction will occur, it should be noted that nothing in the QRH or other onboard manuals would be of great assistance due to the nature of the malfunction(s) presented on this flight. Most of the emergencies we train to are canned and their resolutions readily available via the QRH and other manuals. Some emergencies require an acceptance of whatever is presented and the priority remains flying the aircraft and landing it safely as soon as possible. Had the flight been in IFR / bad weather conditions, or had been at another phase of flight (en-route at altitude and far from a suitable landing field), the result may have been totally different.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
While in cruise flight. I Received information from the Purser (Klazina Van Balderen) that family members were hitting and punching a crying toddler in the passenger cabin, and while intervening to help in the matter our mechanic (Leonardo Ferrer) had been approached by another family member wanting to start a fight.
The Purser believed situation had defused by informing the man that threatening a crew member is against the law and the Captain will divert aircraft and have him arrested upon landing. The man then returned to his seat.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: The toddler was crying uncontrollably and the family members dealt with it in the wrong way.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value:
The flight crew determined the situation to be a threat Level 1 and flight deck went into "Lockdown" per FAA and company procedures.
Contacted the company via SatPhone and informed the duty officer (Kurt Kamrad) of the situation and recommend police authorities met the aircraft upon arrival at the gate.
Continued to destination airport.

attribute.name: physical_symptoms

attribute.name: mental_symptoms

attribute.name: fatigue_contributing_factors
attribute.value: ;Arrangement of Pairing Duty Periods;Late Departure;Long Duty Period

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Prior to the duty day in question, I attempted to adjust my sleep schedule however, as I mentioned above, it is hard to force your body and brain to go to sleep when they don't want to. Also, both the Captain and I planned to nap during our ground stops in KDTW and KTPA but, we couldn't accomplish our rest goals due to all the activities around the aircraft, i.e. catering, fueling, aircraft loading, and other flight related duties and responsibilities. The Captain and I started to show signs of fatigue on our KDTW - KTPA leg. During the descend into KTPA we were both randomly yawning and head drooping. Once on the ground, we attempted to depart KTPA ahead of schedule but a 07:00 am (local) landing curfew in KFRG put a stop to our plans. We had to wait in KTPA for at least 2 hours before we could depart in order to comply with the landing curfew. As previously mentioned, attempts were made to nap but catering, aircraft unloading, and cleaning prevented us from doing so. We were able to catch a nap of 30 minutes prior to our departure however, I think this made things worse. In preparation for our KTPA - KFRG leg, I noticed that both the Captain and I were slow, constantly yawning, and we were having difficulties completing simple tasks like reading the checklist and programing the FMC. Also, we had some additional duties to perform like arming the doors and inspecting the galleys since our Flight Attendants were not scheduled to ferry the airplane with us to KFRG. Instead, they got limoed to Miami. Right after take-off both the Captain and I showed all the mental and physical symptoms of fatigue. In addition to those, we were having problems completing simple tasks like radio communications and fuel checks. As a precaution, we both decided to keep all cockpit lights on, take constant walks, set alarm clocks, breathe oxygen, and position our seats in uncomfortable positions so we could stay awake. During the final stage of the flight, our fatigue was such that my Captain spoke to me in his native language (Dutch) several times without noticing. Thankfully, we completed the flight without incident. Once we were out of the airplane, we took a taxi to LGA in the middle of the morning rush hour. We finally got to our hotel in LGA at around 9:00 am (local) and I believe our duty exceeded 16 hours. I attempted to fill out a report when I got to the hotel however, I was so tired that I fell sleep the moment I sat on my bed, while wearing my entire uniform, including my shoes. I woke up about 8 hours later and stayed awake long enough to take my uniform and my shoes off, get a quick bite to eat. I went right back to sleep after my meal so I could catch my commercial flight home.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: As per the CBA and our company policies, Miami Air is suppose to recognize that certain types of flying can, in certain circumstances, be a factor in causing fatigue (i.e. nighttime or â€œback side of the clockâ€ flying) and will bear this in mind when constructing trip sequences. With all the options available to the company, I strongly believe Miami Air failed to follow the above statement and created a unsafe and fatigue inducing paring. Also, even though fatigue affected our judgement, we (the pilots) failed to recognize all the "red flags". In retrospect, we should have both called fatigue in KTPA and delayed the flight until we were both properly rested.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Safety Department received a hotline tip where the person states that because of the layout of the hangar and placement of the airplane seats, equipment, etc, sometimes the forklift gets very close to some of the outward-opening doors inside the hangar.
Someone coming out of a door might not see an approaching forklift and get hurt. The person suggested that maybe there should be signs inside the doors to inform personnel coming out of the doors to be careful and be on the lookout for forklifts.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: hangar layout, placement of airplane seats and other equipment.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Please post signs that tell personnel to watch out for forklifts when exiting doors.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Accomplished an audit of maintenance control. Found that not all personal that man maintenance control have not been trained on how to scan and input log pages into the computer system.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Performed an audit of maintenance control dept. Found that the oil ccnsumption monitoring program files for all the aircraft were not up to date.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: After parking the aircraft it was determined that the aircraft ingested a bird in the #2 engine during landing roll. Both Pilots observed a small bird fly by the right side of the aircraft at approximately 90 kts during the landing roll.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Birds in the vicinity of the airport

Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: other_location_of_fatigue_event
attribute.value: In Taxi from KFRG to hotel near KLGA

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: The previous duty day ended at 0045 local time, Tried to stay up as long as possible and went to bed around 3 am, woke up at around 10:30 am, for a report time of 17:00 local. For a scheduled duty day off 15 hours. Flew first leg from KLGA to KDTW, where we were on the ground for 3 hours 25 minutes, tried to take a nap, but with all the activities in and around the aircraft was unable to do so. 2nd leg, from KDTW to KTPA, aircraft on ground for 2 hours, got in about a 30 minute nap. 3rd leg, from KTPA to KFRG, Both the First Officer and myself were yawning throughout the flight. From KFRG we took a Taxi to the hotel next to KLGA, Due to traffic this took one and a half hours, But as soon as I was in the Taxi I was so tired I fell asleep and slept the whole time. Had lunch with the First Officer later that day, and he told me I had spoken to him in Dutch (my native language) several times during the flight, of which I have no recollection whatsoever.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Our Duty day was scheduled for 15 hours, with 7 hours and 15 minutes of flying. Unfortunately the previous 3 days had ended between midnight and 2 am, And this day starting at 17:00 lcl, requiring a much different sleep schedule. The schedule called for two extended ground stops, Which I believe made the situation much worse. To avoid this situation in future, Either and an extra pilot, So that one can rest on the plane when tired or limit the duty day/ flight sectors.

attribute.name: fault_isolation/test/inspection
attribute.value: ;Did not Detect Fault;Not Found by Inspection

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On April 5th, 2010, AC N739MA at CJI hanger during Heavy Maintenance Visit, VP of Maintenance and CEO of Miami Air stopped by to look at AC. Upon entering L/H Wheel Well found the Standby Valve not locked out. The DQA for CJI was immediatly informed and the Standby Valve was then locked out. No damage to the AC was found.

category.name: Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
I was being transported by MG Bus Service on 4/1/12 after completing screening for LL 618. The driver (Did not get his name) almost ran a stop sign because he was going at a high speed. We advised him to slow down and be careful! He continued to drive recklessly on I95 Southbound. He was swerving out of his lane causing cars to honk their horns at him. We continuously told him to slow down and be careful; he responded with giggles.
This is the 2nd bad experience that I have had with this company. The first experience was in November after completing screening at Landmark Aviation for ETA Logistics. It was raining outside; the driver was speeding because he had other clients to pick up. I told him to slow down to prevent my death. He yelled back at me saying he needed to pick someone else up! I arrived at MAI the following night to discover MG was our mode of transportation. I told Joe and Anthony of my decision to NEVER ride in that companies vehicle's and proceeded to drive my own to Landmark.
I would have driven my car on 4/1 had I known MG was picking us up from Shelt Air! My safety should not be questioned when on duty for Miami Air! I will no longer subject myself to the torture of riding in another MG vehicle.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: The driver does not think about his passengers safety. He should not be allowed to drive passenger vehicles.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: The driver was told to be careful and slow down.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: During replacement of MLG fwd Trunnion pins, AC 733's LH trunnion pin was found damaged after the MLG had been 3 pointed and the pin installed. The AC was in CJI hanger and was scheduled out in 36 hours. The gear had been RII to the 3 point section, but the RII left and was replaced after shift change by another RII inspector. This inspector found the bolts torqued and the pin lubed. Upon further investigation, the RII Inspector found damage to the trunnion pin in the way of a gouge to the upper surfave.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Captain Martin detected over a series of flight that actual fuel burns were consistantly higher than flight plan projected burns. This was presented to Management prompting a fleetwide audit of aircraft burn rates.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Aircraft tend to increase burn as they age

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: A fleetwide audit determined that burn rates had increase for certain aircraft. Based on the audit fuel burn biases were adjusted in the computer flightplanning system and in the aircraft flight management computers.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Continue to monitor burn rates and adjust flight plans and FMCs as required.

During Flight Segment 3 (TUL to COS) I believe I may have become fatigued due to the long duty day combined as Split Duty without an intervening required rest period and due to being scheduled by the company beyond limitations as established by FAR 117.
FAR 117 Limitations exceeded by the FDP on 21MAR12 thru 22MAR12
FAR 117.21 Reserve status
For Reference Section (a) states:
Section (a) Unless specifically designated as airport/standby or short-call reserve by the certificate holder, all reserve is considered long-call reserve.
Limitations exceeded:
Section (d) For long call reserve, if a certificate holder contacts a flight crew member to assign him or her to a flight duty period that will begin before and operate into the flight crew memberâ€™s window of circadian low, the flight crew member must receive a 12 hour notice of report time from the certificate holder.
Section (e) A certificate holder may shift a reserve flight crew memberâ€™s reserve status from long-call to short-call only if the flight crew member receives a rest period as provided in Â§ 117.25(e).
FAR 117.25 Rest period. Section (e) No certificate holder may schedule and no flight crew member may accept an assignment for any reserve or flight duty period unless the flight crew member is given a rest period of at least 10 consecutive hours immediately before beginning the reserve or flight duty period measured from the time the flight crew member is released from duty. The 10 hour rest period must provide the flight crew member with a minimum of 8 uninterrupted hours of sleep opportunity.
FAR 117.15 Split Duty. Section (d) The rest opportunity that the flight crew member is actually provided may not be less than the rest opportunity that was scheduled.
Section (f) The combined time of the flight duty period and the rest opportunity provided in this section does not exceed 14 hours.
IN SPECIFIC
Violation of 117.21 section (d) occurred at (U2) report time of 0500L / 1200z (22MAR12) for not providing a 12 hour notice of report time before beginning the flight duty period that began before and operated into the flight crew memberâ€™s window of circadian low.
Violation of 117.21 section (e) occurred at (U2) Skeds notification time of 2205L (21MAR12) / 0505z (22MAR12) for shifting a reserve flight crew memberâ€™s reserve status from long-call to short-call without granting the flight crew member a rest period as provided in Â§ 117.25(e). In essence, I received 6+55 hrs of uninterrupted rest.
Violation of 117.25 section (e) occurred at (U2) Skeds notification time of 2205L (21MAR12) / 0505z (22MAR12) for not providing the flight crew member with a minimum of 8 uninterrupted hours of sleep opportunity. Also, [Â§ 117.25(e) affords the flight crew member a rest period of at least 10 consecutive hours immediately before beginning the reserve or flight duty period. As such the company stood in violation of section (e) at (U2) report time of 0500L / 1200z (22MAR12) for not providing a 10 hour consecutive rest period.] Existing rest filed by the company was given after the fact by default, no true required rest period in accordance with FAR 117 and FAR 121 was accomplished.
Violation of 117.15 section (d) occurred at (U2) Skeds notification time of 2205L (21MAR12) / 0505z (22MAR12) for attempting to classify the FDPâ€™s as Split duty when the rest opportunity provided in PHX was less than the rest opportunity scheduled and thus did not qualify as Spit duty.
Violation of 117.15 section (f) occurred at (U2) Skeds notification time of 2205L (21MAR12) / 0505z (22MAR12) for rescheduling both FDPâ€™s together as Split duty in excess of 14 hours combined rest opportunity and flight duty period.
Split Duty 21MAR12 thru 22MAR12
Table B (U2) Actual Report Time 2045z (21MAR12) /1545L Number of Flight Segments (4) as Split Duty
MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 12+00
[The total number of hours I spent in this flight duty period and on long call reserve adjusted to short call out with follow up FDP totaled 22+40 hours. <End of FDP time 1605L / 2205z (22MAR12) minus start of duty 21MAR12 1545L / 2045z (21MAR12)>
Please Note As a reference towards the progress of Miami Air complying with FAR 117 I would like to include the following:
Beginning in January of 2012 under the new unenforceable regulation FAR 117, I have now completed 17 FDPâ€™s (Flighty Duty Periods) as a pilot in flight.
Of the 17 FDPâ€™s thus far 8 of them have exceeded limitations as established in FAR 117.
All cases as acclimated and unaugmented

(03JAN12) FDP Scheduled total 13+45, Report 0130L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 14+05 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 9+00

(27 and 28FEB12) FDP Scheduled total 19+55, Report 1720L, 2 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 25+40 Reserve availability and FDP combined Violation of FAR117.21(c) (1), (2), (3) and FAR 117.25(e) TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 16+00
(01MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 11+25, Report 0430L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 11+15 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 10+00 FLIGHT TIME Scheduled total 8+25, Actual FLIGHT TIME total 8+35 TABLE A MAX FLIGHT TIME 8+00
(18MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 21+30, Report 0730L, 2 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 22+00 Reserve availability and FDP combined Violation of FAR117.21(c) (2), (3) and FAR 117.25(e) TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 16+00
(21 thru 22MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 26+40, Report 1545L, 4 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 22+40 FDP 21/22MAR combined as Split Duty with FDP 22MAR12 combined Violation of FAR 117.15(d),(f), 117.21(d),(e), and FAR 117.25(e)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On flight from NGF to BFL, upon reaching flight level 400, APU FAULT light illuminated and APU did a protective shutdown. We did an air return for maintenance. Maintenance suggested HNL because of better Mx support.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Passenger cut himself with a knife on his foot. Medic was callled to assist. Applied a pressure dressing to control the bleeding. determined ok to continue the flight. Installed liquor locks on first aid and emergency medical kit. Purser kit needs sone gauze pads and gloves. Kurt Kamrad advised at the ime of the incident.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Captain was advised by Purser that a passenger in the rear of the aircraft was very intoxicated and barely conscious. Paramedics were called after the female passenger vomited. Passenger was removed from aircraft and from APIS transmission.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
This is the transcript of the anonymous report received by the Safety Department (a scan of which is attached to this report as well):
"To Whom it may concern, Yesterday, September 19, 2012 I walkied into the In-Flight Department I guess moments after an oxygen canister had been brought up from the hangar. It had been requested by the department for use in training. They had just discovered that it was not empty and a phone call was made to advise this and inquire waht to do next about the oxygen canister.
Knowing we have had a serious and expensive episode in the past involving the mishandling of oxygen canisters I found this to be a bit unnerving. I do not have any details and do not know what was said to lead up to what I saw but thought someone should know in order to ask those questions if deemed necessary. Thank you"

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: None was provided by the submitter.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: the wood floor slats are not secure. I stopped in mid-stride to turn around and a wood slat shot out from under my left foot and went into the hallway. the same thing happened to Uganda on Sunday. Also the air conditioning in scheduling/travel and my office is still uncontrollable. depending on the number of people producing body heat will determine if you require a parka.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: the event occurred because the installation of the floor is incomplete, the ac has never been properly fixed and the power cables that Dave tripped over (see previous WBAT report) were never fixed either.

attribute.value: Today, I noticed a loose metal strip in front of the (south) elevator door on the first floor.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Please have someone from Dade-County fix or remove the strip before someone trips over it.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On Take Off roll at 80 knot call out, FO's ASI read 80 kias and CPT's read 70 kias with IAS Disagree warning illuminated. Take Off was aborted, FO's ASI read 94 kias and CPT's read 83 kias. RTO did not activate. ATC advised and A/C exited runway and received clearance to taxi back to Miami Air ramp.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Per maintenance, there was some water in the pitot static system. A drain valve was not in the proper locked position.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: On Take Off roll at 80 knot call out, FO's ASI read 80 kias and CPT's read 70 kias with IAS Disagree warning illuminated.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: Take Off was aborted, RTO did not activate. ATC advised and A/C exited runway and received clearance to taxi back to Miami Air ramp.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: This was a maintenance issue, they should be queried for suggestions.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: When departing the office on 11/1/12 two MG busses where parked in the reserved executive parking lot.here at MIami Air. A foul, septic oder was present, and a tinted fluid was draining from the bus. The fluid appeared to be waste as if the MG technician was dumping the blackwater tank in the parking lot.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: If the fluid draining from the bus was indeed waste water, then the only reason I can believe why the event occurred would be due to gross negligence.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Michael Hackert asked the MG technician if they were dumping the waste tank of the bus and the guy would not answer.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
From: William Lewis Sent: Saturday, February 05, 2011 2:51 PM To: Luigi Imbrieco Cc: Armando Martinez Subject: Hanger Entry
Hi Luigi,
As I was entering the hanger thru the main entry door my foot slipped into a hole by the drainage grate, this was probably due to someone exiting the same time as I was entering and I had to stay to the right. I was not injured but the posibility is there for someone to hurt themselves when entering, especially if it is bright outside and going into a darker area. While our customers generally do not enter thru this door, on occasion, some have and if hurt, it could turn out very expensive for MAI.
I have attached a picture of what I am refering to. If the plate could be moved to the right or another plate added next to this one, it might improve the situation.
Thank You,
Bill

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: this was probably due to someone exiting the same time as I was entering and

Entered for John Valentine LL520 BOS-LAX

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: ATC cleared us to descend from FL340 to FL260 direct "Norku" on the arrival into AMS. Before reaching "Norku" and prior to leveling at FL260, control assigned us a heading and a series of descents to lower altitudes, the last of which was FL100. On one of the aforementioned descents the TCAS showed a target that was below us at approximately 5 nm at our one o'clock position, climbing from left to right. The TCAS called out "traffic" for a brief moment (maybe 3 to 5 seconds). In the correct manner, the TCAS showed the target go from white to amber as we came within approximately 5 nm and approximately 300ft climbing. ATC had assigned us 250 KIAS on the descent and in "Level Change" mode this was yielding a rate of descent of approximately 1,500 fpm. In response to the "T/A" advisory we decreased our rate of descent to less than 1,000fpm by commanding the "Vertical Speed" mode. We continued to AMS with no further incident.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Lack of ATC separation and/or too great of a descent rate?

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: I was in the center of the hangar after completing a seat conversition paperwork and noted two women exiting the women's restroom in the northwest corner of the hangar. Neither of them were wearing any type of proper identification, so I challenged them. One woman identified herself as an employee of J & L Welding and she stated that she had left her id on her desk. She claimed she was escorting her guest to the restroom. I told her she had to wear proper identification to walk through the hangar and to obtain a leasehold badge or a J & L Welding company id for her guest before proceeding through the hangar as failure to have proper identification is a violation of TSA regulations and Miami Air company policy.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Flight 538 Spokane, Washington To Vancouver, Canada
After take-off we realized the cabin was not pressurizing prpoerly. Followed Miami Air Cabin Alt. Warning checklist. AC packs were on. Door illumination Panel was not illuminated. We were then advised that the L1 door was not sealed properly. We landed and entered the item in the log book. Maintenance was preformed. The item was signed off. We were then cleared to proceed to Vancouver with no farther incident.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: The event occurred because either the sensor does not work properly or the door needs a secondary sensor to detect that the door is sealed correctly. Perhaps a primary latch and a secondary latch to seal the door ... ie two seperate fuctions to seal it.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: APU lost oil pressure and it Auto Shutdown itself inflight. The event happened on ETOPS airspace and about one hour and forty five minutes prior to reaching our ETP. I took the disicion to turn back around to Oakland. A landing was made in OAK with no further incidents.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Took off from TUS, runway 29R, climbing left turn southbound enroute to MEX. During the climb approx. 10 miles south of TUS @ approx 9000 ft., purser called cockpit advising of a loud noise (very loud rushing wind sound) coming from the L1 door. Aircraft was leveled off, Flt. Mech. checked the door and found the door handle in the locked position (cockpit door light extinguished) but the door wasn't seated properly in the frame preventing the door from being completely sealed. TUS departure was advised and the aircraft was returned to TUS. On the ground, the Flt. Mech. inspected the door and found everything satisfactory, closed the door properly, and the aircraft departed with no further problems.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Whoever shuts a cabin door should make sure that the door is closed slowly, and when locked, the door should look like it's flush in the door frame. If any corner of the door is slighly raised away from the frame, it should be opened and reclosed.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Cleared for the visual approach to runway 23r at destination. Approach control advised VFR traffic, 10 o'clock, 5 miles, 500 feet above you has you in sight and is maintaining visual seperation. We reported that we had the traffic on TCAS but not visually. Approach responded that "he has you in sight and is maintaining visual seperation. He will pass above and behind your aircraft. Maintain best forward speed, you are number one"
Approaching the glideslope, the TCAS target started descending. I informed the First Officer (PF) that it appeared the traffic was attempting to "duck under" our flight path, rather than pass overhead, as instructed. I got a visual on the aircraft at the same time we received a TA from the aircraft. Within seconds, we received an RA to CLIMB. We leveled our approach, maintained visual with the traffic as he passed under us by approximately 200'.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Reliance of ATC to allow a VFR pilot to be the only one responsible for seperation in Class Bravo airspace.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: Adjusted our flight path, in compliance with a TCAS RA and safety of flight, after making visual contact with the traffic.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: If both aircraft cannot maintain visual seperation, in this case we did not initially see the other aircraft, perhaps a vector away from the potential conflict could have been issued, even though the weather was VMC.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: At 6am on Friday August 7, 2009 I was talking to the Hangar door. I had gone to the right of the door for it was raining hard and the entrance floods about five inches . When I stepped onto the sidewalk the next thing I knew, I was down on my right hip sliding on the wet sidewalk toward the front door of the hangar. The sidewalk has black/mold on it from the trees. The sidewalk need to be pressure cleaned and the flooding problem addressed before someone gets hurt.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
18MAR12
On 17MAR12 at around 0838L (1238z) Miami Air Scheduling Dept. notified me that I would be placed on short-call reserve at 2000L/17MAR12 // (0000z)/18MAR12. Reserve availability period to end 0729L (1129z) 18MAR12 a total of 11+29 hrs.
On 17MAR12 at around 0838L (1238z) Miami Air Scheduling Dept. also notified me that I had a trip assignment in addition to short-call reserve immediately following the reserve availability period.
Scheduled on duty Report time was 0730L (1130z)
Scheduled Trip 18MAR12 MIA to FLL (Limousine crew) 1200z to 1300z FLL to BMI (BSK626) 1500z to 1800z BMI to SAT (BSK521) 1900z to 2130z
Scheduled Off Duty Release time 2200z (18MAR12)
Total Scheduled FDP (Flight duty period) 10+00 Total Scheduled work hours on company time (On Duty to Scheduled Release) 10+30
Actual Trip Block times 18MAR12 Actual on duty Report time was 0730L (1130z)
MIA to FLL (Limousine crew) 1205z to 1227z FLL to BMI (BSK626) 1530z to 1825z BMI to SAT (BSK521) 1935z to 2200z
Actual Off Duty Release time 2230z / 1730L (18MAR12) Actual Hotel Check-in time 2315z / 1815L (18MAR12)
Actual Total completed work hours (On Duty to Actual Release) 11+00 Actual Total completed work hours on company time (On Duty to Hotel check-in) 11+45
Actual FDP 10+30 (Ending at Aircraft Block-in Time)
During Flight Segment 3 (BMI to SAT) I believe I may have become fatigued due to being scheduled by the company beyond limitations as established by FAR 117.
FAR 117 Limitations exceeded by the FDP on 18MAR12.
FAR 117.21 Reserve status. Section (c) For short call reserve, (2) For a flight crew member who has completed a reserve availability period, no certificate holder may schedule and no flight crew member may accept an assignment of a reserve availability period unless the flight crew member receives the required rest in Â§ 117.25(e).
[Â§ 117.25(e) affords the flight crew member a rest period of at least 10 consecutive hours immediately before beginning the reserve or flight duty period. As such the company stood in violation of section (c) (2) at report time of 0730L / 1130z (18MAR12) for not providing a 10 hour consecutive rest period.]
(3) For an unaugmented operation, the total number of hours a flight crew member may spend in a flight duty period and a reserve availability period may not exceed the lesser of the maximum applicable flight duty period in Table B of this part plus 4 hours, or 16 hours, as measured from the beginning of the reserve availability period.
Table B Scheduled Time of Start (0730L) Number of Flight Segments (2)
MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 14+00
[The total number of hours I spent in this flight duty period and in the reserve availability period totaled 20+00 hours. <End of FDP time 1700L / 2200z (18MAR12) minus start of reserve availability period 2000L / (17MAR12) // 0000z (18MAR12)> The company violated section (c) (3) limitation of 14 plus 4 = 18 hours or 16 hours as the lesser maximum.]
FAR 117.25 Rest period. (e) No certificate holder may schedule and no flight crew member may accept an assignment for any reserve or flight duty period unless the flight crew member is given a rest period of at least 10 consecutive hours immediately before beginning the reserve or flight duty period measured from the time the flight crew member is released from duty. The 10 hour rest period must provide the flight crew member with a minimum of 8 uninterrupted hours of sleep opportunity.
Violation of 117.25 section (e) occurred at report time of 0730L / 1130z (18MAR12) for not providing a 10 hour consecutive rest period immediately before beginning the flight duty period.
Please Note As a reference towards the progress of Miami Air complying with FAR 117 I would like to include the following:
Beginning in January of 2012 under the new unenforceable regulation FAR 117, I have now completed 14 FDPâ€™s (Flighty Duty Periods) as a pilot in flight.
Of the 14 FDPâ€™s thus far 7 of them have exceeded limitations as established in FAR 117.
The following cases as acclimated and unaugmented:
(01JAN12) FDP Scheduled total 12+20, Report 0645L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 12+50 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 12+00
(03JAN12) FDP Scheduled total 13+45, Report 0130L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 14+05
(23JAN12) FDP Scheduled total 12+20, Report 1200L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 11+30 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 10+00
(23FEB12) FDP Scheduled total 13+35, Report 0400L, 4 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 12+27 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 10+00
(27 thru 28FEB12) FDP Scheduled total 19+55, Report 1720L, 2 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 25+40 Reserve availability and FDP combined Violation of FAR117.21(c) (1), (2), (3) and FAR 117.25(e) TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 16+00
(01MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 11+25, Report 0430L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 11+15 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 10+00 FLIGHT TIME Scheduled total 8+25, Actual FLIGHT TIME total 8+35 TABLE A MAX FLIGHT TIME 8+00
(18MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 21+30, Report 0730L, 2 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 22+00 Reserve availability and FDP combined Violation of FAR117.21(c) (2), (3) and FAR 117.25(e) TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 16+00

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: COMPLY WITH FAR 117 FOR SCHEDULED TRIPS, FLIGHT DUTY PERIODS, REQUIRED REST PERIODS, SHORT-CALL LIMITATIONS AND RESERVE STATUS REQUIREMENTS AS SET FORTH UTILIZING TABLES A, B, AND C.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Just prior to top of descent, Purser call stating that a male passenger was having a nose bleed and vomiting. A nurse attended. Purser advised that the passenger was recovering and that the nurse advised her that while it was not an emergency situation, she recommended we have the paramedics meet the aircraft. Unable to reach the Graound Handler on VHF, so called Dispatch to organize the Paramedics. Landed, passenger had recovered enough to walk off the aircraft. Two oxygen bottles used, EMT depleted one to zero.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Enroute to PSM 1+45 before arrival at FL 360 I was informed by the cabin crew of a strange smell in the mid cabin area (like an electrical cable being burned). QRH for the condition was executed. Cabin crew investigated further and located the smell around rows 17,18 LHS. We proceeded to switch off the IFE and galley power and after that the smell slowly dissipated. Upon visual inspection found IFE box underneath row 17 with some indications of burned cables. Flight continued to PSM with no further problems.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: While initiation a take-off from IAD we had a take-off warning configuration horn. I initiated an RTO. We notified the tower. We exited the runway and accomplished all the required items. We discovered the leading edge indicator circut breaker popped. A log book entry was made for the C/B the mechaniz reseted the C/B without any further pops. Another take-off was made with no further incident. The rest of the operation was normal.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: No TOGA FMA indication upon depressing TOGA switch in throttle quadrant. Aborted Taoke-off and exited RWY 19R at taxiway K. Found MCP DC2 circut breaker out (popped). Consulted Maintenance Control and Flight Mechanic Leo Ferrer. Reset circut breaker per Maint. No further abnormal indications. Item written-up and cleared at MKE.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Take off warning horn sounded when thrust levers set to take off power. Aborted takeoff and exited runway. Wrote iten in maintenance logbook and the mechanic then tested and cleared the item. Flight continued without incident.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Walking to the hotel after eating I sliped on Ice on the side walk in KLGA and fell I landed on my back. Had some pain for a while but as the day when on I felt more pain on my lower left back and it when down my leg. On Sunday as the day when on and I sat on the airplane seat the pain continued, when I got home and laid down and when to sleep the pain when away except when I turn and moved it would come back. The pain is best describe as a shooting pain in my lower back. When got up on Sunday morning I felt no pain but as I started to move around the pain comes back as a shooting pain in my lower back.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: A/C on the MAI Hanger Ramp should be afforded the same protection to prevent wing damage as required by ground handlers at out stations, i.e., safety cones at wing tips. When the A/C is parked on the ramp for team loading, there is minimal clearance between the R wing tip and the parked GSE for the fueler or caterer. There is not a Ground Safety Report on WBAT so an incident report was initiated as a way to identify a potential issue.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: No event actually occurred. There is not a Ground Safety Report on WBAT so an incident report was initiated as a way to identify a potential issue.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: No event actually occurred. Talked with VP OPS about situation and was advised to fill out report.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: No event actually occurred. MAI ramp personnel should be required to comply with the same procedures as ground handlers at out stations in order to lessen the potential for A/C damage due to wing tip clearance.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Mr. Imbrieco and Mr. Martinez found that circular saw used in hangar was missing the safety cover (see attached picture). The power cord on the saw was cut off immediately to prevent further usage and the Director of Purchase, Ms. Jimenez was directed to purchase a new saw equipped with the proper safety features.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
I was entering into the ladies restroom infront of the break room on the 3rd floor at around 10:20 am and I slipped and was able to hold myself up with the wall so I did not fall to the floor. Dustin was walking by the hall and saw me as I was trying to see what was on the floor that made it slippery.
I noticed grease on the floor and I threw paper over it and put a small rug over it, so that I may go look for Felimon. I found Felimon and he cleaned the area up but then I overheard Maria Pottinger say that she also slipped she did fall to the ground. Maria and I are both entering this info in WBAT to see if something can be done to avoid someone else from falling.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: I believe the floor was cleaned with some checmical that is still on the floor and that water will not take it away... the area needs to be checked out to avoid someone else from falling.

The bees appear to be making a nest. The bees are very active and the swarm is the size of a watermelon. Luigi was advised of the issue.

CAPT CALLED VIA SAT PHONE TO ADV ENCOUNTERED POSITIVE 25KTS WINDSHEAR ON FINAL EXECUTE A MISSED APPROACH AND HOLDING. ADVISED CAPT OF WX REPORT AT PLANNED ALTN-KGSO. CHECKED FUEL ON BOARD...CAPT REPORTED 2.8KGS. WE BOTH AGREED TO PROCEED TO ALTN.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
The following narrative has been transcribed word for word from an email sent by Cpt. Steve Russo to Chief Pilot John Passwater the morning after the incident:
"This letter is an incident report that occurred on 26 march 2014 at ASIG North ramp. BSK 550 departed YQG Windsor, ONT. to DTW Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport. Weather was VFR upon arrival at 2050Z, 1650 lcl time. We landed on 21L and exited to the right to taxi north on whiskey, cross 9L, left on Papa I made the comment to FO Nicolaas Kuyper that taxiway was in need of repair. Upon arrival at ASIG North ground personal where marshaling us onto their ramp nose to the west. I again made a comment to FO Kuyper that North ramp was in very bad shape. I have enclosed pictures of ramp condition and a video of poor repair patch.
We cleared customs and where re-positioning under power to ASIG South. Because we were empty with a light fuel load, I elected to start number 2 and perform a single engine taxi. While applying thrust to taxi straight ahead then a left turn, I noticed that marshaler made a surprised facial expression however he continued to marshal us from the ramp. I told FO Kuyper that marshaler made a surprised expression that I did not understand. I did not use excessive thrust to taxi from ramp. We made a left onto Papa and I looked back to ASIG North ramp and could see that ground personnel were looking at damage on the ramp.
Re-position to ASIG South was uneventful. After shnutting down I asked FO Kuyper to accompany me on a post flight inspection because I wanted two sets of eyes to check for FOD damage to the engine. NUmber 2 engine did not sustain any damage however the aircraft right horizontal stabilizer leading edge had received puncture damage.
Bill Hardin, General Manager ASIG was on scene right away and provided us with assets to inspect aircraft more closely. He expressed to me that he has spoken with airport authority about condition of North ramp and that surface was not stable. I also spoke to driver that took us back to North ramp for pictures and he said large aircraft did not park on North ramp only small business jets parked there."
--Capt. S.P. Russo

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Ramp where aircraft was parked to clear customs was in poor condition.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: Excerpt from Cpt. Steve Russo's report: "...While applying thrust to taxi straight ahead then a left turn, I noticed that the marshaler made a surprised facial expression however he continued to marshal us from the ramp. I told FO Kuyper that marshaler made asurprised expression that I did not understand....I looked back to ASIG North ramp and could see that ground personnel were looking at damage on the ramp."

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: 4 Radio calls @< 100NM. no answer. 1 phone call to operations on the ground. No answer.

attribute.name: other_aircraft/pilot
attribute.value: A/C preceding us very slow to exit runway

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: 8 mile in trail of A/C landing RWY 28. Preceding A/C took extremely long time to exit runway due to high speed taxiway BB closed and A/C had to roll to end. At 100' executed go around as A/C had not completely cleared runway and tower had not issued a landing clearance. Also, due to construction and A/C lined up for departures, it took 38 minutes to taxi from landing runway to ramp.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Preceding A/C took extremely long time to exit runway due to high speed taxiway BB closed and A/C had to roll to end.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: Preceding A/C had not completely cleared runway and tower had not issued a landing clearance.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: ATC should advise A/C on runway where following A/C is and encourage them to expedite their exiting of the runway. Allow more spacing between A/C on final due to taxiway closures and long length of runway.

attribute.name: mental_symptoms
attribute.value: Accidentally Performing Wrong Task/Action;Difficulty Concentrating on Task/Action;Failure to Anticipate Events/Actions;Lapses in Attention

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
09JUL12
On 07JUL12 at around 0939L (1339z) Miami Air Scheduling Dept. notified me that I would be placed on short-call reserve at 2000L/07JUL12 // (0000z)/08JUL12. Reserve availability period to end 1959L (2359z) 08JUL12 a total of 23+59 hrs.
On 07JUL12 at around 0939L (1339z) Miami Air Scheduling Dept. also notified me that I had a trip assignment after completion of the short-call reserve for 08JUL12 following such reserve availability period.

During Flight Segment 3 (MCO to MIA) I believe I may have become fatigued due to being scheduled by the company beyond limitations as established by FAR 117.
FAR 117 Limitations exceeded by the FDP on (08 thru 09JUL12)
FAR 117.21 Reserve status. Section (c) For short call reserve,
(1) The reserve availability period may not exceed 14 hours.
(2) For a flight crew member who has completed a reserve availability period, no certificate holder may schedule and no flight crew member may accept an assignment of a reserve availability period unless the flight crew member receives the required rest in Â§ 117.25(e).
[Â§ 117.25(e) affords the flight crew member a rest period of at least 10 consecutive hours immediately before beginning the reserve or flight duty period. As such the company stood in violation of section (c) (2) at report time of 0325L / 0725z (09JUL12) for not providing a 10 hour consecutive rest period.]
FAR 117.25 Rest period. (e) No certificate holder may schedule and no flight crew member may accept an assignment for any reserve or flight duty period unless the flight crew member is given a rest period of at least 10 consecutive hours immediately before beginning the reserve or flight duty period measured from the time the flight crew member is released from duty. The 10 hour rest period must provide the flight crew member with a minimum of 8 uninterrupted hours of sleep opportunity.
Violation of 117.25 section (e) occurred at report time of 0325L / 0725z (09JUL12) for not providing a 10 hour consecutive rest period immediately before beginning the flight duty period.
FAR 117.11 Flight Time Limitation. Table A Scheduled Time of Start (0325L) MAX FLIGHT TIME LIMIT = 8+00
8+25 scheduled FLIGHT TIME exceeded this limitation; 8+20 Actual FLIGHT TIME exceeded this limitation
FAR 117.13 Flight Duty Period: Unaugmented operations Table B Scheduled Time of Start (0325L) Number of Flight Segments (3)
MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 09+00 12+25 scheduled FDP exceeded this limitation; 12+20 Actual FDP exceeded this limitation

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On Septembet 18, I went on A/C N753MA at the hangar to check on the Jeppesen library. In the USA volume 1, I found that out of 17 revisions 7 of them were not signed off. Also the "Q" book contained all 8 "Q" updates when it should have contained only 2.(The other six were out of date and should have been discarded). I have since then replaced the volume 1 on this aircraft with new contents from Jeppesen. I have also corrected the contents in the "Q" volume.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On preflight crew O2 gage dropped to zero with L & R pilot O2 mask test.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Maintenance determined O2 supply bottle had been turned off.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
In the past week, I experienced two like events where the ground staff attempted to pushback the aircraft from the gate with the parking brake set and without the appropriate clearance from Air Traffic Control.
The first instance occured on LL640 (17DEC09) with Captain Ross Fischer.
The second occured on LL644 (19DEC09) with FO Jan Slingenberg.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value:
Two primary reasons and company SOP's were violated.
1. The pushback crew had no headsets to effectively communicate with the cockpit.
2. Lack of ability to maintain conversational english on the part of the tug driver.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value:
When it was apparent that the tug was pushing against the aircraft, with the parking brake set, we opened the window and yelled, in english to STOP, since they had no headset. Either they did not understand the english or the outside noise level was too high for us to be heard.
With regard to LL644 on 19DEC09, I asked Dispatcher Slettmo to contact the Ground Handling company and get the name of a shift supervisor. The person who answered the telephone refused to provide this information to the Dispatcher.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Company SOP's regarding the use of headsets during pushback operations should be strictly observed, when possible. If no headset is available, then prior communication between the tug driver and the pilots is essential to make certain that all parties involved have a clear understanding as to how to safely push back and tow the aircraft.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Received an email from Blake Anderson, Air Safety Investigator for Delta Airlines regarding the condition of the aircraft parking area adjacent to Atlantice Aviation. Please see attachments to this report with pictures and a copy of the briefing paper regarding the debris from crumbling concrete in the parking area where Miami Air normally park their aircraft. This debris could be sucked into an engine, resulting in major damage.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: There are political issues between the airport authority and Atlantic Aviation. We are not in a position to have any authority to get this issue resolved. All we can do is ensure our aircraft do not taxi into, park at, or taxi out of areas where there is debris.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Two climb RA alerts while on arrival to KPGD. Had visual contact, no deviation from clearance.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Large amount of flight training and gen aviation in area.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: We were cleared for take-off so I brought both thrust levers up to 40%. Two stable I pushed TOGA and we got a master caution, ENG and both EECs had gone to ALT mode. I rejected the take-off slow seed abort, cleared the runway, ran the checklist for Alt EECs and the Rejected Take-off checklist and turned the aircraft over to Maintenance who could not duplicat the problem. Log book was signed and mission completed.

attribute.name: fatigue_contributing_factors
attribute.value: ;Insufficient Rest Period;Long Duty Period;Tried Prior to Start of Duty Period

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: I received a call from crew scheduling at 3 pm December 30th notifying me, I had 1:30hrs to report in the crew room for a trip. The trip was a ferry flight to PGD then a turn. PGD to IAG followed by a van ride back to MIA arriving 4:30am local time the next day. After reviewing the trip, I notified crew scheduling I would not be safe. And that I have already been on airport standby ( short call ) for 20hrs. It is my opinion that the leg from IAG to PGD leaving at 11:00 pm arriving PGD at 01:30 am local would be too much. I woke this morning at 5 am and I would not have a chance to get any rest for over 24 hrs. I would have been on duty for over 33 hrs straight, operating the entire time during the window of circadian low. I promptly received a call form my chief pilot requesting an explanation of, whether I was sick or fatigued. After clarifying I felt the assignment would be unsafe I was told to file a fatigue report ASAP. At no time was a hotel or schedule change offered.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Airport standby ("short call") should reflect the new CFR's as a proven science we need now. Not in two years. It is unreasonable to expect someone to be ready to fly all night, then expect them to be fit for duty 20hs later. If the company wants that amount of flexibility, they should loosen the purse strings and staff realistically.

attribute.name: factors
attribute.value: ;Fatigue/Lack of Alertness;On Time Performance Pressure;Operational Time Pressure, Delays, Push for On Time Performance

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: After pushback from stand 10A, ground crew was told to disconnect towbar and show us the bypass pin. Tug and towbar were clear of the aircraft and ramp worker on aircraft left was holding a pin in his hand, showing the crew. After accomplishing the BEFORE TAXI CHECKLIST and receiving clearance to taxi, we realized that we had no control of our nose steering. The aircraft was stopped, ground crew notified and the bypass pin was removed. Apparently, the ramp worker was not experienced with our aircraft and was showing us the tow bar pin.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value:
Several factors contributed. All week long at this same station the ground crew was using a bypass pin without a REMOVE BEFORE FLIGHT streamer. It was always included in our briefing between the pilots and the flight mechanic, as well as the pushback crew. However, somehow this time something was missed. I had not noticed this individual working our aircraft in previous stops at this station.
Language barrier was also a factor. Limited ability on our part to speak French and on the part of the ramp workers to speak English.
Finally, crew fatigue. Our crew had a very long day, the day before. With only 8 hours in the hotel and upon checking in for our scheduled one leg day, a 20 minute flight, we were informed that we now had to work 6 legs and have another long duty day because another crew was not legal. By the end of this second, unplanned, long day, we were noticibly fatigued, including this fact in every briefing but still simple errors were starting to creep in by the end of the day.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: Ground crew was notified to come back to the aircraft and remove the bypass pin. They were also seen "harrassing" the "new guy" for his error.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value:
First and foremost, PTP ground operations needs to have a REMOVE BEFORE FLIGHT streamer on the bypass pin. Any color will do but something that will help the flight crew visually determine that they are being shown the correct pin after pushback.
If communication verbally is not possible, an additional ground person should be available to utilize universal hand signals, rather than the limited verbal communication abilities between the flight crew and the tug driver.
