category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
The following narrative involves an incident on N742MA - Captain R. Clager / First Officer R. Garcia on 3 Jan 2010.
At approximately 4 pm on Sunday, January 03, 2010, N742MA landed on Rwy 24R at CYUL. The aircraft taxied to the Starlink FBO ramp adjacent to the departure end of Rwy 24L and blocked in at 4:15 pm. While on the Starlink FBO Ramp, the aircraft was catered for the Buffalo Sabres Hockey team for the flight from CYUL to KBUF scheduled for a 7pm departure.
At approximately 6pm, N742MA started engines to reposition from Starlink FBO ramp to gate 72 at CYUL. N742MA exited the Starlink ramp at the same point of entry earlier, between previously plowed snowbanks adjacent to taxiway R. The aircraft taxied onto Twy R and turned right towards the Hold Short position for Rwy 24L as instructed by ATC. Prior to reaching the Hold Short Point, the aircraft felt as though the nose wheel had turned sideways on the hard packed snow on Twy R and power was added to assist the turn. The aircraft did not continue to move forward or turn and it was determined that the right main wheel assembly had either become stuck in a small snowbank, had displaced a grate on the tarmac under the snow, or had left the paved surface under the snow, contrary to what is depicted on the Jeppesen Airfield diagram as a fully paved area. The engines were immediately secured (the APU was still online and providing electrical power and air conditioning for the repositioning of the aircraft).
Starlink FBO personnel brought out stairs and the right main assembly was inspected by the flight crew and flight mechanic. The flight mechanic decided that there was no damage to the right main wheel assembly or tires and suggested the aircraft be towed forward by a tug. Multiple attempts to free the aircraft by tug were unsuccessful and maintenance control directed that no further attempts would be made.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: The event occurred because the ramp & taxiway (Taxiway R) adjacent to the Starlink FBO were covered/obscured by snow and the Jeppeson Airfield diagram for CYUL (Chart 10-9) did not accurately depict the unpaved areas which existed between the ramp and Taxiway R and unpaved area NE of the Starlink FBO ramp and the Hold Short area for Runway 24 L.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Aircrew should realize that, despite their best efforts to safely taxi aircraft in snow covered or otherwise adverse conditions, that errors in publications upon which all pilots rely may, in fact, contain errors which may lead to incidents such as this one. These errors must be brought to the attention of those responsible for the publication of such information to ensure as much accuracy as possible, and aircrew must be aware that these errors can and do exist in the publications we are to utilize and to exercise extreme caution when adverse weather conditions exist which increase aircrew reliance on these publications.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On rotation for Takeoff (PIC as PF) RWY 09 at KCID, the aircraft tailskid scraped the runway surface.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value:
Unknown. Rough runway at KCID and gusty wind conditions may have contributed as a causal factor. Aircraft payload was at the maximum contracted weight of 18K, however this was calculated using approved average weights, not actual weights. If actual weight was greater than the average weights utilized, then OPT V1, Vr, V2 calculations would have been inaccurate and may have contributed as a causal factor.
Thu, 18 Feb 2010 17:03 Z RWY 09 at KCID is scheduled for resurfacing due to its condition. It is possible that the area on that runway at which rotation took place was at the intersection of the crossing runway which is listed as being in good condition. Reduced tailskid clearance due to the poor condition of the active runway and the crown of the crossing runway may have been a causal factor.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: The flightcrew and inflight mechanic on jumpseat heard/felt tailskid scrape on Takeoff. On climbout, FA from rear of aircraft also called cockpit to confirm tail contact w/ runway on Takeoff.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: The flightcrew determined that there were no immediate airworthiness issues as a result of the event, accomplished QRH procedures (Tailstrike on Takeoff QRH p.15.6) and diverted to KSTL. The aircraft landed at KSTL at 1655z, and inspections were conducted by the mechanic per the maintenance manual regarding the tailskid damage and the overweight landing at KSTL. The inspections were completed, the aircraft was refueled, refiled, and continued on to the passengers original destination (MDPC) at 1800z.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Continue to exercise vigilence and extreme caution / care on takeoff rotation with heavily loaded aircraft in gusty wind conditions on poorly- surfaced / rough runways.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)
Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)
Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On February 18th, 2012 we had a 02:15 am local report time. The trip sequence started the day prior with a 04:45 am report, which I was notified on the 16th of the trip. I normally try to adjust my sleeping pattern if I am given adequate notice to do so, however I didnâ€™t know about the trip early enough on the 16th to make any adjustments. I adjusted the sleeping pattern on the 17th. The 18th consisted of a four leg day flying out of a maintenance base with several deferred items, including an inoperative APU. Our day was scheduled to fly into the Caribbean airports (PUJ, AUA & MBJ). The fact that the APU was inop and getting the satisfactory ground equipment made for a challenging day alone not to mention we started at 2:15 am. Experiencing an inoperative APU caused extra delays on the tarmac and required extra communication with the ground handlers who in many cases did not answer their radios or said they were on their way when it took them a long time to arrive with the proper equipment. Itâ€™s hard to put into words or to quantify the degree of fatigue this trip caused, but the captain and I both agree that it was a fatiguing day and I therefore felt it required a fatigue report. Scheduled for 9:25 hours of flying with a duty day of 14:55. We ended up flying 10:35 minutes and having 15:40 minutes of duty time.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Avoid four legs that start with a 2:15 am local report time. The first ferry leg INT - BOS could have been flown the day prior.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: About thru the flight from TLH to MIA I heard over the service intercom that FA Christine Proskie wasn't feeling well. At around 500 feet AGL landing in MIA Purser Brulz called me and said that FA Proskie was passed out and needed the paramedics. I called the tower immediately and asked for the paramedics to meet us at the gate. We pulled up to the gate and the paramedics were there within 2 minutes. FA Proskiewas taken outside into the terminal. After the passsengers were deplaned, I went into the terminal to see the condition of FA Proskie. The paramedics released her but one of the paramedics pulled me to the side and told me that she was seeing evil spirits and was trying to cast them out. FA Proskie got back on the airplane and we taxied back to Miami Air's hangar. After we parked, Purser Anita Brulz came to me and said that FA Proskie was sick again and was laying down on teh seats. I went to see heer and saw that she had a plastic bag over her mouth likme she was getting ready to vomit. I told her that she could stay in the airplane until she felt better. I didn't want her to come down the stairs if she was feeling dizzy. However, she said she was fine and proceeded to get off the airplane and sat down on a chair. I left the hangar but had to return to retrieve the Trip Envelope. FA Proskie was now sitting in the breakroom. Mr. Rafael de la Paz told me that FA Proskie wanted me to leave the hangar and that she was " walking around like a zombie" and makeing the cross sign with her hands. I called Ms. Billie De Palma a second tine and told her that FA Proskie was still in teh hangar. Ms. DePalma recommended that I call the paramedics one more time. I called MIA ground control and asked for the paramedics a second time. Again they arrive a few minutes later. P.S. attached is the name of the paramedic that assisted FA Proskie - Lt. Keith Seafield, Rescue 12 (MIA) Website (Divine Trinity)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: During climbout experienced loud air noise at L1 door with the cabin not pressurizing. Leveled at 5000 feet for radar vectors to ILS 28R PIT. Read door latches had not engaged at L1 door. Mechanic inspected and Reseated door. Pressurization checked good on the ground. Rereleased to KFLI.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Door was closed by mechanic who did not properly verify door closure. Contributing cause may have been snow and ice accumulation in and around the door seal during time on the ground.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On 03/20/2010 aircraft N733MA, MSN 30619 departed Houston(HOU) with no passengers on board. Aircraft could not pressurize and aircraft returned to HOU for maintenance. Maintenance found L1 door locked but not sealed properly. Found #2 alignment pin out of adjustment.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Our crew of 6 checked in at 9:00am local for a flight to SKB then to SFB where we were scheduled to be picked up by the Miami Air crew van and driven back to Miami, a 4 to 4.5 hour drive beginning at 7:45pm. The driver was there on time and we began our drive to Miami. I questioned the driver as to what he had done prior to picking us up. He stated that he had driven another crew to SFB in the morning and had just been "hanging out" until we arrived. After dropping off the other crew, he had about 7 hours in between drives that he could have been resting in a hotel room, but Miami Air management didn't provide him with that option. My casual observation of the driver indicated that he was fatigued.
About 1.5 hours into the drive, I noticed that the driver was starting to have trouble staying in one lane, periodically drifting from the left lane to the center and back again. About 2.5 hours into the drive, the driver drifted off the roadway and onto the shoulder of the road. Several of the other crew members including my self, yelled at the driver who was startled and drove back onto the road. We stopped in Ft. Pierce for about 15 minutes to stretch and "wake-up". The driver was asked repeatedly if he was OK to continue driving and he replyed that he was. We arrived in Miami a little after midnight without further incident.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: This event occurred because the driver was fatigued from not being afforded adequate facilities in which to rest. We were just split seconds away from a real disaster. If the van would have continued to drive off the paved shoulder catching the soft dirt, this would have been a real disaster at the speed were were traveling, we would have made the headlines and people probably would have lost their lives.. Also, on the other side, if another car or truck had been next to us on the right side when the driver drifted into the center lane, another impending disaster.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: Driver was drifting from lane to lane, then off the road

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: Stopped the van in order to wake up the driver

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: I'm told that our agreement with Luigi is that a van trip over 3.5 hours requires a day room for the driver prior to the beginning of a trip. Luigi is under the mistaken impression that a drive from Sanford, or even Orlando (which is a little closer) takes 3.5 hours or less. That's possible if you drive at 90 and don't hit any traffic. Once again, someone is "pinching the buck" and putting our crews at risk. Also, the driver had already driven a trip beginning in the early morning hours to SFB and then had to wait all day before picking us up. Whoever scheduled this used very poor judgement. Either require the driver to rest in a day room, or hire a professional company to do the driving.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Potential Hazard. We have noticed that the wood floors in Crew Scheduling are warping and are lifted in some areas. Someone needs to take a look at them.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: L1 windscreen developed fire on window heating element on climbout (passing 33000 feet climbing to assigned altitude of 37000 feet). Window heat secured to L1 windscreen (it cracked outer pane top to bottom shortly thereafter). Flight crew complied with QRH procedures (Electrical Fire & Cracked windscreen) notified ATC that flight was going to return to AMS, notified MAI Ops, MAI maint, Servisair (AMS) and Purser / passengers of the nature of the problem/reason for return. Aircraft returned to AMS without further incident.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: L1 Window heating element failure causing "arc" ing and windscreen fire.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: We were third A/C to land o newly displaced thresholc RWY 08 FRU. On downwind FRU Approach Control reminded us of Ruwy Shortening. On 4 mi. final FRU Tower said "disregard runway markings". Very busy radio at this time. Flew normal approach to Rwy and arrested our descent at approx 50 to 70 feet to touchdown at new threshhold.RWY was clear. Found out later that actual transmission was "disregard runway distance remaining markers"

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Busy ATC radios and confusing info from ATC.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Low Speed Abort due to take-off configuration warning horn. Cleared Rwy 21L at intersection W 4 and stopped aircraft until problem resolved. Suspected spoiler not fully down position. Recycled spoilers and coulc not duplicate problem.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
As I was entering our Miami Air office on July 11th @ 08:10 am local time I was going up to the 3rd floor via the stairs and I noticed a piece of the tile roof on the floor on the carper of the stairs.
Immediately I looked up and saw that there were various areas of the roof that have tiles hanging off just that may possibly come down at some point.
I had to proceed to the morning meeting but once the meeting finished I informed Joe Obermeir and Joe and I both went to go look once agaian and Joe saw the tiles on the carpet as wellas some metal pieces that hold up these tile about to fall off.
I then proceeded to enter info in WBAT.

attribute.value:

Immediately I looked up and saw that there were various areas of the roof that have tiles hanging off just that may possibly come down at some point.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
30MAR12 Scheduled on duty Report time was 0135L (0535z) Augmented Flight Crew (3 Pilots) Scheduled 4 flight segments
Scheduled Trip 30MAR12 MIA to LEX (BSK544) 0705z to 0930z LEX to MSY (BSK640) 1100z to 1255z MSY to LEX (BSK542) 1355z to 1540z LEX to MSY (BSK642) 1710z to 1905z
Scheduled Off Duty Release time 1935z (30MAR12)
Total Scheduled FDP (Flight duty period) 13+30 Total Scheduled work hours on company time (On Duty to Scheduled Release) 14+00
Actual Trip Block times 30MAR12 Actual on duty Report time was 0135L (0535z)
MIA to LEX (BSK544) 0650z to 0910z LEX to MSY (BSK640) 1115z to 1310z MSY to LEX (BSK542) 1355z to 1550z LEX to MSY (BSK642) 1710z to 1920z
Actual Off Duty Release time 1950z / 1450L (30MAR12) Actual Hotel Check-in time 2030z / 1530L (30MAR12)
Actual Total completed work hours (On Duty to Actual Release) 14+15 Actual Total completed work hours on company time (On Duty to Hotel check-in) 14+55
Actual FDP 13+45 (Ending at Aircraft Block-in Time)
During Flight Segment 4 (LEX to MSY) I believe I may have become fatigued due to the long duty day and due to being scheduled by the company beyond limitations as established by FAR 117.
Fatigue set in also due to fellow co-workers not following established procedures to enhance pilot rest in a designated Miami Air cabin (passenger) seat. The Normal seats reserved for APC duties were not blocked out by the flight crew and regular customers were permitted to use them. In addition Miami Air APC delegated seats do not satisfy the requirements of a Class 3 rest facility and are less than adequate.
Furthermore I would like to report that on flight segment 4 the other FO did not have to sit in an aisle seat as I had during my delegated rest on flight segment 2. In the aisle seat and with 2 other revenue customers sitting immediately next to me the rest facility provided to me was quite unfair. There were many times that I was bumped by traffic in the aisle while trying to rest.
Also I have filed legitimate grievances concerning the same issue in the past and have suffered retribution by the company for doing so. Therefore I did not make any confrontation with the flight crew because in essence I learned my lesson the last time. The company has created and continues to endorse a climate of intimidation for people like me that have tried to do the right thing and educate fellow crew members of FAA approved pilot crew rest procedures in the past only to be subject to negative consequences and continued harassment and abuse as one of the companies â€œwhipping boysâ€. In essence, company management supports favorites when it comes to following the FAA approved procedures and does not support their own written procedures concerning individual employees that it does not consider in good favor.
I am certain that the company culture as indicated also contributed to my fatigue and an inability to achieve good rest while not standing duty in flight as a pilot behind one of the two controls either acting as PM or PF
.
FAR 117 Limitations exceeded by the FDP on 30MAR12.
FAR 117.17 Flight Duty Period: Augmented flight crew Table C Scheduled Time of Start (0135L) Number of Flight Segments (4) Number of Pilots (3) Less than Class Three Rest Facility
MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD (For Class Three Rest Facility) = 13+00 MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD Table B (due to Lack of Class Three Rest Facility) = 9+00 13+30 scheduled FDP exceeded this limitation; 13+45 Actual FDP exceeded this limitation
Miami Air B737â€™s pilots rest facility does not qualify as a Class Three Rest Facility
For Reference: Class 3 rest facility means a seat in an aircraft cabin or flight deck that reclines at least 40 degrees and provides leg and foot support.
Please Note As a reference towards the progress of Miami Air complying with FAR 117 I would like to include the following:
Beginning in January of 2012 under the new unenforceable regulation FAR 117, I have now completed 19 FDPâ€™s (Flighty Duty Periods) as a pilot in flight.
Of the 19 FDPâ€™s thus far 10 of them have exceeded limitations as established in FAR 117.
The following cases as acclimated and augmented:
(25 thru 26MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 13+20, Report 1200L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 13+50 Due to Lack of a Class 3 Rest Facility TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 13+00
(30MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 13+30, Report 0130L, 4 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 13+45 Due to Lack of a Class 3 Rest Facility TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 9+00 TABLE C MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 13+00
The following cases as acclimated and unaugmented:
(01JAN12) FDP Scheduled total 12+20, Report 0645L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 12+50 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 12+00
(03JAN12) FDP Scheduled total 13+45, Report 0130L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 14+05 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 9+00
(23JAN12) FDP Scheduled total 12+20, Report 1200L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 11+30 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 10+00
(23FEB12) FDP Scheduled total 13+35, Report 0400L, 4 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 12+27 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 10+00
(27 and 28FEB12) FDP Scheduled total 19+55, Report 1720L, 2 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 25+40 Reserve availability and FDP combined Violation of FAR117.21(c) (1), (2), (3) and FAR 117.25(e) TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 16+00
(01MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 11+25, Report 0430L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 11+15 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 10+00 FLIGHT TIME Scheduled total 8+25, Actual FLIGHT TIME total 8+35 TABLE A MAX FLIGHT TIME 8+00
(18MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 21+30, Report 0730L, 2 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 22+00 Reserve availability and FDP combined Violation of FAR117.21(c) (2), (3) and FAR 117.25(e) TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 16+00
(21 thru 22MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 26+40, Report 1545L, 4 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 22+40 FDP 21/22MAR combined as Split Duty with FDP 22MAR12 combined Violation of FAR 117.15(d),(f), 117.21(d),(e), and FAR 117.25(e)

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value:
COMPLY WITH FAR 117 FOR SCHEDULED TRIPS, FLIGHT DUTY PERIODS, REQUIRED REST PERIODS, SHORT-CALL LIMITATIONS AND RESERVE STATUS REQUIREMENTS AS SET FORTH UTILIZING TABLES A, B, AND C.
IN ADDITION A CHANGE IN CLIMATE AT THE COMPANY MUST CHANGE THAT ALLOWS COMPANY "FAVORITES" TO GET AWAY WITH THINGS THAT "UNFAVORITES" DO NOT.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On climb out off of 23R the lower display came up indicationg low quantity in Eng #1 of 3 liters and Eng #2 indicated 7 liters. Descending # enging began rising to 6 liters and we landed with 7 liters. Eng #2 raised to 9 in the descent and we landed with 10 liters. After blocking in for 10 mins Eng #1 came up to 10 liters and Eng #2 came up to 12 liters.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Oil system indicated low quantity during climb.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)
Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Upon leaving the office for the day on Thursday November 1, 2012 I proceeded to my car parked in the MAI executive parking lot on the east side of the Pan Am Flight Academy. My car was the last executive car parked in the lot. MG Bus had a large bus parked diagonally with the rear of the bus adjacent to the hose nozzle on the outside of the pan am building. There was a panel open on the rear of the bus and fluid was being drained from the bus and was puddling around the area enough that the fluid was underneath my car and had to be stepped in for me to enter my car. I asked the personnel at the MG bus what the fluid was as the odor from the fluid had a sewage smell. The person told me the sink on the bus was leaking. I challenged him and asked if it was sewage from a bathroom on the bus. He hesitated to answer then said no. He immediately grabbed the hose and began spraying hose water on the parking lot. I got in my car, drove a few feet away and watched them bring another large bus to the MAI executive parking area and maintenance on that bus second bus commenced.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: I leave the office many evenings after 6 or 7 pm, many times the last car of the MAI executive staff. I often see bus maintenance being performed on that lot. I have previously reported tires being left leaning on our wall and other litter being left on the sidewalk near our parking spaces.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Billie Di Palma called me to inform me that there was a recurrence of an issue reported a few months ago regarding the air conditioning vents in the Inflight Department (suite 308)
Again, the vent is giving off a black powder and film that is all over their desks and floors, ruining paperwork and having the potential to cause health problems.
I went over and took pictures. I also informed the Armando Martinez, Director of Safety. He also went to take a look to confirm the report.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: There is something wrong with the air conditioning vents.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Due to sports event accommodations for crew after flight were not available. See attachment.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Travel failed obtain positive confirmation of reservations, due to international travel communication via cell phone was unavailable, and there should be better communication between travel, crew scheduling, and dispatch about crew accommodations. Perhaps a free email account could be set up for crew members to use when cellular service is unavailable.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: During descent to approach into KCMH Rwy 10R flaps selected to 10 degrees. Once Flaps 15 were selected the flaps were unresponsive and remained at 10 degrees. Followed Trailing Flap Disagree Checklist and used Alt Flap Syst. which induced a flap split assymetry. Followed Trailing Edge Flap Assymetry Checklist and uneventful landing at Flaps 10 degrees on Rwy 10R (10000) field required 4750 ft.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Holding short of Runway 36R at LTAI. Tower cleared us to Line Up and Wait behind the landing traffic and be ready for immediate take-off. Lined-up on 36R, Tower cleared us for take-off. At approx. 20 knots ground speed, tower cancelled our take-off clearance and cleared an aircraft on final to go-around as the aircraft which landed delayed exiting the runway. Tower asked us if we could accept a take-off from our present position. We stated we needed full length. ATC cleared us to exit on taxiway P. Took-off on Runway 36R in sequence as normal. Tech log page 235650.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: I received a call as the Operations Duty Officer at approximately 0030L on 10 July from the Dispatcher Joel Harreld. He ad vised me that the flight scueduled to depart Kadena AB Japan to Guam was returning to the gate because the required predeparture service check (PDSC) had not been accomplished. At approximately 0200L on the same date I received a call from Maintenance Controller Vincint Gonzalez that Flight Mechanic Masik had advised him that the PDSC had also not been accomplished on the flight from Guam to Kadena. Mr Gonzalez stated that the flight mecanic had been advised by the flight crew that a PDSC was not required for that leg.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Flight crew erroneously thought that the flight did not require ETOPS procedures.

category.name: Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: There is an electrical box on the western side of the MAI Hangar with an open panel and thick electrical wires cut and exposed. Unsure if the wires are live.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Possible improper maintenance on the electrical box. Panel left open, exposing cut wires.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: MAI Safety Hotline called. Safety department investigated and took pictures. See attachment.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Heavy frost on wings requiring De-ice, taxied to de-ice pad and completed procedure with engines running. Upon completion reconfigured A/C and taxied for takeoff. During reading of the OPS 611 post application checklist, the item complete before taxi checklist was passed over by the FO and not caught by the CAPT. At some point in the process, the right side probe heat switch had moved to the off position and by not repeating the before taxi check, it was not identified.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: By missing the item, before taxi checklist complete, the probe heat was not rechecked and recall was not rechecked that would have identified the issue.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: On takeoff roll, Master Caution light illuminated with ENG segment.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: Aborted takeoff, exited runway and saw R side probe heat was not on. Placed switch in proper position, requested engine run-up from ground controller. Completed with no issues, returned for takeoff without incident.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Amend OPS 611 so that the complete before taxi checklist is on it so crew is not required to go back and forth between checklists. At a minimum, add recall check to the de-icing before takeoff checklist to aid in identifying a potential problem.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
New Years report Local on duty time was 0145L (0645z) just after New Years eve celebrations.
MIA to PGD (Limosine crew of 6) 0715z to 0935z PGD to ORH (BSK5802) 1200z to 1458z ORH to SFB (BSK5805) 1610z to 1905z
Off Duty 1935z Hotel Check-in 2005z
I was notified of the scheduled one day trip at around 0900L (1400z) 31DEC2011 after going to sleep at my normal circadium rythm friday night 30DEC2011 after getting an 11 hour notice the prior evening at 1901L (0001z 31DEC) of my placement to short-call (reserve) that began at 0600L (1100z) 31DEC2011. My wife began to enquire about getting some rest and going back to bed soon at around 1030L (1530z) 31DEC2011 because of the early report time of 0145L (0645z) 01JAN2012. I explained to her that even if I went to bed that I would not go to sleep because I had gone to bed friday night to be sure I was rested in case I was called out from short-call (reserve) during that particular day 31DEC2011. Therefore there is no way I could appropriate rest for both requirements.
I completed 13 hours of short-call standby (reserve) from home on 31 DEC 2011. From 0600L (1100z) to 1900L (2400z)
Following this I received 6:45 hours rest prior to report time (0645z 01JAN2012) Of the 6:45 rest approximately, 2-2.5 hours of time spent in preparation to arrive at report time from home.
Despite efforts by the entire crew to rest the day and night of 31DEC2011 prior to Miami Air scheduled report time all crew members discussed difficulties in getting adequate rest due to Fireworks nearby everyones' homes that evening.
Due to a long scheduled crew van ride from Miami Airport (Miami Air Office Headquarters) to PGD airport of 3 hours and appropriate new years's events the company should have realized the gravity of such a situation.
Next year it would be strongly prudent to short call the crew to report on 31DEC in the morning to give them a cew van ride to a hotel near PGD airport because of the New Years expected fireworks and events. This would at the very least avoid the long van ride with tired bodies before setting out on the completion of a scheduled 12:20 duty day. This would cut off a good 3 hours from such a long duty day after fighting to sleep during fireworks that begins after sundown.
Despite strong efforts by all crewmembers to take deep breaths, be team players, and try to complete our duty assignment, I and other crewmembers became fatigued during the last flight segment ORH to SFB.
Lastly, as a point of fact, the 12:20 scheduled duty day with a report time of 0145 local time, New Years night or not, does not comply with the new unenforceable FAA duty fight duty period restrictions. Also, the 6:45 rest after short-call (reserve) assignment does not comply with the new unenforceable FAA duty regulations.

attribute.value:
New Years report Local on duty time was 0145L (0645z) just after New Years eve celebrations.
MIA to PGD (Limosine crew of 6) 0715z to 0935z PGD to ORH (BSK5802) 1200z to 1458z ORH to SFB (BSK5805) 1610z to 1905z
Off Duty 1935z Hotel Check-in 2005z

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Vector to visual approach into PSM. 6 miles from Rwy 34 on 045 heading (approx 90 degrees off final approach course of 345 degrees) Boston Approach advises that a helicopter is in the vicinity, between my aircraft and the intended point of landing, and has my aircraft in sight and that the helicopter will maintain visual separation as I am cleared to intercept localizer Rwy 34 at 2000' for landing Rwy 34 at PSM. At 1/2 mile left of localizer, aircraft captures localizer and turns left to intercept inbound course (345 degrees). Established on localizer and slightly high, aircraft maneuvered to intercept glideslope at YOKNZ at 1700', but upon completion (rollout) of turn onto final approach course, TCAS warning initiates with "Traffic", immediately followed by Resolution Advisory (RA) warning to "Climb". I estimate that at the initiation of the RA, the helicopter was less than 1/2 mile from YOKNZ at 1500' (YOKNZ fix is the Final Approach Fix for ILS Rwy 34 and is "on glideslope" at 1700'). The autopilot was disengaged and the aircraft was maneuvered in compliance with the RA. Once clear of conflict, the aircraft continued on visual approach and was manually flown to uneventful landing on Rwy 34 at PSM. I contacted the controller after the flight and she apologized for the incident as she did not realize that her maneuvering instructions would initiate a TCAS event.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: ATC controller failed to maintain appropriate separation between the only 2 airborne contacts (a helicopter and a 737-800) within a 30 mile radius of KPSM at 2330 local on a clear night.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: Complied with TCAS RA until clear of conflict, then resumed visual approach to uneventful landing Rwy 34 at KPSM.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: ATC should not have helicopter traffic near FAF, and within 500' of the FAF altitude, of approach to active Runway at the same time when vectoring jet traffic to intercept the localizer within 1 mile of the FAF. The helicopter was not on an approach to PSM (probably just transiting the area) and was likely unaware of its proximity (horizontally and vertically) to the FAF for the active runway at PSM as ATC vectored the jet onto the localizer for its approach to landing.

attribute.name: mental_symptoms
attribute.value: ;Difficulty Concentrating on Task/Action;Failure to Anticipate Events/Actions;Failure to Communicate Important Info;Lapses in Attention

attribute.name: fatigue_contributing_factors
attribute.value: Accumulated Fatigue;Arrangement of Pairing Duty Periods

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: I was on a 24 hour brake begining on Dec. 31, 2011, begining at 1901 local to January 1, 2012 1900 local. On January 1, 2012 around 930 am I received an e mail notifying me of a trip on January 3 with a report time at 250 am report time local. At the same time on January 1 I was notified of my short call reserve status begining january 1, 1900 local to january 2, 1900 local. With this information I decided to re-arange my sleep schedule begining the night of January 1 to be able to sleep during the day on January 2, 2012. On the morning of january 2 around 930 am local I was contacted by scheduling department and confirmed for my trip leaving on the January 3 with a 250 am local time report with a 12 hour duty day, my short reserved call status remained in place until 1900 local on January 2, 2012. At around 1210 local on January 2 I was contacted by scheduling to report within 1 hour 30 minute for a 4 leg trip sequence and 12 hour 15 minute duty day, my intentions was to go to sleep early evening on january 2 in preperation for the trip leaving early on january 3 that I was already checked for by the scheduling department. Since I had reduce sleep from the previous day the effects of fatiqued where not that apperant initially since it was in the middle of the day. The fatiqued begun to affect me as the evening of january 2 when on, the fatiqued became borderline exhaustion. If you have any further question please do not hesitate to contact me.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value:
The best way to eliminate this situation from happening again is. 1. Do not place a pilot on a short call status the previous day prior to a flying duty period begining between midnight and 5 am the following day. 2. If a pilot is to be placed on short call status he should be relieved of the short call duty status when the pilot is checked formally by scheduling, for the trip that they are originally assigned that has report time of midnight and 5 am the following day.
If you have any questions please contact me.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Canadian Military fuel truck that approached the aircraft for refueling only had the NATO designation for the type of fuel onboard. The is no reference in the Company manuals to deccode this designation. The fuel onboard was in fact JP-4 which is unsuitable for the B-737. The reporter question the designation and avoid using an unacceptable fuel.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: The Company maunuals did not address the different nomenclature for fuels that could be used.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Company manuals have been revised to include a means of identifying alternate fuel designations.

category.name: Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: A number of the cement bars used to line up the grass and parking spots east of the hangar had broken or crumbled, exposing rusted steel rods that could cause personal injury or damage to vehicles.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: It is the result of wear and tear over the years.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: The county was informed of the safety concern.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Aircraft N738MA was parked on the Atlantic Aviation ramp. It had been brought in by a previous crew the day before. When we arrived at the aircraft, it was around 03:30 LT and it was still dark out on the ramp. The ramp was congested with aircraft from two major conventions in town.
During taxi on the uncontrolled ramp, we only had two ground Marshalls taxing us. The first Marshaller, with wands, was in front of our aircraft. The second Marshaller, with no wands, was at a distance on our left side and under the vertical stabilizer of one of two B-737 parked next to each other.
We began our taxi and came close to hitting the stabilizer of the B-737 (that the second Marshaller was standing under) with our right winglet.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value:
After engine start and after the â€œbefore taxi checklistâ€ was completed, the Marshall in front of our aircraft directed us to taxi forward and make a hard left. The ramp does not have any defined taxi lines or lines depicting its shape, nor does the Jeppesen diagram.
After making the left turn, the Marshaller in front of us was now out of sight and the second Marshaller (who had started on our left) had moved across my field vision and of out of my sight to the right of our aircraft. The First Officer watched the second Marshaller on our right wingtip to see if we were clear to continue taxing North along the row of aircraft. The First Officer, watching the second Marshaller, then said we were clear to continue.
Next, the First Officer saw the first Marshaller, the one with with wands, run about 100 yards from the back of the aircraft to the front right side, where the second Marshaller was standing. The first Marshaller signaled us to stop the aircraft and shut down our engines. I immediately stopped the aircraft and shut down the engines.
We inspected the wingtip to see if there was any damage. There had been no contact with the other aircraft. After talking to the ground personnel, we learned that the first Marshaller had wanted us to make a left, then a right, to go through a narrow opening between the two B-737 w/winglets.
My assessment of why this event occurred is that there was a miscommunication between the two ground Marshalls and with the fight deck. The first Marshaller assumed we knew that he had intended for us to go through the narrow opening between the two B-737s and the second Marshaller did not give any signals to which way to go.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: Marshaller singled us to stop and shut down the aircraft.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value:
We inspected the wingtip to see if there was any damage. There had been no contact with the other aircraft.
I elected to be towed out to the taxiway because I did not think that I could maneuver the airplane under power through the narrow opening to the taxiway. They assured me that I could because the manger on duty had measured the distance between the two B737 and there was five feet of room to maneuver with.
Despite being given this advice, I still elected to be towed between the two B737s. While being towed, the tug could not pull us straight through the opening. They towed us close to one aircraft, at a 45 degree angle to clear the winglets and then put us at another 45 degree angle to clear the nose of the other aircraft. I would guess about 2-3 feet clearance per side.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value:
Atlantic Aviation could use more ground personnel.
Marshallers should be communicating with the flight deck with signals at all times and should be standing in the appropriate place (under the wing tip of the aircraft they want us to taxi between and not under the vertical stabilizer).
One of the B737s should have been moved out of the way, making a clear path to the active taxiway.
Most importantly, improve communication between ground crew and flight deck regarding where they want the aircraft to taxi.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Report time was 19:30 Local (on paper 20:00). Duty time 17:55 (on paper - actual duty time longer). We had one live leg (CMH - UNV) followed by one ferry (UNV - VCV) 5:20 minutes. From there we had two hour van ride from VCV to LAX. Had two more hours at LAX before commercial flight back to MIA. Once in Miami it was 2 pm Sunday. Driving home was challenging. Before I stated this trip sequence, I asked scheduling for a room in LAX but they denied it saying that my day was perfectly legal. I did not check the extended duty day box on my bid sheet. I thought anything over 16 need my permission. A hotel in MIA wasn't offered either and I had to drive home. The trip was a Saturday evening report to fly all night to then commercial all morning and early afternoon home arriving Sunday 2 pm loacal.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: I think the two legs on the back side of the clock would have been alright. It was the two hour van ride to the airport followed by the two hour sit at the airport waiting for the flight that put me over the top in tiredness. The flight back from the west coast was then over four hours. I would have preferred to layover in LAX and had a fresh start on Sunday instead of continuing the back side of clock trip.

attribute.name: other_physical_fatigue_symptoms
attribute.value: Errors copying clearance and readbacks of ATC freqs and instructions

attribute.name: fatigue_contributing_factors
attribute.value: Accumulated Fatigue;Insufficient Rest Period;Late Departure;Long Duty Period;Tried Prior to Start of Duty Period

attribute.name: other_fatigue_contributing_factors
attribute.value: Combined FDP with Reserve availability period in exceedence of FAR117 limitations.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
27FEB12 and 28FEB12
On 26FEB12 at around 1515L (2015z) Miami Air Scheduling Dept. notified me that I would be placed on short-call reserve at 0300L (0800z) 27FEB12. Reserve availability period to end 1900L (2400z) 27FEB12 a total of 16+00 hrs.
On 26FEB12 at around 1850L (2350z) Miami Air Scheduling Dept. notified me that I had a trip assignment in addition to short-call reserve immediately following the reserve availability period.
Initial Scheduled on duty Report time was 1400L (1900z) 27FEB12. Miami Air Scheduling Dept. contacted me at 1130L (1630z) to adjust the Report time. {Update #1} New Scheduled on Duty Report time was now 1720L (2220z).
Initial Scheduled FDP Trip 27FEB12 MIA to DAB (BSK536) 2030z to 2140z DAB to JQF (BSK8663) 2240z to 0005z
Scheduled Off Duty Release time 0035z (28FEB12) / 1935L (27FEB12)
Total Scheduled FDP (Flight duty period) 5+05 Total Scheduled work hours on company time (On Duty to Scheduled Release) 5+35
{Update #1} New Scheduled FDP Trip 27FEB12 thru 28FEB12 MIA to DAB (BSK536) 2350z [27FEB12] to 0100z [28FEB12] DAB to JQF (BSK8663) 0230z [28FEB12] to 0355z [28FEB12]
Scheduled Off Duty Release time 0425z (28FEB12) / 2325L (27FEB12)
Total Scheduled FDP (Flight duty period) 5+35 Total Scheduled work hours on company time (On Duty to Scheduled Release) 6+05
{Update #2} New Scheduled FDP Trip 27FEB12 thru 28FEB12 with segment1 completed MIA to DAB (BSK536) 2344z [27FEB12] to 0054z [28FEB12] completed actual times DAB to CLT (BSK8663) 0800z [28FEB12] to 0925z [28FEB12]
Scheduled Off Duty Release time 0955z (28FEB12) / 0455L (28FEB12)
Total Scheduled FDP (Flight duty period) 11+05 Total Scheduled work hours on company time (On Duty to Scheduled Release) 11+35
Actual FDP Trip Block times 27FEB12 thru 28FEB12 Actual on duty Report time was 1720L (2220z) 27FEB12
MIA to DAB (BSK536) 2344z [27FEB12] to 0054z [28FEB12] DAB to JQF (BSK8663) 0820z [28FEB12] to 0940z [28FEB12]
Actual Off Duty Release time 1020z / 0520L (28FEB12) Actual Hotel Check-in time 1110z / 0610L (28FEB12)
Actual Total completed work hours (On Duty to Actual Release) 12+30 Actual Total completed work hours on company time (On Duty to Hotel check-in) 12+50
Actual FDP 12+00
During Flight Segment2 (DAB to CLT) I believe I may have become fatigued due to the long duty day and due to being scheduled by the company beyond limitations as established by FAR 117.
FAR 117 Limitations exceeded by the FDP on 27FEB12 and 28FEB12
FAR 117.21 Reserve status. Section (c) For short call reserve, (1) The reserve availability period may not exceed 14 hours.
[I completed a reserve availability period on short-call reserve for a total of 14+20 hours at update #1 report time of 1720L / 2220z (27FEB12) in violation of section (c) (1).]
(2) For a flight crew member who has completed a reserve availability period, no certificate holder may schedule and no flight crew member may accept an assignment of a reserve availability period unless the flight crew member receives the required rest in Â§ 117.25(e).
[Â§ 117.25(e) affords the flight crew member a rest period of at least 10 consecutive hours immediately before beginning the reserve or flight duty period. As such the company stood in violation of section (c) (2) at update #1 report time of 1720L / 2220z (27FEB12) for not providing a 10 hour consecutive rest period.]
(3) For an unaugmented operation, the total number of hours a flight crew member may spend in a flight duty period and a reserve availability period may not exceed the lesser of the maximum applicable flight duty period in Table B of this part plus 4 hours, or 16 hours, as measured from the beginning of the reserve availability period.
Table B {Update #1} New Scheduled Time of Start (1720L) Number of Flight Segments (2)
MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 12+00
[The total number of hours I spent in this flight duty period and in the reserve availability period totaled 25+40 hours. <End of FDP time 0450L / 0940z (28FEB12) minus start of reserve availability period 0300L / 0800z (27FEB12)> The company violated section (c) (3) limitation of 12 plus 4 = 16 hours maximum.]
FAR 117.25 Rest period. (e) No certificate holder may schedule and no flight crew member may accept an assignment for any reserve or flight duty period unless the flight crew member is given a rest period of at least 10 consecutive hours immediately before beginning the reserve or flight duty period measured from the time the flight crew member is released from duty. The 10 hour rest period must provide the flight crew member with a minimum of 8 uninterrupted hours of sleep opportunity.
Violation of 117.25 section (e) occurred at update #1 report time of 1720L / 2220z (27FEB12) for not providing a 10 hour consecutive rest period immediately before beginning the flight duty period.
Please Note As a reference towards the progress of Miami Air complying with FAR 117 I would like to include the following:
Beginning in January of 2012 under the new unenforceable regulation FAR 117, I have now completed 11 FDPâ€™s (Flighty Duty Periods) as a pilot in flight.
Of the 11 FDPâ€™s thus far 5 of them have exceeded limitations as established in FAR 117.
All cases as acclimated and unaugmented
(01JAN12) FDP Scheduled total 12+20, Report 0645L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 12+50 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 12+00
(03JAN12) FDP Scheduled total 13+45, Report 0130L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 14+05 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 9+00
(23JAN12) FDP Scheduled total 12+20, Report 1200L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 11+30 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 10+00
(23FEB12) FDP Scheduled total 13+35, Report 0400L, 4 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 12+27 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 10+00
(27 and 28FEB12) FDP Scheduled total 19+55, Report 1720L, 2 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 25+40 Reserve availability and FDP combined Violation of FAR117.21(c) (1), (2), (3) and FAR 117.25(e) TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 16+00

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: COMPLY WITH FAR 117 FOR SCHEDULED TRIPS, FLIGHT DUTY PERIODS, REQUIRED REST PERIODS, SHORT-CALL LIMITATIONS, RESERVE STATUS REQUIREMENTS AND LIMITATIONS AS SET FORTH UTILIZING TABLE B.

attribute.name: other
attribute.value: Walking to hangar from parking lot

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
A call through the safety hotline was received where an individual reported parking his/her car in the parking lot where the flight crews park their vehicles at 04:00 on the morning of 11/16 when the individual noticed that all the lights in the parking lot were off.
The individual had to walk alone in the dark from the car to the hangar. This is dangerous because cars might get broken into, or someone might get robbed.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: It is unknown why the lights were off.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: please make sure the lights are on in the parking lot when it is dark.

attribute.name: fatigue_contributing_factors
attribute.value: ;Early Departure;Long Duty Period;Rest Quality at Hotel;Tried Prior to Start of Duty Period

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: THIS FATIGUE ISSUE STARTED WITH A REPORT OF 01:45 LOCAL. UNABLE TO SLEEP MORE THAN 2 HOURS PRIOR TO REPORT. DUTY DAY 15:15. NEED I SAY MORE? AFTER A 13:55 LAYOVER THE NEXT DAY WE REPORTED AT 0555 LOCAL, FLEW TWO LEGS AND SAT IN A LIMO FOR 4 HOURS FROM MCO TO MIA. THIS DUTY DAY WAS 14:45.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: SCHEDULE A LONGER LAYOVER WHEN FLYING BACK SIDE OF THE CLOCK AND SCHEDULING DUTY DAYS OVER 14 OR 15 HOURS.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
After pushback from gate, the aircraft was holding short of the runway at midfield, Taxiway Bravo, due to inbound traffic. Cabin was ready for takeoff and appropriate checklists were accomplished.
The Purser notified me that there was a passenger walking around in the cabin, refusing instructions to be seated and to fasten his seat belt, telling the flight attendants to "shut up." In their opinion, he smelled of alcohol and his eyes were quite red.
We advised Ground Control and Operations that we needed to return to the stand, to advise security that we were removing a passenger from the aircraft. We made a turn on the ramp and parked the airplane. Secured the #1 engine to allow the door to open. Security removed the passenger and his belongings. We confirmed with the manifest that he had no checked baggage. The door was then closed, the #1 engine restarted, checklists completed again and the flight departed without further incident.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: I was the Captain of the honor flight originating from Baltimore Washington landing Ocala Florida on June 14 2011. It had been brought to my attention that the vets would appreciate it if, the capital flag could be hung out the window upon our return to Ocala. I thought it would be a nice gesture and discussed it with the crew, we came up with the plan to have the number one engine shut down after we passed under the fire hoses. And after it slowed below 20% N1 the mechanic would open the window and hold the flag out until we finished our parking check list, at the parking spot. I did not take into consideration we would be making a right turn. Turning into an operating engine, fortunately we had the momentum to use minimum thrust on the number 2 engine. If we had not it would have required us to use a large amount of thrust much to close to people and vehicles. It worked out this time, but after reviewing the unsuccessful second attempt and thinking about our number 2 engine thrust requirement. I will not do it again.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Crew displayed flag at customer request

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: captain counseled that action was inapprpriate

attribute.value: Accidentally Performing Wrong Task/Action;Difficulty Concentrating on Task/Action

attribute.name: fatigue_contributing_factors
attribute.value: ;Arrangement of Pairing Duty Periods;Late Departure;Long Block Time;Long Duty Period;Rest Quality at Hotel

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
This portion of the trip occurred on day 4 of a 5 day sequence. On the 28th zulu day, we also had a 24 hour break in PTK. Preceeding the show, I slept until 0800 L. I had every intention of sleeping later, but with all the noise in the hotel, it was not possible. I did, however stay lounging in bed until around 11:30. I know that even if I'm not sleeping, being sedentary actually helps me gain additional rest.
Due to the nature of the trip and the "high profile" of the client, the catering rep requested that the show time in PTK be increased to 3+0. I immediately saw the problem with this. The sequence was already built onto the backside of the clock and was scheduled at 9+45 hrs of flight with two pilots. I felt that there was no justifiable reason for the pilots to be there so early and could exacerbate the potential for fatigue. I alerted the Chief Pilot to this. He agreed and the show time for the pilots was returned to the original 1+30.
The first leg from PTK to LAX was uneventful, save for departing PTK almost 1 hour late for passenger convenience. The captain and I did, however, extensively brief the arrival and approach into LAX. The aircraft we were flying had a DMI for an inoperative fuel guage. This precluded us from using VNAV. The arrivals into LAX often include many step downs and crossing restrictions. Not having VNAV greatly increased our workload.
Due to the delay in the departure from PTK, the purser suggested that we could minimize the ground time in LAX by having the F/A's clean the aircraft. The company disagreed and a light cleaning was performed at the FBO. This added an additional 20 minutes to the ground time.
The departure from LAX was intially normal. During the climb out, though, we were issued a clearance to fly direct to a fix that was not in the FMC. I recalled that it was on the departure plate and the captain requested it. At first I didn't know where it was, but then realized that during rotation and climb out, the plates and weather package had all slid off the center console and now lay on the floor. The captain remarked that a sloppy cockpit was the first sign of fatigue. Turned out he was right. We proceeded as cleared. The second noticeable event occurred just prior to level off at our final altitude. As I slowed the rate of climb, I looked at the altimeter and realized that we had not set it to standard as we passed through FL 180. Fortunately, this was caught prior to an altitude deviation.
As we continued on our route of flight, the cockpit was really quiet. It's important because it was such a significant change from every leg prior on this rotation, including the inbound leg from PTK. Each leg, we'd chatted nearly incessantly, mostly about work, but just all sorts of things, too. I also noticed that I was starting to really feel tired. I began yawning a lot and the captain asked if I was okay. I replied that I was, but decided that I needed to do something to distract myself. I decided to tidy up the cockpit. I began by putting away the charts for LAX and ONT. I reorganized the trip envelopes, ensured all the receipts were properly entered, and then got to work on my flight bag. This is where things really went down hill. Every time I went to get something from the bag, my hands became entangled in the spiral cords for the hand held mic or the removable map light. It set me off in a way that hasn't happened in a long time. It surprised me because it's not a normal reaction for me. It reminded me of being a little kid and having things go wrong leading to nap time. I knew it was from fatigue. It was also during this time (about 0200 eastern) that I started really feeling wiped out, heavy eyelids, basically all the symptons of dozing off. I decided that it was time for some coffee. This helped some and coupled with a walk to the back of the aircraft, and constantly busying myself with any tasks that I could think of, slowly started to increase my level of alertness. I did notice, though, that the captain seemed to be experienceing similar symptons, noticeably head drooping and a little yawning. The big thing, though was the radios. While I don't think we missed a significantly increased number of calls, we surely missed more than a few. We never lost a frequency, but as it gets awfully quiet at that time of night, we often thought that we'd missed a hand-off and were now out of range. Thankfully that was never the case, but we were second guessing ourselves more than usual.
Fortunately, due to the lack of traffic at that time of night, we were able to skip the arrival and request dircet routing with our own descent/speed profile. Again due to a lack of the VNAV from the DMI, this was really important in reducing our workload. The arrival into PIT was an ILS in visual conditions with a quartering tailwind to 32. This was also uneventful, and we taxied to the ramp. We were both pretty happy to be done.
We went to the hotel and I was in bed just before 0500L. Unfortunately again due to hotel noise, I only got about 4 hours of sleep. I am very glad that my duty assignment today only has me as a passenger. I would not be safe to be part of a working crew tonight.
While I relaize that under the current FAR's that this sequence was legal, it was very challenging and definitely required the crew to be extra vigilant. We were both fine going into LAX, and that was a good thing, as the lack of VNAV and deteriorating weather conditions really increased our workload. We were lucky that the weather in PIT cooperated and gave us an easy approach. Had we had similar conditions as in LAX, it would have made a challenging night that much more difficult and unsafe.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: As a company, we really need to evaluate and minimize backside of the clock repositioning flight.. The Chief Pilot moving our show back to the standard 1+30 certainly helped, but in reality it didn't do a lot to help. Short of shutting the sequence down upon arrival at LAX, the safest course of action would have been to have an APC as part of the crew. Additionally, that APC could have been added in LAX. this would have made him/her as fresh as possible. The APC could have functioned as the flying pilot on the LAX-PIT leg, allowing the other tow crew members sufficient rest, significantly increasing the margin of safety and virtually eliminating the fatigue in this sequence.

attribute.name: fatigue_contributing_factors
attribute.value: ;Late Departure;Long Block Time;Long Duty Period;Rest Quality at Hotel;Tried Prior to Start of Duty Period

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Late departure from hotel. Midnight local showtime to fly all night. Only 2 pilots, even though requested APC. 4 legs. 9 hours 35 minutes block flight time on 15 hous 30 minute duty day. Only reason was able to fly last leg was because ferry flight, 1 hour 50 min. This trip was designed to the maximum limit. Times were not due to any kind of weather delays.
In addition to extreme duty and flight time during back side of clock flying, hotel location was across street from college football stadium during bowl game. Also US mens Rugby team at hotel which was booked full. Attempting Normal sleep during daytime hours in this type of situation is almost impossible.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
15APR12 Scheduled on duty Report time was 0545L (0945z) Augmented Flight Crew (3 Pilots) Scheduled 3 flight segments
Scheduled Trip 15APR12 BOS to PUJ (BSK720) 1115z to 1520z PUJ to NAS (BSK504) 1620z to 1830z NAS to JFK (BSK647) 2030z to 2325z
Scheduled Off Duty Release time 2355z (15APR12)
Total Scheduled FDP (Flight duty period) 13+40 Total Scheduled work hours on company time (On Duty to Scheduled Release) 14+10
Actual Trip Block times 15APR12 Actual on duty Report time was 0515L (0915z)
BOS to PUJ (BSK720) 1125z to 1520z PUJ to NAS (BSK504) 1645z to 1910z NAS to JFK (BSK647) 2030z to 2347z
Actual Off Duty Release time 0017z / 2017L (15APR12) Actual Hotel Check-in time 0115z / 2115L (15APR12)
Actual Total completed work hours (On Duty to Actual Release) 15+02 Actual Total completed work hours on company time (On Duty to Hotel check-in) 16+00
Actual FDP 14+32 (Ending at Aircraft Block-in Time)
During Flight Segment 3 (NAS to JFK) I believe I may have become fatigued due to the long duty day and due to being scheduled by the company beyond limitations as established by FAR 117.
Fatigue set in also in part due to the Miami Air APC delegated seats do not satisfy the requirements of a Class 3 rest facility and are less than adequate.
Furthermore I would like to report that on flight segment 1 there were 170 pax of which 4 of them sat in row 30 (the same row as the Normally delegated APC seat). There were multiple disturbances while attempting rest during this flight segment to include babiesâ€™ cries, loud talking passengers, loud talking FAâ€™s and kicks of the feet from the passenger immediate in front at seat 29A.
FAR 117 Limitations exceeded by the FDP on 15APR12.
FAR 117.17 Flight Duty Period: Augmented flight crew Table C Scheduled Time of Start (0515L) Number of Flight Segments (3) Number of Pilots (3) Less than Class Three Rest Facility
MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD (For Class Three Rest Facility) = 13+00 MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD Table B (due to Lack of Class Three Rest Facility) = 12+00 13+40 scheduled FDP exceeded this limitation; 14+32 Actual FDP exceeded this limitation
Miami Air B737â€™s pilots rest facility does not qualify as a Class Three Rest Facility
For Reference: Class 3 rest facility means a seat in an aircraft cabin or flight deck that reclines at least 40 degrees and provides leg and foot support.
Please Note As a reference towards the progress of Miami Air complying with FAR 117 I would like to include the following:
Beginning in January of 2012 under the new unenforceable regulation FAR 117, I have now completed 24 FDPâ€™s (Flighty Duty Periods) as a pilot in flight.
Of the 24 FDPâ€™s thus far 11 of them have exceeded limitations as established in FAR 117.
The following cases as acclimated and augmented:
(25 thru 26MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 13+20, Report 1200L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 13+50 Due to Lack of a Class 3 Rest Facility TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 13+00
(30MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 13+30, Report 0130L, 4 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 13+45 Due to Lack of a Class 3 Rest Facility TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 9+00 TABLE C MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 13+00
(15APR12) FDP Scheduled total 13+40, Report 0515L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total xx+xx Due to Lack of a Class 3 Rest Facility TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 12+00 TABLE C MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 13+00
The following cases as acclimated and unaugmented:
(01JAN12) FDP Scheduled total 12+20, Report 0645L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 12+50 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 12+00
(03JAN12) FDP Scheduled total 13+45, Report 0130L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 14+05 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 9+00
(23JAN12) FDP Scheduled total 12+20, Report 1200L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 11+30 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 10+00
(23FEB12) FDP Scheduled total 13+35, Report 0400L, 4 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 12+27 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 10+00
(27 and 28FEB12) FDP Scheduled total 19+55, Report 1720L, 2 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 25+40 Reserve availability and FDP combined Violation of FAR117.21(c) (1), (2), (3) and FAR 117.25(e) TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 16+00
(01MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 11+25, Report 0430L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 11+15 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 10+00 FLIGHT TIME Scheduled total 8+25, Actual FLIGHT TIME total 8+35 TABLE A MAX FLIGHT TIME 8+00
(18MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 21+30, Report 0730L, 2 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 22+00 Reserve availability and FDP combined Violation of FAR117.21(c) (2), (3) and FAR 117.25(e) TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 16+00
(21 thru 22MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 26+40, Report 1545L, 4 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 22+40 FDP 21/22MAR combined as Split Duty with FDP 22MAR12 combined Violation of FAR 117.15(d),(f), 117.21(d),(e), and FAR 117.25(e)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: I was called on reserve to report at 0415 L. The call was at 10 or so local. I was called again later in the day to advise that I was now an active crew member for all three legs instead of just the last. In the late afternoon, I was again called to Move the show to 0330. I was in bed at 2000L, but was unable to fall asleep due to not prepping the night before. I was very fatigued on the drive in. The first leg to ADW, I was an ineffectual crew member. The second leg, was not too bad, but still, I was not a great asset. I was the flying pilot on the third leg and my energy levels were okay, but by not having sufficient notification to prepare for a 0415L show, that became a 0400L show, and then a 0330L show, for a 15 hour duty day into an environment where English was not the primary language created a very challenging, difficult and unsafe environment. The worst part was being informed by the crew that this trip had been on their line for a significant time and was by no means a "pop up" trip. Additionally, I should note that it turns out that I'm not doing well physically. The captain was so concerned about my excessive coughing and hoarse voice on the last leg that he urged me to call in sick for my SBY duty the next day. I have done so. It is my second sick call in 4 years, and it is obvious to me that my condition was exacerbated by a lack of sufficient rest from a poorly constructed trip sequence/notification process.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: while unloading a company van, consisting of a pallet and two main aircraft wheels, i pulled it out using the forklift. As soon as the load cleared the van, the pallet tilted to the left and the two main wheels rolled against the company van that was parked in the parking lot in front of the hangar, causing some damage to the front fender of the van. I immediately called the maintenance supervisor (luigi) so that he come inspect the damage. After that, Douglas Koby and myself stood up the MWA. At that moment, I inspected the tires for damage from the repair station as usual. At that time, I strained the pinky finger on my right hand.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Trip began with a two leg commercial from Miami (MIA) to Knoxville (TYS). Was scheduled for an approximate 37 hour layover in Knoxville, TN (TYS). The company (Crew Scheduling) scheduled a 2:50 am Local report time after the layover to fly two live flights (TYS-CLE & CLE-EWR) with a scheduled 8:10 am Local block in time into Newark, NJ (EWR). The allowable FDP period was 9 hours.
Upon waking up the morning before the report time for the two live flights, crew scheduling had sent an updated schedule that included a commercial home after the two live flights. The total duty period would be 15:36. Our report time would start at 2:50 am Local and end at 6:26 pm Local. The new schedule had a commercial from Newark (EWR) to Detroit (DTW) followed by a commercial from Detroit (DTW) to Ft Lauderdale (FLL) followed by a LIMO to Miami (MIA).
Tue23Sep Local times LL674 TYS - CLE 0420 0545 LL674 CLE - EWR 0635 0810 DL3363 EWR - DTW 1100 1251 DL1704 DTW - FLL 1401 1656 LIMO674 FLL - MIA 1726 1826
The scheduled report time was 2:50 am Local at the aircraft. That resulted in a taxi departure time from the hotel lobby of 2:30 am Local. Which meant that I had a 1:30 am Local wake up time to get ready for the trip. I was only able to obtain about three (3) hours of sleep the night prior. I was unable to plan for additional sleep as our schedule showed a release in Newark (EWR) originally. Our updated schedule with the commercial home was not updated/received until the morning of our late night/early morning report time.
The company did not utilize any of the direct flights or "more direct" flights from EWR to FLL or MIA. Instead, it utilized the cheapest option without any regard to sleep patterns, fatigue etc of the crews. After the scheduled block into EWR, the company had scheduled a commercial home with three segments totaling over ten hours of travel time to get from EWR to MIA.
The FAA, through FAR 117, recognizes that in the event of our report time, a duty period (FDP) of 9 hours is the maximum permitted before crew members are unsafe to operate an aircraft. Miami Air has extended the duty period by almost seven (7) hours extra. This will obviously result in fatigued crews. Any person who observes the scheduled itinerary will know that this is a very fatiguing trip/day.
Route ID : TYS2/3

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value:
If the company provides last minute schedule changes, it is impossible for the crew member to plan sleep accordingly. I recommend that the company provide at least 48 hours notice to crew members so that the sleep period prior to the affected sleep period can be adjusted accordingly to minimize fatigue issues. Because travel is "busy", does not excuse or resolve the issue that crews will become fatigued without proper notice of normal sleep interruptions in advance. Without planning, sleep interruptions will result in fatigue.
Travel and Crew Scheduling should actually take into account the affects of schedules on fatigue. It appears that cost of commercials and legality are the only two variables that are considered. There is no consideration for crew schedules and fatigue effects.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Sick Pax on ground prior to block out.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value:
PAX said she took a sleeping pill and was afraid of flying.
Sun, 21 Aug 2011 20:23 Z Prior to closing the door in BJV, PAX Ellen Hazelaar, said she did not feel well, she said she took a sleeping pill and felt as if her hart was racing and felt nauseous. We had a nurse onboard, Elsvan Der Wesde. He checked her paulse and pressure and also had called for a medic come out and check her out. Ellen had said she was afraid of flying, the Nurse and medic felt she was just hyperventilating and had her breath into a bag. They both felt she was then OK to fly. We then departed for AMS and I was told by the purser she was OK and slept on the flight, we landed in AMS with no further incidents.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Jet fuel overflow during fueling operation at FLL:
While fueling 752MA prior to departure from FLL on 10/22/11, the Flight Mechanic on flight 393 inadvertantly pressed the fuel override switches on the fueling panel. Tanks had just "topped off" and truck was still connected, however Flt Mx believed there was an error quantity reading on the fuel gauges, thereby providing an opportunity to take more fuel.
Several gallons of fuel (approx 5-7) from each wing spilled on to ramp and were subsequently cleaned by Sheltair line service in a quick and uneventful fashion.

attribute.value: Captain reported windshear alert during takeoff roll. They aborted at 60-70 knots and were going to wait until the rain storm passed and then takeoff again. It was a ferry flight with no delay to the passenger operation. Flight took off with no further complications.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Notam showing long runway 06/24 at Shannon closed between 2230Z-0530Z; flight scheduled departure time of 2355Z. Dispatch reviewed the airport diagram and considered use of short runway 13/31. Opt data was run and accepted for estimated take off weight; decision made to use runway 13/31 based on OPT data. At approximately 2050Z Dispatch Manager sent an e-mail to ground handler to re-confirm that runway 06/24 would indeed be closed for departure of flight. Response was :yes, runway will be closed and flight will not be able to take off. E-mail sent to ground handler to advise the intent to use runway 13/31; response :no runway will be open until 0600Z. Ground handler offered phone number for Airport Authority; phone call made to Airport Authority who confirmed runway 06/24 would be closed at 2200Z-0530Z and advised runway 13/31 was not avaiable, has been closed for several years. Decision made to operate at 0600Z. Captain was also in communication with the ground handler and receiving the same information as Dispatch.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: During taxi out, tower notified us are ground handing agent had called them requesting we return to the gate. Tower told us the gate agent had found fluid on the ramp and suspected it was are aircraft. We taxied back to the gate and shut down the engines. I left the cockpit to talk the agent and discus the problem, he showed me a spot on the ramp that he suspected to be fluid from are aircraft. I preformed a visual inspection of are aircraft and found no leeks. I asked the first officer to take a look and see if I missed something, he found no leeks as well. After reviewing are fluid levels and the results of my and the first officers visual inspection. I determined are aircraft was not loosing any fluid and continued the flight. After 2:45hrs of flight time we arrived at are destination and the fluid levels remained the same.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: non-compliance_with_cfrs,_policies/procedures
attribute.value: Company Policy SOP Non-Compliance;Reduced Safety Standards

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
March 7, 2012 RE: Incident on Sheltair ramp in FLL
While on the ramp in FLL, a non-qualified employee of Miami Air, Luigi Imbrieco operated the environmental system in the aircraft without permission. A ground air condition cart was hooked up to N753MA. I had configured the system controls by following the Boeing and the Company FAA approved procedures in accordance with my training (Supplementary Procedure section of the AOM (SP 2.1)). After completing this procedure, I noticed a person suddenly reaching into the flight deck and hastily flipping switches. I jumped up to discover Mr. Imbrieco had turned off the recirculation fans on the overhead panel. Mr. Imbrieco then told me that I am â€œnot doing it correctlyâ€. I then emphatically informed Mr. Imbrieco never touch anything in the cockpit again. I added that I had followed the Company procedure correctly.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: A short while after this event, I approached Mr. Imbrieco to ask him if he was a mechanic or if he had gotten permission from our mechanic to operate the system controls. His response was to repeatedly tell me that I do not understand the system. This event is of concern because Mr. Imbrieco is not a pilot, mechanic nor has he been trained to operate controls on a B737. A non-qualified person operating aircraft systems without proper training poses a safety risk. In his haste, he could have operated the wrong system, such as the hydraulic system with the tow bar connected. If the bypass pin was not in, this could have been disastrous. By the tone of our follow up conversation and Mr. Imbriecoâ€™s lack of cooperation, it is my belief that he has done this before. Further, I presume he would not have told the crew that he had altered the systems configuration. He was not receptive to my handling of the situation and so I believe he will continue to function in this unsafe manner in the future.
