He was not receptive to my handling of the situation and so I believe he will continue to function in this unsafe manner in the future.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Have the following people meet, Manager of Flight Safety, Professional Standards Chair, Director of Safety, and Director of Standards to decide how to best proceed.

category.name: Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: At approximately 13:45 EDT, the safety department received a call through the safety hotline informing us that there was personnel servicing the cabin on Aircraft N732MA (parked at the hangar), that the R2 service door was open and the safety restraining strap was not deployed.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: This probably happened due to complacency.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: The reporter appears to have seen the door without the strap. The Director of Safety (Armando Martinez) and I physically went to see the airplane and confirmed the hotline report. We also took pictures (see attachments)

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: The Director of Safety and I physically went to investigate the hotline report. We took pictures. Also, the Director of Safety addressed the cleaning staff, explaining to them the importance of deploying the safety strap across the door. The Director of Safety also discussed the event with the Manager of Facilities, Mr. Luigi Imbrieco.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Flight LL 548, KLEX to KMSY. During post flight inspection at parking gate in KMSY, found evidence of bird strike on the left hand wing, at the number 1 Leading edge slat. Approximately 1 foot in from the inboard edge. No damage to the aircraft was noted.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: A bird was struck during descent or approach into KMSY

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: While checking the weather for the next flight, discovered wx deteriorating rapidly at destination. Informed crew, called alternate, spoke to crew about other possible alternates. Decision made to go to filed alternate.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
ACFT ENROUTE TO FRG, CALLED ACFT OVER SFO RADIO TO NOTIFY CAPT. ABOUT WEATHER GOING UP AND DOWN. THAT THE WEATHER MIGHT BE BELOW LANDING MIN AT FRG.
CALLED SALES ON PHONE TO SEE WHERE THEY WANT US TO GO IF WE CAN'T GET INTO FRG. FIRST IT WAS JFK,BUT JFK COULD NOT HANDLE US, DUE TO LACK OF STAFF. EWR WAS OUR ONLY ALTERNATIVE TO GO THAT REPORTED 5SM ON THE METAR.
WAS CALLING FRG ASOS TO BE UPDATED ON WX IN FRG, BUT WX WAS DROPPING BELOW LANDING MIN. WAS IN GENERAL BETWEEN 1/2SM AND 1/4SM FROM 0345Z TO 0428Z.
ASOS AT 0428Z ASOS REPORTED CALM WIND 1/4SM VV002, AT 0429Z CALLED ACFT THROUGH SFO RADIO ON TOLD THE UPDATED WX AT FRG. CAPT TOLD ME THAT ZNY CENTER ALSO TOLD HIM THAT FRG WAS BELOW LND MIN. CAPT AND ME DECIDED TO GO TO EWR.

attribute.name: other_leadership/supervision_factors
attribute.value: N/A, BECAUSE THE INCIDENT NO HAPPENED HERE

attribute.name: other
attribute.value: WHEN WE REMOVED THE SHIPPING COVER OF THE ENGINE.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: During my day shift on Jun 26,2013 around 0800am local time in my place of work Miami Air - hangar/Line. The inspector Miller requested to move the engine from the ramp to inside the hangar for to do receiving inspection of the engine and we proceeded to move the engine inside the hangar, use safety procedures, after placed/secure/parked the engine in the hangar then went to my office 10 min later K. Westerman (mechanic) and R. Miller (inspector) notified to me that during removed the shipping cover off, they found damaged on the tail cone of the engine. I reported the damaged of the engine to Maintenance Control/ DOM W. Iwanenco by email and attached the picture at 0816 local time.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: The information that was relayed to Maintenance Control is that the R2 door was not closed properly.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)
Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: A/C departed early for RMS. When TACC called for the times, they advised that RMS had a RAMP freeze and we may not be able to land. After looking at the fuel on the flt plan, I advised them we did not have much hold fuel. They told me to look at possible diversions. Contacted LEJ and they advised they could handle us. Spoke to TACC and RMS ops and found out the entire airport closed until 0900Z. We were not adivsed of the closure until after we had departed. Even if we had followed the schedule, we did not have the fuel to hold the extra time. A/C landed without incident in LEJ and was scheduled to continue to RMS with a 0900Z ETA

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)
Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On June 28th , 2012 at 11:03 a.m. local, Capt. John Valentine reported that the ground handler at CVG provided airstairs that were missing a railing. Capt. Valentine spoke with ground handler and they used a stair with a railing. Ground Handler - Delta Private Jet FBO.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Ground Handler failed to maintain his equipment in good working order.

Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: At 2025Z we began to pushback from A2 to taxiway A. Tail to the south with the intention of using runway 20. When asked by ATC whether we could except runway 2, We checked the performance numbers and agreed that we could. We were given a clearance to take-off on runway 2 from intersection Bravo. So as to use as much runway as possible, I taxied slightly right, to turn left to line up when the right main gear went into the grass.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: I taxied too far to the right as I was preparing to turn to the left to line up.

attribute.name: how_was_the_event_detected?
attribute.value: ATC;Flight Crew;Operations Center/Maintenance Operations Center;Self Awareness/Scan

attribute.name: flight_crew
attribute.value: ;Contacted ATC;Contacted Company;Contacted Mainenance;Declared Emergency with ATC

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
While retracting the gear on Runway 35L in MCO I noticed what looked to me as large black chunks of rubber being projected from the aircraft.
I notified ATC and told them we may have had a possible nose gear tire blowout on take-off. They later confirmed that there was rubber on the runway. Declared an emergency and contacted the company. A joint decision was made to divert to MIA.
While on approach into MIA, hydraulic pump ENG 1 LOW PRESSURE light illuminated and we verified hydraulic quantity was decreasing on the lower DU. Followed QRH procedures and landed safely.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Nose-gear tire delaminated on take-off. Debris from the tire damaged the nose-gear bypass valve causing an hydraulic leak.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: Large pieces of rubber came into sight in-front of the aircraft when we retracted the gear.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: Notified ATC and told them we may have had a possible nose gear tire blow out on take-off. They later confirmed that there was rubber on the runway. Declared an emergency and contacted the company. A joint decision was made to divert to MIA.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Gear handle would not move from OFF to DOWN position. QRH 14.22 procedures completed with normal landing. Exited runway and parked on ramp using rudder steer and differential braking.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Failure of gear handle to move from OFF to DOWN.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: Gear handle would not move from OFF to DOWN.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: QRH 14.22 procedures completed with normal landing. Exited runway and parked on ramp using rudder steer and differential braking.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Determine what is causing gear handle to lock in OFF position.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Ground stop was issued to DTW due to weather. ground stop was supposed to end at 22z with 60% probability for extension. bsk534 was had an eta of around 2330z which is about 1.5 hours after the original end of groundstop not accounting for extension. Captain Miguel Martin was given warning of ground delay in writing along with a copy of the ground delay printout with the weather and notams update package. Dispatch was flight following with no signs that they might divert. During 5 mile final, a focused and hurried Captain Martin called in that he wil divert to CLE due to 1 issue. A high windshear advisory that was given to him by the control tower. It was later found out he had min fuel and could not hold. I believe he landed in CLE with 1.9. Catalina Diaz was the senior dipatcher.

attribute.name: fatigue_contributing_factors
attribute.value: ;Arrangement of Pairing Duty Periods;Late Departure;Long Block Time;Long Duty Period;Rest Quality at Hotel

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: noisy in hotel during rest period - due to NCAA unplanned 1:35 block flight due to return to CLT on flight 660 planned block on paper was 8:20, no APC...turned out to be 10:47 unrealistic planned block time CLT TO BGI. was 4:50. not 4:05 had to show 30 minutes before show time on paper due to a/c repo to gate...duty day would have been over 16 hrs if properly recorded. 2 hr. delay for mx due to return to CLT. flt. 660. the fatigue event was over a range of time from 0130 to 0600. in flight and on way home. the local time of event covered times 1700 to 0200.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value:
the fatigue program, one of the so called 'cornerstones' of our company, needs to be followed! when we try to help out the company, we should also be helped...and thanked
unrelated issue occurring frequently: less than 8 hrs behind door on a min. rest period. crew treated like it is our fault that we need min. rest. 'numbers' on itin. 'worked' to make next day go as scheduled.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: North State Aviation shipped a fire extinguisher to the Miami Air Stockroom without the proper haz-mat shipping documents.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: fatigue_contributing_factors
attribute.value: Accumulated Fatigue;Late Departure;Long Block Time;Long Duty Period

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
30APR12 thru 01MAY12 Scheduled on duty Report time was 1600L / (2300z) 30APR12 Augmented Flight Crew (3 Pilots) Scheduled 2 flight segments
Scheduled Trip 01MAY12 SEA to OGG (BSK626) 0100z to 0710z OGG to RIV (BSK134) 0855z to 1400z Limo Crew RIV to ONT (2 vans) 1430z to 1530z
Scheduled Off Duty Release time 1530z (01MAY12)
Total Scheduled FDP (Flight duty period) 15+00 Total Scheduled work hours on company time (On Duty to Scheduled Release) 16+30
Actual Trip Block times 30APR12 thru 01MAY12 Actual on duty Report time was 1530L (2230z)
SEA to OGG (BSK626) 0118z to 0728z OGG to RIV (BSK134) 0840z to 1430z Limo Crew RIV to ONT (2 vans) 1508z to 1550z
Actual Off Duty Release time 1550z / 0850L (01MAY12) Actual Hotel Check-in time 1555z / 0855L (01MAYR12)
Actual Total completed work hours (On Duty to Actual Release) 17+20 Actual Total completed work hours on company time (On Duty to Hotel check-in) 17+25
Actual FDP 16+00 (Ending at Aircraft Block-in Time)
During Flight Segment 2 (OGG to RIV) I believe I may have become fatigued due to the long duty day and due to being scheduled by the company beyond limitations as established by FAR 117.
Fatigue set in also in part due to the Miami Air APC delegated seats do not satisfy the requirements of a Class 3 rest facility and are less than adequate.
FAR 117 Limitations exceeded by the FDP on 30APR12 thru 01MAY12.
FAR 117.17 Flight Duty Period: Augmented flight crew Table C Scheduled Time of Start (1530L) Number of Flight Segments (2) Number of Pilots (3) Less than Class Three Rest Facility
MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD (For Class Three Rest Facility) = 14+00 MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD Table B (due to Lack of Class Three Rest Facility) = 12+00 15+00 scheduled FDP exceeded this limitation; 16+00 Actual FDP exceeded this limitation
Miami Air B737â€™s pilots rest facility does not qualify as a Class Three Rest Facility
For Reference: Class 3 rest facility means a seat in an aircraft cabin or flight deck that reclines at least 40 degrees and provides leg and foot support.
Please Note As a reference towards the progress of Miami Air complying with FAR 117 I would like to include the following:
Beginning in January of 2012 under the new unenforceable regulation FAR 117, I have now completed 26 FDPâ€™s (Flighty Duty Periods) as a pilot in flight.
Of the 26 FDPâ€™s thus far 12 of them have exceeded limitations as established in FAR 117.
The following cases as acclimated and augmented:
(30APR12 thru 01MAY12) FDP Scheduled total 15+00, Report 1530L, 2 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 16+00 Due to Lack of a Class 3 Rest Facility TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 12+00 TABLE C MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 14+00
(25 thru 26MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 13+20, Report 1200L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 13+50 Due to Lack of a Class 3 Rest Facility TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 13+00
(30MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 13+30, Report 0130L, 4 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 13+45 Due to Lack of a Class 3 Rest Facility TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 9+00 TABLE C MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 13+00
(15APR12) FDP Scheduled total 13+40, Report 0515L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total xx+xx Due to Lack of a Class 3 Rest Facility TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 12+00 TABLE C MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 13+00
The following cases as acclimated and unaugmented:
(01JAN12) FDP Scheduled total 12+20, Report 0645L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 12+50 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 12+00
(03JAN12) FDP Scheduled total 13+45, Report 0130L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 14+05 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 9+00
(23JAN12) FDP Scheduled total 12+20, Report 1200L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 11+30 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 10+00
(23FEB12) FDP Scheduled total 13+35, Report 0400L, 4 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 12+27 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 10+00
(27 and 28FEB12) FDP Scheduled total 19+55, Report 1720L, 2 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 25+40 Reserve availability and FDP combined Violation of FAR117.21(c) (1), (2), (3) and FAR 117.25(e) TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 16+00
(01MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 11+25, Report 0430L, 3 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 11+15 TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 10+00 FLIGHT TIME Scheduled total 8+25, Actual FLIGHT TIME total 8+35 TABLE A MAX FLIGHT TIME 8+00
(18MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 21+30, Report 0730L, 2 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 22+00 Reserve availability and FDP combined Violation of FAR117.21(c) (2), (3) and FAR 117.25(e) TABLE B MAX FLIGHT DUTY PERIOD = 16+00
(21 thru 22MAR12) FDP Scheduled total 26+40, Report 1545L, 4 Flight segments, Actual FDP total 22+40 FDP 21/22MAR combined as Split Duty with FDP 22MAR12 combined Violation of FAR 117.15(d),(f), 117.21(d),(e), and FAR 117.25(e)

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: COMPLY WITH FAR 117 FOR SCHEDULED TRIPS, FLIGHT DUTY PERIODS, REQUIRED REST PERIODS, SHORT-CALL LIMITATIONS, FLIGHT TIME LIMITATIONS, AND RESERVE STATUS REQUIREMENTS AND LIMITATIONS AS SET FORTH UTILIZING TABLES A, B, AND C.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: ESTABLISH A CLASS 3 REST FACILITY OR GREATER FOR PILOTS IN THE CONDUCT OF AUGMENTED FLIGHT CREW OPERATIONS. ALSO COMPLY WITH FAR 117 FOR SCHEDULED TRIPS AND FLIGHT DUTY PERIODS AND LIMITATIONS AS SET FORTH UTILIZING TABLES A, B, AND C.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: aircraft at the hangar with external power and tow bar connected. Got into cockpit and both center tanks were on, crossfeed open, and A mechanical hydraulic pump off. It came in with 3.5 kgs of fuel and was fueled to 14 kgs. An unattended aircraft with or with out fuel? Does the warning in volume one only apply to flight crews??

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Performing Aircraft Pre Departure Security Check (OPS 500), the TSA was observing. The Purser, (Churchill) found a 3" pocket knife under the seat cushion at seat 1A. The prior revenue trip had been a military flight from IND-RIV on 5/13/12.
The knife was turned over to the TSA inspectors onboard the aircraft and they issued a "yellow alert". I explained that we had previously performed a military flight and they seemed extremely satisfied with our finding it and our response to the security threat.
Joe Obermeier was immediately contacted as well.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
BSK639 NAS-BOS AT 2325Z/17 RECEIVED CALL FROM A/C PAX HAD RAPID HEART BEAT-NOT FEELING EXTREMETIES-PAX SHAWN MCCORMICK-22 MALE -A/C DIVERTED TO KMCO 2329Z- WX READ.
SERVISAIR MET A/C AT GATE A20 CUSTOMS ADVISED. 3 PAX GOT OFF- SICK PERSON AND 2 FRIENDS. MX CALLED A MX PERSON IN KMCO TO DO OVER WEIGHT INSPECTION. NO MX-O/B 2325Z-RECEIVED CALL 2334Z- CUSTOMS OFFICER CALLED (CRUZ) 2329Z-DIVERTED ALERT 2334Z MX-CONTROL ADVISED 2330Z-CAROL MCO REP CALLED 2335Z-D/O CALLED STEVE ANDRIOCCI 2337Z-KAMRADCALLED 0010Z-FUELING REQUESTED 2340Z-PROIA CALLED-LEFT MSG 2332Z-CREW SCH ADVISED 2353Z-PASSWATER CALLED

Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: A/C N733MA ferried into EWR from PHL. There was no flight mechanic or flight attendants on board the ferry. Allied Aviation was fueling our aircraft when the flight mechanic came to the aircraft in EWR. The flight mechanic questioned why they were fueling our aircraft with no Miami Air supervision. The fueling was almost complete when the tech rep arrived to the aircraft.

category.name: Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
There are a few areas in the crew scheduling department where wires extend from desks across walkways to the wall or computer. I almost tripped over one and someone may get hurt if these wires are not covered.
Also, there is an area where the rug is cut and bend up, also creating a trip hazard.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Should probably re-route the wires or cover them with something so that they aren't exposed.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Contractor observed working on MAI aircraft wing at hangar without fall protection in front of MAI employee (Foreman)

category.name: Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Our driver was from M.G. As soon as he pulled off he was about to miss the first stop sign because he was driving very fast out of the parking lot. He slammed on his brakes whereas, the van slide a little. He proceeded to speed as we were heading towards the highway. On the highway he was speeding excessivly and he was losing control of the van on numerous ocassions because the van continue to leave its lane. At one point when he was entering the HOV express lane, he went past the lane and almost hit the cones while entering the HOV lane. At that point I told him and i quote "Honey, you need to control your driving, I need to get home to my family safe and all in one piece". He mumble something under his breath and continue to speed but did not lost control. This is my second time driving with this driver. The first time he picked me up from FLL airport and was exactly the same thing with the exception that he was driving extremely slow to the point that drivers were honking at him and giving him the finger because He was driving at that speed in the HOV express lane and never went over 45 mph. With that said, he was still losing control of the van and going over to the other lane.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: I don't know why the event occurred. .

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: I don't think the driver of this van should have a license to drive. Martha needs to test her employees driving skills prior to allowing them board Pax on their vans. Our lives are left on their hands and we have no control unless, we make them stop the carand we exit van in the middle of the highway.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: AT 0225Z 21MAY-2012 RECEIVED CALL FROM A/C N732MA NEEDED TO SPEAK TO MTC CONTROL-AS LANDING GEAR WAS GOING UP HEARD A LOAD THUMP VIBRATION NOISE LOUDER THAN NORMAL.CAPTAIN SPOKE TO MTC CONTROL AGAIN AT 0235Z HE WOULD ADVISE AIRPORT. CAPTAIN DECLARED EMERGENCY ATC SUGGESTED A FLY BY- THEY DID -TOWER DID NOT DETECT ANYTHING A/C LANDED AS THEY TAXIED 1 BLOWN NOSE TIRE

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: A/C departed early because the passengers had arrived early. I had three flights preparing to depart, although two were delayed due to late arriving pax. We contacted the ground handler after the a/c was enroute to advise they were early and were advised no problem. The ground handler called back at approximately 0210 local and advised the airport authority told him both runways were closed for taxiway repaving and would not be opened for our arrival. I contacted Sheltair in FLL and asked if they could handle the a/c. I also contacted the duty officer to advise of the situation. I spoke to the lead ground handler from Galaxy in PBI and he told me the crew and the buses were coming down to assist in pax transport to PBI. Sheltair was short on staffing and they would assist with offloading the pax bags with Sheltair's approval.

category.name: Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Lights in Parking lot and on Pan Am building are not turned on when I arrive to work (still dark at 0545). the parking lights to the east of the building are also not illuminated.

category.name: Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: other
attribute.value: Arrival at office parking lot - east of office building, north of runway, west of Commodor Hangar

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Upon arrival at the office, I noted that a large section of fence had been removed at the south end of the parking lot. See Photo No 1. The contractor had removed some of the poles, which had not been cut to be flush with the parking lot. See Photo No. 2. There was also a great deal of debris and it was windy. The wind was blowing pieces of debris onto the north runway. See Photo No. 3. Some of the pieces of debris while light in weight were large enough to cause damage to persons or property when blown about by the wind. The debris could also be blown onto the runway and get sucked up into an engine. See Photo No 4. In the last photo you can see that the wind was often blowing so hard that it forced a large plastic cone under the fence. All of the issues present a danger to air traffic, pedestrians, and vehicles. I immediately brought this to the attention of our Director of Safety, who personally went down and cleaned up a great deal of the debris. We also notified our POI Stanley Crum about this issue. The Miami Dade Aviation Department was called. They said the Commodor facility had contractors removing the fence. Mr. Martinez insisted upon a work order being placed to get the debris properly clean up and the poles cut flush with the ground. Work Order #215259.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: The contractor was lax about cleaning up the demolition and properly cutting the poles down.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: At 2025 z we started our push back towards taxiway A tail south. The tower asked if we could depart runway 02 from bravo, we told him to standby and ran the performance for departure. After checking the numbers were good we told him we could accept it. The tower cleared us for takeoff. As we taxied for takeoff the captain taxi straight towards the runway and made a slight turn to the right to follow by his left turn to align the aircraft with the center line,in the process the right main tire went into the grass where we came to a stop and shut the engines down. The aircraft remained there until they pulled us out.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: At approximately 2105Z Dispatch received a phone patch from A/C 733, Flight 351, Capt. Nilsson advised flight had encountered CAT (Clear Air Turbulence) and there were apparent injuries to some members of the flight crew.Capt, requested an ambulance meet the flight on arrival. Team Dr. on board was assisting and evaluating injuries; suspected one Flight Attendant may have possible broken or factured leg, Flight mechanic leg injury and possibly inury to Flight Attendant Mahon. No reported injuries to passengers. Capt. account on arrival KORF: about 10 minutes prior to TOD (top of descent) aircraft encountered CAT (not severe). Flight was over cloud layer, no significant updraft. Flight attendant Rogers transported to Sentara Leigh Hospital in Norfolk. Flight mechanic and Flight Attendant Mahon refused to go to hospital. Flight continued on to final destination KUNV. Capt. Nilsson to submit irregularity report.

attribute.name: other_sleep/rest_information
attribute.value: Quality sleep was not possible as I was placed on short call standby expected to report for duty within 1hr 30mins for the 11hrs and 30mins prior to my report time.

attribute.name: fatigue_contributing_factors
attribute.value: ;Arrangement of Pairing Duty Periods;Long Duty Period;Rest Quality at Hotel

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: At approximately 1500z on Aug 4th I was notified that I would be on short call standby from 0001z on the 5th of Aug to my flight duty report time at 1130z Aug 5th During the FRMP training, one of the suggestions for quality sleep prior to reporting for a duty assignment was to turn off devices that may cause interruptions, this is not possible while on short call standby nor is achieving quality sleep with the threat of the phone ringing at any time with a new report within 1hr 30 mins. In my case the short call standby and subsequent flight duty day combined came to 24 hrs and 25 mins.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: It is difficult to believe that the FAA and/or local JAA for Arkefly support this type of rest abuse in the 12 hrs prior to a report time. No Flight Crew Member should be assigned to short call standby during the 12 hrs prior to report.

category.name: Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: I light post in MAI's parking lot has been knocked partially over. Glass and debris around parking lot and pole is leaning over - could completely fall. No cones or tape to block off area.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: completed WBAT and notified Safety Department (safety department stated they were aware of problem.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Enroute cruise that started at FL 370. ATC was step descending the flight in 2,000 foot increments. Aircraft was level at FL 330. First Officer Kuyper was inclined to use the lavatory. Time frame was approximately 20 minutes prior to a normal time for Top of Decent. Auto pilot was engaged. First Officer Kuyper returned from lavatory. Captain Nilsson and Flight Mechanic Ferrer were in cockpit. First Officer Kuyper had sat down, prepared himself to accept control of the aircraft, accepted control of the aircraft, and resumed his duties as Pilot Flying. Flight Mechanic Ferrer was in the process of extending the stowed jump seat. There was no Air Traffic Control or other aircraft reports of turbulence in our vicinity. The meteorological conditions did not indicate a possibility of turbulence. Aircraft encountered Clear Air Turbulence. Almost instantaneously, the aircraft deviated approximately 100 feet low from assigned altitude. First Officer Kuyper maintained control of the aircraft and noted that the aircraft was returning to assigned altitude. Flight Mechanic Ferrer was injured during this event. The Seat Belt sign was not illuminated at the time of the event. Captain Nilsson illuminated the Seat Belt sign as soon as the event was recognized. The entire Clear Air Turbulence event lasted approximately 2 seconds. Captain Nilsson called Purser Kerr after the event occurred to receive a cabin report. Captain Nilsson was called back and advised off injuries. No passengers were injured. All passengers were seated with seat belts fastened. Flight Attendants Rogers and Mahon were injured. Purser Kerr called Captain Nilsson stating that Flight Attendant Rogers had injured her leg and that there was a team doctor onboard. The doctor advised Purser Kerr that Flight Attendant Rogers will need a wheel chair and to have medical attention. Doctor informed Purser Kerr that Flight Attendant Rogers may have fractured or broken her ankle/foot. Captain Nilsson called flight operations on the SAT phone and advised operations of the event. Captain Nilsson requested that Flight Operations call the Fixed Base Operator in Norfolk (KORF) and have paramedics meet the aircraft at the ramp/parking area. Captain Nilsson discussed the injuries with Flight Mechanic Ferrer and advised to have the paramedics attend him on the ground. Captain Nilsson monitored the status of the Flight Attendant's injuries with Purser Kerr until just prior to sterile cockpit procedures took effect. Paramedics met the aircraft at the FBO ramp. The paramedics boarded, assessed Flight Attendant Rogers, and informed Captain Nilsson that she is stable. Captain Nilsson allowed the passengers to deplane. After the passengers were deplaned, the paramedics attended Flight Attendant Rogers, Flight attendant Mahon, and Flight Mechanic Ferrer. Flight Attendant Mahon and Flight Mechanic Ferrer both refused to go to the hospital. Paramedics removed Flight Attendant Rogers from the aircraft and took her to the hospital.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: There were no indications of turbulance in the aircraft vacinity. The meterological conditions did not indicate a possible turbulance area. Clear Air Turbulance was brief and unexpected.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Outside of IT dept these is a puddle in hallway from leaky A/C unit. I was the only person involved.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: water mopped up and yellow sign put on floor

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: 1) Fix problem for good 2) Instead of a grey chair on wheels as a warning, they should have put put bright cones with tape surrounding area.

category.name: Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: water on floor infront of my office,

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: placed a chair with sign to alert other employees.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: I was notified by Jim Proia that there was a breach of airport security at OKC. I proceded to OKC airport and met with agents of the FBI (Brian Martin), TSA, NBA Security and local airport security officials. They conducted a thorough search of aircraft 753MA that was scheduled to fly the Miami Heat basketball team to Miami that night. Nothing out of the ordinary was found during the inspection of the aircraft.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: While on layover at TOL, I went for a long walk to go see a movie. The walk to the theater was uneventful. After the movie I began to walk back to the Hotel, the temperature had risen quite a bit and the heat index was over 100 degrees. I stopped for water and ate a banana. As I continued to walk, I finished my water and stopped at a service station for more. The difference between the extremely hot air outside and the cool air inside gave me a "head rush" and I felt a little dizzy. I was sweating profusely and when I reached for a counter to steady myself, my hand slipped and I fell to the floor hitting my head on the edge of the counter resulting in a cut over my left eye.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: The attendant provided me some napkins to control the bleeding and called the Paramedics. I did not want to go to the Hospital but the wound was deep enough to require sutures.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Drink more water, don't stay outside for extended periods in extreme heat and humidity.

Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Filled out a WBAT report yesterday regarding a light post in the parking lot which was knocked over. I received an email that the county was notified and sent a crew out to remove the knocked over light post and haul it away and the report was closed. However there is still a large amount of broken glass in the parking lot.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: The glass is a result of an incomplete cleanup by the crew who removed the light post.

attribute.name: fatigue_contributing_factors
attribute.value: ;Dead Head;Early Departure;Rest Quality at Hotel;Tried Prior to Start of Duty Period

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Fatigued during last hour and a half prior to landing in AMS on flight 3794. Did first AMS flight after 13:55 DH flight. Took over 2 hours from block in to get to hotel. Got 2 hours of sleep on DH flight and 5-6 hours of sleep prior to duty report for flying. Body clock was off due to time zone change and long previous day of DH. Hotel lacked temperature controls in room. Room was very hot during rest which woke me up multiple times.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Send first departure crews over 1 day earlier to acclimate to time zone and recover from long duty day that is required to get into position. Put crews in hotel with climate controls so that the room temperature can be controlled.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On Oct 18th, prior to descend into ORF (LL351) area, AC 733 at FL 330 experienced clear air turbulence. The first officer came from the fwd lavatory and the time he sat down and secure his seat belts, we all notice in the cockpit that the AC started to oscillate up and down. Quickly, the rough area and turbulence started. It was very quick. I did not have time to seat down due to the previous transit from FO to occupy his seat, and I could not unfold the OBS seat to seat myself. As a result of it, I started to bounce up and down inside the cockpit to the point that my RH knee hit the RH book self corner underneath the OBS seat. The turbulence ended and I was on the cockpit floor. The pain was intense for about the entire descend until landing. The front end crew was OK, they were secured with belts on. The back end crew was hurt, names of Mary R., H. Ferrell, and Claudia M. were few of them. Purser gave me ice before landing. The ORF paramedics showed. After taking care of the hurt FA, one of them came to me and asked me few questions related to the incident. I received a band aid. I put a lot of ice due to pain. Also I took 2 advils for pain. I noticed that during next flight ORF-UNV (LL 511) I was on pain still.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: FEEL DIFF Press light came on while at cruise (FL 370). Ran ORH procedure. Notified the onboard mechanics and maintenance control. Dispatch informed us to divert to BOS. While on approach, the landing ger lever would not move to the DN position. Aborted the approach, followed the QRH procedure. Declared an emergency and landed without incident.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Trip started on the 27th with a line check. Had mechanical problem that led to diverting to BOS. While on approach, landing gear would not come down and declared a emergency. Did not get into my hotel room until 2:00 am local time. Woke up 5 later and started coordinating crew and passenger to get to aircraft for 11:00 am show.
Dead headed to AMS. Luggage was lost in AMS. Got to hotel at 6:00 am. Lugged luggage up 3 flights of stairs. No air conditioning in room could not take a nap. Transfer to new hotel at 12:00 pm. Got to hotel 2:00 pm ish. Rooms where not ready. Unpack, and settle in and ate a early dinner.
Try to go to bed around 8:00 PM, had a hard time getting to sleep. Woke the next day at 1:30 AM for at 3:15 AM show.
First leg was I was just tired by the end of the return leg I was exhausted.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Should have been removed from trip and given more time to receive proper rest.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Very tired upon arrival in AMS on last live leg of flight. Has 3 consecutive duty days prior to event. Didn't adequately acclimate to local time. Hotel didn't had in room ventilation or climate controls of any kind.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Allow crews 1 day off prior to using in live flight environment so that they might acclimate to the local time and sleep patterns. Provide hotel with environmental controls to adequately control room temperature.

attribute.name: other_sleep/rest_information
attribute.value: Construction Area very near TDY hotel Fairfield INN & Suites 5060 A st, Anchorage, AK

attribute.name: other_physical_fatigue_symptoms
attribute.value: very exhausted at time of return to hotel

attribute.name: other_emotional_fatigue_symptoms
attribute.value: Frustrated for having to fly over Contractual SOP duty limits and flight duty limits.

attribute.name: fatigue_contributing_factors
attribute.value: Accumulated Fatigue;Late Departure;Long Duty Period;Rest Quality at Hotel

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
10AUG12 thru 11AUG12
Scheduled Report time 1530z (0730L) Unaugmented Flight Crew (2 Pilots) Scheduled 2 Flight Segments
Scheduled Trip 10AUG12 thru 11AUG12z ANC to BRW (BSK820) 1700z to 1900z BRW to ANC (BSK824) 0230z to 0230z (11AUG12)
Scheduled Off Duty Release time 0500z (11AUG12)
Total Scheduled FDP (Flight duty period) 13+00 Total Scheduled work hours on company time (On Duty to Scheduled Release) 13+30
Actual Trip Block times 10AUG12 thru 11AUG12z
Actual on duty Report time was 1515z (0715L)
ANC to BRW (BSK820) 1735z to 1940z BRW to ANC (BSK824) 0540z to 0740z
Actual Off Duty Release time 0810z / 0010L (11AUG12) Actual Return to Hotel Check back-in time 0835z / 0035L (11AUG12)
Actual Total completed work hours (On Duty to Actual Release) 16+55 Actual Total completed work hours on company time (On Duty to Hotel check back-in) 17+20
Actual FDP 16+25 (Ending at Aircraft Block-in Time)
Narrative:
There was numerous safety violations conducted on this one day trip.
Our briefings clearly indicated direction for safety to be the number one goal at Shell Oil.
Miami Air FOM Bulletin 12-04 states: The purpose of this bulletin is to address the additional policies and procedures specific to this contract and the additional restrictions for operations into PASC.
Under Duty and Rest Limitations of this bulletin it states: Shell has established the following duty and rest limitations over and above Miami Airâ€™s FAR and contractual limitations:
â€¢ Max flight duty period of 14 hours. Can be extended to 16 hours with a duty break (day room) of at least 3 hours. â€¢ Max 190 duty hours in a 28 day period. Includes standby time.
Both of these limitations established over and above Miami Airâ€™s FAR and contractual limitations were violated on this one day trip.
Flight duty period (FDP) is defined by current FARâ€™s to mean: A period that begins when a flightcrew member is required to report for duty with the intention of conducting a flight, a series of flights, or positioning or ferrying flights, and ends when the aircraft is parked after the last flight and there is no intention for further aircraft movement by the same flightcrew member. A flight duty period includes the duties performed by the flightcrew member on behalf of the certificate holder that occur before a flight segment or between flight segments without a required intervening rest period. Examples of tasks that are part of the flight duty period include deadhead transportation, training conducted in an aircraft or flight simulator, and airport/standby reserve, if the above tasks occur before a flight segment or between flight segments without an intervening required rest period.
Duty is defined by current FARâ€™s to mean: Any task that a flightcrew member performs as required by the certificate holder, including but not limited to flight duty period, flight duty, pre- and post-flight duties, administrative work, training, deadhead transportation, aircraft positioning on the ground, aircraft loading, and aircraft servicing.
The FDP completed this trip was 16+25 hrs. The Duty completed in the past 28 days after this trip 193+47 hrs. (please note that only Miami Air Short Call standby or as what the FARâ€™s delineate as Reserve availability period is used in this calculation) Additional time would have to be added if Shell Oil considers standby time to include Miami Airâ€™s long call standby.
Here is the data to support excess duty in the past 28 days.
11AUG duty completed 08+35 10AUG duty completed 08+45, total 17+20 (10&11AUG continual duty across zulu day)
02AUG duty completed 05+55, total 23+15 01AUG duty completed 10+55 31JUL duty completed 05+00, total 38+20 (31JUL&01AUG continual duty across z day) 30JUL duty completed 08+33, total 46+53 29JUL duty completed 03+00, total 49+53 28JUL duty completed 24+00, total 83+53
23JUL duty completed 09+15, total 93+08 23JUL duty completed 04+45 22JUL duty completed 03+30, total 101+23 (22&23JUL continual duty across zulu day) 21JUL duty completed 08+04, total 129+57 21JUL duty completed 05+10 20JUL duty completed 07+00, total 143+07 (20&21JUL continual duty across zulu day) 19JUL duty completed 13+50, total 156+57 19JUL duty completed 02+15 18JUL duty completed 18+00, total 177+12 (18&19JUL continual duty across zulu day) 17JUL duty completed 04+55 16JUL duty completed 05+30, total 187+37 (16&17JUL continual duty across zulu day) 15JUL duty completed 06+10, total 193+47
Our operation conducted on 10AUG12 into 11AUG12 (the zulu day) mostly all on 10AUG local Alaska time was in violation of the FDP (flight duty period) limitations as provided by Shell Oil and in violation of enforceable FAR duty time limits under part 121.
After a mostly uneventful flight #820 ANC to BRW our crew were transported to Shell Oilâ€™s man camp. This was a dayroom with dining and rest facilities and other services.
The crew assembled at around 0100z to 0115z for transport from the BRW dayroom to the aircraft. When we returned to the passenger terminal we received word that the aircraft battery switch was left on and that the aircraft battery was dead. Captain Lane specifically told the FAâ€™s that they could remain in the passenger terminal because there was no heat on the aircraft. After only a couple of minutes the FAâ€™s elected to go out to the plane to get ready and prepare for flight #824, it appeared that they initially were willing to wait on a cold aircraft while maintenance would be performed to restore battery power.
During the attempt to re-charge the battery this process began to take a long time. We were due to block out at 0230z and after some time charging the battery it became clear that we would not get out on time. For the most part our 5 passengers remained patient. At some point in time the passengers were boarded and an attempt to start the #1 engine from a ground air cart was made. The engine did light off and begin to run up but before starter cutoff the electrical power in the plane went out and we were forced to shut-off fuel to the start because of no indications in the cockpit on this engine.
The passengers were then let off the plane. Sometime later an Alaska airline B737 arrived and the passengers got word that it was scheduled to depart to ANC. They elected to leave the Shell Oil passenger terminal and go to Alaska airlines terminal to leave on that flight. Alaska airlines records indicate that flight AS#52 blocked out of BRW at (2046L) 0446z.
After our passengers left and that we noticed the Alaska flight departed the captain became concerned that we may exceed flight duty time restraints. We were already bumping up against the 14 hour limitation but due to the dayroom we would be allowed to go to 16 hrs.
Therefore it could be determined that in order for the max of 14 to be extended to 16 we would have needed to block out by 0715z and still be good to plan to block in for the scheduled 2+00 hr block flight at 0915z. A planned Block-in time at ANC of 0915z would place us at exactly 16+00 Flight duty period.
However as minutes turned into hours and hours on into the next waiting a good portion of the time on the aircraft in freezing cold temperatures re-charging the aircraft battery it became apparent as we were getting closer to 0715z that we would probably have to stay in BRW.
After realizing a problem existed in the fact that we had not reset the battery charger circuit breaker and the reason we may had not be getting a good re-charge on the battery could have been due to this. Therefore despite the fact that we were now very, very close to the time of 0715z the captain chose to see how well the charge was doing after the mistake. I believe that he felt that he would be able to get a good charge on the battery after the mistake was corrected and that he would be able to maintain a good air cart start once the battery made it up to his desired voltage. The result was just this, however we had a problem in that the attempt to start the #1 engine this second time was done after 0715z. We indicated that we blocked out at 0740z from BRW, which was too late to be in compliance with Shellâ€™s mandate.
I felt intimidated by Captain Lane and with the presence of Javier Ferrer (a designated Jumpseater not dispatched for flight duties) not to object to completing operations beyond the limitations established by Shell Oil. Despite Shell Oil briefings that authorize any person even low on the totem pole permission to shut operations down for suspected safety concerns, I did not feel comfortable at Miami Air to do this. I was worried that if I refused to go beyond the 16 hours duty or even 16 hours flight duty period that a possibility existed that Javier Ferrer would be dispatched by the company to fly the crew home on flight #824 and leave me in Barrow alone in arguably some sort of trouble with the company if I did so. I felt that I was in a tight spot.
When asked by the Captain of my opinion in BRW. I explained that we should just return to ANC in the morning.
The reality is that a lot more happened including pressure by the Captain to consider resetting the clock by returning to the day room and count a rest period utilizing the block-in time at BRW of 1940z (10AUG12). When confronted by the Captain about such and idea I refused to answer and to my best recollection I may have shrugged my shoulders. He explained to me that we could plan a block-out time of around (2340L) which in turn comes out to be 0740z. When looking up the FOM bulletin there are conditions where Shell Oil permits the 12 hr rest period to be reducible to 11 hrs if the accommodations are within 30 minutes as such was the case. The time of 0740z 11AUG12 minus the time of 1940z 10AUG12 equals 12 hrs. After reviewing these numbers I believe the captain was considering granting the crew a 12 hour rest vice an 11 hour rest to begin at our BRW Block-in time. If we would have conducted such actions we would have clearly violated duty time constraints as it is difficult for any certificate holder to justify requiring a crew member to report for duty then after some time, and in this case about 4-5 hours of waiting, not count the duty involved in waiting for an up aircraft.
Also in that dayâ€™s mess included pressure by FAâ€™s that clearly had get-home to ANC itus. They did not want to stay in Barrow.
The working conditions were appalling due to the fact that the plan return trip was spent mostly in freezing cold weather with no APU nor heat on the N752MA aircraft.
One can clearly see that we completed 16+40 hrs duty in accordance with the Miami Air report procedures.
Since Shell indicates by the FOM bulletin a limit on the FDP vice Miami Airâ€™s trip sheet duty, you will find the FDP completed was 16+25 hrs.
And we really didnâ€™t block out at 0740z because it was actually 5-10 minutes later.
My frustration after reaching the hotel after 17+20 hrs was not only because we violated FAA Regs as well as Shell requirements but also because of many other safety violations.
Some of my frustrations were because of procedural issues in conducting an approach to BRW in instrument conditions. While cleared to 2000 ft direct to LEDHO the following occurred after clearance to fly the 16 DME arc and clearance to fly the LOC DME (back crs) RWY 25 to PABR/BRW. The captain flew the leg. We intercepted the final approach course at approximately 11.9 DME as we were unable to maintain the 16 DME arc. While in a nice turn intercepting the Final approach course the captain selected VOR/LOC and the FMA captured the VOR/LOC but began what appeared like an immediate turn to the right yet the auto-pilot may have only been taking out the original left turn applied that was capturing the Final approach course nicely. As a result the captain de-selected the VOR/LOC function engaged V/S to descend to 1700â€™ and tried to redirect the heading to center up the final approach course. While we stayed within the Final approach course limits of the HSI course that was dialed in 071 degrees, we never centered the course until sometime later in visual conditions. I called JISTU 1740 ft crossing the Final Approach Fix and shortly thereafter we went to full scale deflection of the HSI to the left. The captain decided to dive the aircraft at approximately 1100-1200 fpm with the full scale deflection in an attempt to break through the reported 600 overcast ceiling to find the runway before the MAP. We did break through the overcast layer and when we did so I reported the runway in sight. I continued in visual conditions to report the 100 ft above minimums until the captain reported his visual to the runway as procedure established by Miami Air. My safety concerns were that the captain had difficulty flying the 16 DME arc, went to full scale deflection inside the FAF and failed to execute a missed approach, and then decided to dive the aircraft to break through the overcast before the MAP while not in protected airspace.
Some of my frustrations were because of maintenance issues that occurred on the ground after arrival in BRW. The maintenance issues on the ground were related to the dead battery as previously described. However, I would like to add that I am uncertain as to whether proper charging procedures were applied to get the dead battery re-charged. Our AOM has a procedure that calls for a 28V dc source to re-charge the battery and I believe we only used a 115V DC power source. This is probably why after the captain reset the Battery charger circuit breaker very late in the duty day that we were able to get a good charge on the battery. My safety concern was because proper procedure was not followed on the re-charge.
Some of my frustrations were because a Non-dispatched pilot (a Jumpseater) was allowed to fly portions of the leg BRW to ANC. This I was not certain was in compliance with what Northern Air Cargo and Shell Oil may or may not object to.
In addition to a frustrating day for all crew members I was very tired, cold, hungry and fatigued throughout most of the evening there in Barrow. My feet literally didnâ€™t get warm until arrival into ANC, where the reported temperature was 14 C. And I was especially fatigued upon arrival at the Fairfield INN at 1235am (0035L) 11AUG 12 after 17+20 hours.
Lastly, upon my departure from the Hotel in Anchorage as requested by Northern Air Cargo I was approached by Captain Lane while boarded to the hotel shuttle-bus. He came up to me to say goodbye. Then just as he began walking away he said â€œIâ€™m sorryâ€
I was puzzled and I exclaimed â€œsorry?, for what?â€
He said â€œbecause you have to go.â€
I said â€œBob.â€
He said â€œWhat?â€
I asked â€œDonâ€™t you think it would have been best to have returned from Barrow in the morning?â€
He said â€œYep.â€

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Just avoid going over time duty limits. When you turn into a pumpkin, it is time to stop.

attribute.name: flight_crew
attribute.value: ;Contacted ATC;Declared Emergency with ATC;Executed Missed Approach;Landed in Emergency Condition

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: During approach into AMS the landing gear lever was jammed in the off position, we could not extend the gear normally. We informed ATC, executed a missed approach and declared an emergency. We were given vectors back for an approach to runway 27 with enough time to complete all checklists including the manual gear extention. With the gear extended manually and confirmed down and locked we completed a normal landing in visual conditions to runway 27. We alerted the tower that we would not have nose wheel steering after landing as a result of the abnormal condition and would need assistance. The passengers were made aware of a technical problem with the gear lever. I informed them that I would be using an alternate method of lowering the landing gear, thanked them for their patience and reassured them that we would be making a normal landing. The AMS airport did an outstanding job. Our passengers were deplaned and taken to the Terminal by buses and the Aircraft then towed to Gate D10.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: The landing gear lever malfunctioned and could not be moved out of the off position.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: The landing gear lever was jammed in the off position.

Scheduled block 9:09, duty 1410 Actual block 9:25, duty 13:30 During the last third of the third flight I felt myself yawing and eye rubbing. After blocking in I found myself irritable with minor occurrences.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
It was presented to me that an EFB needed to be created and released as soon as possible because an EFB was DMI'd only because of a search feature not working in one of the manuals (FOM) in the unit.
I suggested waiting for the next release which would be released in 3 days to release the fix and DMI-ing an EFB only because of a search feature was not necessary. To clarify, the EFB still works perfectly fine, its just the search feature that had an issue.
A Read File was created (RF 1149) and posted without my knowledge that the EFB unit should not be DMI'd because of a search feature in a manual not working. I then received word directly from the Chief Pilot, Miguel Martin that the EFB being DMI'd was useless and was not required to have an EFB released just for one manual. Since I am responsible for taking orders directly from my supervisor, I informed him via email and asked for clarification since I am primarily responsible for releasing EFB's and should know whats going on. Although the new EFB set that was set to release on 7/16/2015 with an addition updated bulletin to the FOM, I was ordered to still proceed with the old release to fix the search issue. Employee's responsible for shipping and handling of the EFB work orders were not too happy about the release going out so soon and including myself think it was not only a waste of time but also a waste of money.
I personally think that this could have been properly handled if there was better communication and having confidence in employee's recommendations which are notorious to be ignored company-wide. In this case, I am told by my supervisor to do one thing, while someone in hire authority asked me something else (something that I initially suggested), then my supervisor proceeds to tell me to do something different.
Lack in communication is not only unfair to employees but it could result in safety issues, unnecessary cost, and additional work/task to be done that is not actually required. Additionally, when someone ask another immediate employee a question about an item in the department "I don't know, you have to ask [xyz]" should not be a response 99% of the times. We have had incidents in the past, where we not only embarrassed ourselves in front of the FAA but were hammered for similar issues, yet it still continues.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Refusal for management and supervisor to communicate

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Have better communication with all members pertaining to an item. This makes sure everyone understands what's going on rather than everyone having a different level of understanding of what's going on

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Acting Purser D. Kearse called the flightdeck and advised she had a sick passenger and might need oxygen. Advised her to ask if any medical personel were onboard to assit her. A doctor onboard assited the pax with oxygen and used the blood pressure cuff and stethescope out of the EMK. The patient was stable and an emergency was not declared. Best couse of action was to continue to destination. Contacted Aliegent Operations at KPIE and requested the flight be met by medical personnel on arrival. Landed without incident. A/C met by paramedics and the passenger was removed from the A/C and taken to the ambulance. Please see Acting Purser D. Kearse's report for more detailed pax info.

attribute.value: On climb out of Miami I turned on Wx Radar and got a Wx Fail message. Then the Master Caution Overhead came on alerting us to the Left Equipment Cooling Exhaust Off Light illuminated. We ran the checkslist and Switched to Alternate and light flickered in the Alt. mode along with degrading of color on attitude indicatior and nav display. I elected to retun to Miami due to no wx radar flro flight.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: After completeing all Before Takeoff checks (including the check of the takeoff warning horn) we were cleared for takeoff on Runway 20. The throttles were moved to 40% N1 and the aircraft started its takeoff roll. The captain (myself) called 40% N1. The First Officer pushed the TOGA button and called "N1, HDG SEL, TOGA, check thrust". Within seconds the takeoff warning sounded the first officer pulled the throttles to idle and I took control of the aircraft. We taxied off of the runway at "Bravo" taxiway. We checked the aircraft configuration (Flaps were 1, Stab in the green band LEDs extended, green light, no parking brake, SB handle down, no spoilers up) and pushed both throttles up several times and no takeoff warning horn. Second takeoff was normal.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: March 03 7:00pm to March 06 7:00pm, 3 strait days of 24 hr standby. With the requirement to be at the office within an hour and a half once called.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Impossible not to sleep during this duty, we need a defined rest period.

attribute.name: fatigue_contributing_factors

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Approaching SERTA intersection (not in wbat database) PF called for Flaps 1. L Flap needle moved to 1/2 way between up and 1, R Flap needle stayed near up and flaps stopped moving. Completed Non-Normal Checklists 9.37 and 9.48. At 500' Captain took control of A/C and landed without incident.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: L Flap needle moved to 1/2 way between up and 1, R Flap needle stayed near up and flaps stopped moving.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: Saw L Flap needle 1/2 way between up and 1, R Flap needle near up and flaps stopped moving.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: PF called for Flap Asymmetry Checklist. Pilot in observer's seat ran checklist while PF continued approach and PM communicated with ATC. At 500' Captain (PM) took control of A/C and landed without incident.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: This was an A/C anomaly that can occur for a number of reasons. System was checked, A/C was unpowered to remove faults and released for flight without further incidence.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
At cruise ArkeFly F/A Kadirbaks noticed a lady with a cast on her arm that was setting in the exist row. She felt the lady may not be able to perform the required task of the exist row. F/A Kadirbaks asked the lady to move to a non exist row. The lady's husband had an issue with the request and verbally threatened F/A Kadirbaks by telling his wife to hit the flight attendant. After several time of telling his wife, other passengers started to back up F/A Kadirbaks. The family did finally move to a different row.
After the incident F/A Kadirbaks came to the flight deck and requested to have the police meet the airplane at the gate in AMS. So, she would have the option to press charges against the verbally threatening passenger if she chose to. I called Ops(131.4) to request security to meet the flight upon arrival.
The police meet the airplane at gate G05 in AMS and escorted the verbally threatening passenger off the airplane. After the rest of the passengers had deplaned, I asked the police officer if we (MAI crew members) needed to give any statements? The officer said "no and we were free to carry on with our normal duties."

I gave information to a/c we were diverting to BOS for Mx to inspect-Gave frequency for Signature.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Engine Fire extinguisher bottle and squibs were shipped properly from MAI's stockroom to North State Aviation, a Part 145 Repair Station. The partially undeclared box was somehow placed in the cargo hold of N739MA and flown for five legs. While the aircraft was in Norfolk, VA. Mr. Dimitry Pigne, a Tech Rep for Miami Air, found the box while looking for tools. Mistakenly, Mr. Pigne, shipped the box without inspecting the contents to the Miami Air stockroom via two day FedEx, undeclared on April 16, 2013. The box was received by Mr. Joe Benard at the stockroom, who upon receipt of the package realized that it had been shipped improperly. Ms. Maria Jimenez, Director of Purchasing/Stores, began an investigation of the shipping history of the package. All shipping labels were secured, pictures taken (see attachments to this report). Mr. Pigne wrote a letter of apology to Mr. Walter Iwanenko, Director of Maintenance, accepting full responsibility for shipping the item partially undeclared.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Flight attendant Nora Arriola (who was working aft of aircraft) was made aware that a female passenger was feeling light headed upon landing in San Juan.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Probable cause was passenger dehydration and/or heat exhaustion

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: As we were parking at gate 24, Flight attendant Nora Arriola advised Purser Matt Goodbody via inter phone.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: Once blocked in, purser Matt Goodbody advised me via inter phone to please call paramedics as we had a possible medical emergency. I immediately advised San Juan ground on frequency 121.9 to please have the paramedics meet the aircraft at gate 24 where we were parked. Paramedics arrived within 5 minutes, placed the female passenger in a wheelchair and provided oxygen. According to paramedics the passenger showed dehydration/heat exhaustion symptoms.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: N732MA Flt 356 commanded by Capt William Robinson occured around 2300z .The weather was above minimums during planning, before takeoff, and most of enroute. Weather at UNV became below landing minimuns M1/4 sm visibility as flight was approaching for landing. new taf estimated that the weather will stay approximately that way for the next 3 -6 hours. Capt called operations, supervisor was notified and the decision to divert was made. Diversion was to PIT. Client was consulted before making the decision to go to PIT and they concurred that it would be best for safety.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: At around 2335z a conversation was over heard between Maintenance Control and Capt. Curtis. Capt. Curtis reported that he had an aborted takeoff due to a problem with the Autothrottle. Dispatch notified the Duty Manager and copied Chief Pilot, V.P. Ops and CEO. I spoke with Capt. Curtis at 0010Z and I remind him to submit an irregularity report.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
At 0400z saw that the metar and taf for SBEG dropped below landing min. advised Capt of conditions, talked to our ground handler in MAO that we might divert due to wx if the wx do not improve prior to arr.
ACFT diverted at 0605z to STM. Waited for WX to improve in metar, but no improvment by 0800z. Consulted with duty officer, John Passwater at 0810z that the best option is to put the crew to rest. Crew needed to be off STM by 0915z to be in MAO by 1030z to be legal, per crew scheduling

attribute.value: On May 3, 2013 Giovanni brought to my attention that he was attack by fleas while working in the cage area located in the Hangar. I immediately contact Luigi so he can call the extermator. Orkin came on Friday afternoon and perform there treatment. On May 7, 2013 Rodolfo brought to my attention that he has also been attack by fleas while working in the cage. I immediately told Luigi and he called the extermator which came out and perform the treatment. Today is May 9,2013 and the problem still occurs. Both Giovanni and Rodolfo got attack again by fleas and this morning when Giovanni wanted to show me where it occured i got attacked.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
"Out on the line for a couple of weeks in April and perhaps someone else other than me should look at a possible incident waiting to happen.
Specifically, the maintenance utility ladders that are stored in the belly of the aircraft and used to access the pitot probe covers as well as to get into and out of the belly of the aircraft itself, are inadequate for the job.
The ladders are too short and the base of ladder is not wide enough causing an unstable reach and/or egress from the belly of the aircraft. This instability is in good weather and when you add gusty winds, rain and/or an icy tarmac, think you will be asking for trouble. My opinion is that another two feet should be added to the ladder with a proportional base width increase, so as not to be using the last rung of the ladder in reaching up, or in the case of cargo area, stepping down from the bay."

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: It is very difficult to do the preflight on the AED on the 800s. We had a borken hasp on the AED box on A/C 739 recently and that was fixed. Then the handle on that very same AED was broken when the F/As attempted to remove it from it's container for inspection. The complaint is that the door to the box and the way it opens makes it difficult to remove the AED.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: The handle broke because you have to yank on the AED to remove.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: Written up in the log book and the hadle was fixed

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Modification to the AED box. If it could open top to bottom instead of side to side that would provide enough room to remove the AED without having to yank on it. This would prevent other handles from being broken and the F/As will not have to struggle to remove the AED to perform

attribute.value: Company Policy SOP Non-Compliance;Reduced Safety Standards

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Arrived at KPIT Atlantic Aviation Ramp and the requested GPU was not redly available. Forward stairs brought up to A/C so engine 1 was shut down and waited for GPU to arrive. While waiting ground crew approached R side of A/C, opened forward cargo compartment and began unloading bags in close proximity to running engine #2.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Ground crew in hurry to off load personal bags of home sports team.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: Flight deck indication that forward cargo door had been opened while engine #2 still running. Mechanic exited A/C and found belt loader at forward cargo pit and bags lined up at the nose of the A/C.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: After GPU power applied and engine #2 secured, went down and lecture ground personnel on the dangers of being in close proximity to the inlet of an operating jet engine and the threat to life and limb as well as the possibility of FOD damage to an expensive jet engine.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Atlantic Aviation KPIT needs to train ground personnel on dangers of working in and around jet A/C.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
MAINTENANCE CONTROL FELIX MARCANO REPORTED THAT N738MA DID A OVER WEIGHT LANDING AT LAS. THE AIRCRAFT TAXIED TO THE TAXIWAY.PASSENGERS OFFLOADED AND TRANSPORTED TO THE TERMINAL.THE AIRCRAFT WAS LATER TOWED TO THE GATE FOR THE BAGS TO BE OFFLOADED.THE AIRCRAFT WILL THEN BE TOWED TO A MAINTENANCE SPOT ONE. THE AIRCRAFT ARRIVED AT GATE APPROXIMATELY 0255Z
Sun, 06 Apr 2014 19:03 Z PLEASE NOTE, THE COMMENT "OVER WEIGHT LANDING" WAS THE NARRATIVE USED WHEN MAINTENANCE CONTROL FIRST REPORTED TO DISPATCH AND NOT BASED ON FACT.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Landed at KELM and taxied to parking on the De-Icing Ramp. Ramp personnel did not put cones around the aircraft; no marshaling of passengers away from the aircraft.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Ramp personnel (Atlantic Aviation employees) are not familiar with Miami Air ramp procedures.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: Talked to an Atlantic Aviation ramp supervisor, he stated that Atlantic Aviation were unaware of Miami Air's procedures regarding cones, vehicles, fuel trucks approaching the aircraft etc and had no written documents from Miami Air detailing those procedures.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Request a copy of Miami Air's "Station Operations and Ground Handling" Manual and sections of the FOM detailing ramp procedures be forwarded to Atlantic Aviation at ELM.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Declared medical emergency for a passenger requiring medical assistance. The information that was given to me; female 21 years of age, recently had undergone 2 laperoscopic surgeries to remove a blood clot from an undisclosed female area. She also had a D&C and currently taking no medications. During the flight she vomited 3 times and was bleeding profusely from her nose. Purser Anita Brulz and PA Erin Van Allen/passenger tended to Miss Alice Sams til paramedics boarded the aircraft. The paramedic surmized that her vital signs were normal, but as a precaution she should be taken to the hospital for further treatment. Miss Sams refused to go and decided to stay for the next flight ANC-SEA

attribute.name: non-compliance_with_cfrs,_policies/procedures
attribute.value: Company Policy SOP Non-Compliance;Reduced Safety Standards

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: I received a Safety Concern on 10/30/13 regarding Captain Lane's operations during the month of September 2013. Apparently Captain Lane, contradictory to company policy, decided to turn off the No Smoking Sign in the Passenger cabin on almost every live flight, shortly after takeoff. On the first occurrence, the cabin crew asked if it was a Smoking flight because none of the flight attendants were on the smoking flight volunteer list. Additionally, the passengers on that first flight had all been drinking heavily and there was confusion from the passengers as well. The captain responded that he did not want the lights from the signs interfering with the movie and stated that, like the Airbus, we are turning them off after takeoff. This non-compliance with procedures continued for the rest of the month, to the point where it became a joke among the crew to "light 'em up" after each takeoff.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Unknown. Captain decided to turn off the No Smoking signs after each live takeoff, contrary to published SOP's.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: Hotline report from a Purser and Flight Attendant.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: Filed this incident report for Operations to follow-up.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Recommend that a email or Read File be issued by the Chief Pilot or VP of Flight Operations that SOP regarding Passenger sign use is required and, without specific instructions from the company, Captain's are expected to comply with SOP's regarding the use of passengers information signs on all live passenger flights.
