attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: During climb lower DU illuminated announcing Engine #2 low oil pressure and 0 oil quantity. All other engine parameters indicating normal. Performed Engine Low Oil Pressure non-normal checklist which directed the Eingine Failure or Shutdown Checklist, shutting down #2 engine following Miami Air SOPs diverted to KMSY. Uneventful landing accomplished. Overwight landing occurred at KMSY.

attribute.name: flight_crew
attribute.value: ;Contacted ATC;Contacted Company;Declared Emergency with ATC;Executed Emergency Descent

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Cabin altitude warning horn sounded while climbing out of FL 250. We accomplished the immediate action items for cabin altitude warning horn. rapid depresurization. The cabin was at 13000' approx. and I felt it might exceed 14000' so I initiated the Emergency Descent. After all check-list where completed I noticed that the cabin altitude was descending below 10,000'. I asked ATC if we could stop the descent at FL200 since cabin altitude was 9000'. At FL200 we were able to control the cabin to normal cabin altitude so I canceled emergency with ATC and continued to destination.

attribute.name: flight_crew
attribute.value: ;Contacted ATC;Contacted Company;Contacted Mainenance;Contacted Operations;Declared Emergency with ATC

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: After takeoff from YQB the noise from the nose gear during retraction was louder than normal as the wheel spun down in the wheel well. All systems were functioning and indicating normally with no faults or warnings reflected.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: At the time there was no way of determining what caused the noise during the gear retraction.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: The noise from the nose gear was louder than normal during retraction

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: After determining that all systems were normal I called maintenance control to describe the noise we heard during gear retraction. They informed the duty officer and in a follow up call informed me that it was their opinion that there no cause for alarm. It was only a 47 minute flight and with no indications of an identifiable problem and no guidance from our QRH there was no reason not to land in ALB. I still had concerns that there was some kind of problem with the nose wheel, possibly a deflated tire. In the interest of safety, I explained the situation to the approach controller and asked that the emergency vehicles be on standby for our arrival. This constituted declaring an emergency. ATC suggested a flyby of the Tower to visually verify the status of the nose gear. The gear was extended and locked down with all normal indications. We accomplished the flyby; the Tower verified that everything appeared normal. We left the gear in the down and locked position and returned for a normal landing. On landing the nose shimmied a little but was very much controllable. An inspection of the gear after landing revealed that the left nose wheel tire had deflated and had some cuts in it accounting for the noise we heard during retraction.

attribute.name: flight_crew
attribute.value: ;Contacted ATC;Contacted Company;Contacted Operations;Declared Emergency with ATC;Landed in Emergency Condition

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Shortly after reaching cruise altitude I was informed the we had a passenger experiencing severe medical difficulties. Increasing heartbeat, difficulty in breathing, tightness in teh chest, losing feeling in his arms and legs and intermittent responsiveness. The passenger, Sean McCormick, needed immediate medical assistance. We declared a medical emergency and diverted to KMCO, the nearest major airport. Medical assistance and ground handling was arranged with coordinations through Dispatch. After landing the passenger was treated and taken to the hospital by medical personnel. Two on-board reps accompanied him, Pax Peter Forkner and Brandon White. After an overweight landing inspection by Maintenance and the log-book write-up cleared, we continued to BOS without further incident.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Missed approach for landing at KOAK straight ahead at 4000' due to landing gear failed to move from OFF position to down. Manual gear extension required. Landed normally.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: We were parked at North Cargo 3 (BOS) undergoing servicing of the aircraft at the time of the event. Passengers had been deplaned, equipment offloaded, and the aircraft fueled. A request was made to have the lavs fully dumped to facilitate the winterization process as we were scheduled to fly to YYZ for an overnight. At 7:15, I was in the back of the airplane with several of my flight attendants when we felt something impact the aircraft. There was a loud bang as the plane shook wildly for several seconds accompanied by sounds of screeching metal. I immediately ran off the airplane down the airstairs on to the tarmac. Seeing nothing to the left, I ran around the front of the aircraft to the right side where I saw a body sprawled out on the ground behind the right engine & Hector Ortega (Mech) running towards Pat Marz (Co Rep) and myself screaming for someone to call 911. I raced back up the airstairs to the aircraft. At 7:16 I placed a call to 911 and instructed F/O De LaRosa to call ground control and relay the situation to MassPort and instructed everyone else to remain onboard. Police, Fire/Rescue, Paramedics et al arrived on scene a couple minutes later.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: While I can only speculate, what I think happened is this. One Signature employee was backing a lavatory service truck up to aircraft left as another man was marshalling him in to position. The driver may have left the vehicle in Reverse thinking in fact he had put it in Park. Attempting to get out of the truck and with it still moving, he probably panicked and accidentally slammed on the gas pedal, instantly ramming into the marshaller, the underside tail end of the aircraft through to the other side coming to a rest about 30-40 feet off to aircraft right. On a side note, I do not recall seeing extra wheel chocks lying on the ground near where the lavatory truck normally would have been parked.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On pushback, GND Crew gave no signal to set parking brake when they disconnected. GND Crew was using hand signals. A/C started to roll backwards down hill. I set brakes. After start of #1 and #2 engines, I had no hydraulic steering. GND Crew failed to remove the bypass pin. I shut down engines, GND Crew removed bypass pin and we continued normal operation.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Ground Crew fail to comply with Company SOPs

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
For years I have sat down in the front middle desk at Dispatch office. There is a air condition vent (which has mold spores growing from it). I have asked again and again for this vent to be cleaned and a filter put in it. Finally after nagging for many years Miami Dade came (6years ago) put a filter in this particular vent. It has been a long while and no filter has been ever replaced.
When I walk into our Dispatch office after of a couple of hours of being there my throat starts to bother me. Or I sneeze, or my eyes start to cry. This is a very unhealthy environment to work and give your best performance.
All of this can be confirmed by just looking up at the vent. Also in the back room where the refrigerator is the vent is blowing black mold particles. Again this is a very unhealthy environment. I am very concerned for myself and my co-workers health.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: Slow bag delivery by Ground Handler. Lack of belt loader. Typical terrible ground service by Swissport YYZ. Didn't check for pax baggage. No pin for push back.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
This is regarding a safety concern that has occurred a few times in the past and continuously happens to that point I feel it should be addressed. This remains a concern to me because it puts my life and the lives others in great danger.
For some reason, someone (most likely, the contractors) almost always continue to leave the Aircraft stair railing completely open (e.g., Pic 2 and 4 ) OR occasionally, create what I call: a Bear Pit where they, leave the stair pulled away away from the aircraft (1 to 3 feet away) while the door remains open (e.g., Pic 1, 3, 4 and 5). If someone does not pay close attention to this they WILL fall right through the opening.
I want to clearly state that Luigi, Reniel, and Eddie are always very good at keeping an eye on safety issues and, from my personal experience, always address the matter immediately when it goes mentioned. However, I also notice that safety issue are higher when we have contractors are working on the ramp. In regards to the stair, to rectify the matter, I personally asked the nearest worker (so happened to be a contractor) "if [he] could assist me in moving the stair closer to the aircraft since it was a safety concern". His response was â€œAre you going up to the aircraft?â€ and â€œnot to worry about it because nobody is inside the aircraftâ€. With my experience, I don't really think contractors are concerned or care about keeping areas safe. After all, they are not full time Miami Air employees.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On rollout from landing Rwy 25L. Right main #4 tire blew out approximately 1500-2000' after touchdown at less than 1000 knots groundspeed. Exited runway at high speed taxiway A& and turned right onto inactive RWY 7L-25R for back taxi to gate e-1 at terminal 3. Tower informed us of smoke coming underneath the airplane. Stopped the airplane on RWY for fire/emergency vehicles to respond/evaluate. Passenger removed on busses to Int'l Terminal for Immigration/Customs. Aircraft towed to gate E-1 once cleared by emerg/rescue units and evaluation by flight mechanic. Pictures by Flt Mechanic indicate large "bullseye" pattern possibly indicating locked wheel (non-rotation of tire) on rollout causing the tire to blow. No abnormal anti-skid indication in cockpit. Auto brake setting was at "2".

category.name: Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
The following safety concern have been brought to my attention by several Crew members.
The Lanyards that Miami Air International provides to their Crew members have no safety release/breakaway feature. The lanyard could get stuck when an employee is performing their duties, without the safety release an injury could occur!

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Provide lanyards with a Miami Air logo with a safety release feature.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
AT 33,000 IN CRUISE , CREW RECEIVED AND RESPONDED TO A TCAS TA/RA COMMAND . FIRST OFFISER CENNING MANUEVERED THE AIRCRAFT IAW TCAS COMMAND "DESCEND". CREW RECEIVED "CLEAR OF CONFLICT " AT 32,000 FEET . THE AIRCRAFT DESCENDED 1000 FEET AND THEN LATER RETURNED TO ASSIGNED ALTITUDE.
ATC ADVISED THAT THEY WERE AWARE THAT ANOTHER AIRCRAFT COULD NOT MEET A CLIMB RESTRICTION AND THAT WAS THE REASON FOR THE EVENT. MEMPHIS CENTER AND ATLANTA CENTER WERE INVOLVED. THIS OCCURRED AT HAND OFF.
CREW RESPONDED IAW MIAMI AIR'S SOP.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: OTHER AIRCRAFT WAS UNABLE TO MEET ATC CROSSING RESTRICTION ALTITUDE.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: AIRCRAFT WAS FLOWN IAW TCAS 'DESCEND' COMMAND

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: BETTER COORDINATION WITH ATC ON TRAFFIC. IN THE PAST I HAVE BEEN GIVEN A HEADING CHANGE OR DIFFERENT ALTITUDES.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: @TUL, parking was on GA ramp with rope tie downs everywhere. This is an accident waiting to happen. Tulsa FBO has to be told that parking must be on a ramp free of tie downs and FOD.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: After deplaning at BIF, the ground crew left. No one was in the building as we walked out. The gate at the building was locked and unmanned. There was no transportation set up for the crew. We later found out that there is a taxi service on the airport which is usually used instead of the hotel van. This has to be set up ahead of time.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: Personal bags was excessive. Had to gate check bags. Also no Spanish speaking Crew members.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: During taxi in, aircraft's right main tire momentarily left the ramps paved surface.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: The new JQF ramp parking area is unlit with no taxi line guidance or edge lighting. Nigh operation with limited visibility. The parking spots are set back from the building causing the parking aircraft to taxi to close to the unlit ramp edge.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Uncontrolled ramp area needs lighting and surface markings. Parking area needs to be relocated closer to the buildings providing more space to maneuver.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Upon arrival at N752MA on MAI Hangar Ramp, PIC briefed by maintenance that the aircraft had fresh PT, had just had work done on #1 engine to replace 5 fan blades and engine re-rigged to within limits to more closely match acceleration with the other engine, and that, upon takeoff thrust settings, the bleed system developed big split in bleed air pressure (causing #1 engine Bleed Air Trip Off), but that upon reduction of thrust from takeoff power to normal climb power, the pressure differential would reduce and the bleed trip would reset. Maintenance indicated that no maintenance action - diagnostic, preventative, or corrective - was taken regarding the bleed system issue prior to the flight. At takeoff (< 100' AGL) the #1 engine Bleed Air tripped off (w/ associated #1 engine "Bleed Trip Off" and "Master Caution" lights illuminating). On climb out, after selecting VNAV for the climb thrust setting, the #1 engine Bleed was reset utilizing the "Trip Reset" button. Cabin appeared to be pressurizing normally on climb out. Aircraft was cleared toward the north (direct VVMAX on Hedly One RNAV SID) and issued series of step climbs to integrate with crossing traffic as necessary. On three separate instances during the climb out, the #1 engine Bleed Trip Off light illuminated and was reset per QRH procedures. On each occasion, the bleed air pressure differential was significant (L Bleed Air 12psi, R Bleed Air 54psi). Although the last climb clearance issued by ATC was to climb to FL350, PIC asked for, and granted permission to stop the climb at FL310 in order to monitor cabin pressure. At FL310, the #1 Engine Bleed tripped off again -- again with the big psi differential noted previously, and it was determined that the aircraft would not hold 8000' cabin altitude (cabin altitude indicated as high as 9000') and that flying at lower altitudes would place the aircraft in, not over, weather buildups present in the direction of the planned flightpath, as well as those forecast enroute to KCLT. PIC decided to return to KMIA and ATC rerouted N752MA back to KMIA without further incident.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Known issues with #1 Bleed Air system were not properly investigated, nor corrected prior to releasing the aircraft as airworthy for flight.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: Aircraft warning systems (Master Caution and Bleed Trip Off annunciations).

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: Once determined that the #1 engine bleed air system's problems had not been properly identified or corrected prior to flight, and that the cabin pressure would be compromised unless the aircraft limited itself to a lower altitude along a route that would take it into present and forecast thunderstorms and icing conditions, PIC determined that returning to KMIA was the best course of action.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: One suggestion would be to thoroughly investigate and correct identified maintenance issues on critical systems such as the engine bleed air system and to test corrective measures taken prior to releasing the aircraft as airworthy.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: CHQ. No ground handling frequency. Tower directed us to the wrong ramp (Military). No taxiway or runway signage at all.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: when_was_the_event_detected?
attribute.value: ;While Aircraft was in Service at Gate

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: While the military were loading 753 in NGU, they put two small dents on the right side of the aircraft, one on either side of the forward cargo door. The dents were caused by a wooden box they use to transport the the bags to the cargo hold via a forklift truck. The dents occurred after loading was complete and they were attempting to move the baggage box away from the aircraft. The dents were written up in the logbook. Our mechanic, John Esposito, photographed and measured the the dents, this information was passed on to maintenance control. The dents were found to be well within limits so the item was cleared and the flight released. There was no delay incurred.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: I was not outside to see but it could only have been a mistake by the military forklift operator.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: I felt the aircraft move sideways slightly.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: I went outside with the mechanic to inspect the area. The damage appeared minor. We contacted maintenance and dispatch to alert them.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: The military could consider a different container for baggage transport, don't bring it so close to the aircraft and try to be more careful and aware in future.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: At YYZ, ground personnel disconnected ground power from aircraft prior to Captain's request. APU was not running, pax were on board.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: Atlantic Aviation FBO @ PBI: Please advise management and crews about sand and gravel in front of engines that will require a tug pull out or single engine taxi at least till out of this area. Very heavy sand and rocks in front of both aircraft here with possible FOD ingestion. I have spoken to Atlantic Aviation and they advise this is the only area able to accommodate a B737. Beware!

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: Fuel was not coordinated with Miami Air. Caused delay.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: BSK577 CALLED IN TO INFORM MAINTENANCE CONTROL THAT THE ARE GOING TO RETURN TO MIA TO INVESTIGATE A MECHANICAL PROBLEM. THE AIRCRAFT WAS AT TOP OF CLIMB ABOUT 14 MINS. NORTH OF MIA.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Company scheduled transportation back to Miami for crew. Travel and Crew Scheduling scheduled a LIMO from UNV to PIT to be followed by a commercial to ATL and MIA. The van that picked up the crew had no seat belts available in the two benches of the van. Only the front passenger seat had a seat belt available. Belts were either tied up and unusable and/or were missing. Road conditions were poor mainly caused by the snow storm that had passed by the day/evening prior. Weather reported at UNV at 2:55 AM was calm, 5.0 miles vis, light snow, overcast skies. Weather reported at PIT at 4:07 AM was light winds, 0.5 miles vis, light drizzle, mist. The forecast for PIT during the drive was 1.o miles vis, light freezing drizzle, mist. Ice was accumulating on the van throughout the three hour drive. Half way through the drive, the driver had to stop for fuel and to clear the wipers and windows from ice build up. Rear view mirrors were unusable due to ice build up. The drive way scheduled for 3:15 AM Local. The roads had not all been cleared/treated and we encountered snow plows still trying to clear the roads during the drive. The driver never wore his own seat belt at any time. Driver also had approximately six or seven cell phones mounted to the dashboard around the steering wheel, one of which was used (iPhone) as a screen to display music videos which were played over the van's speakers. The van drive was in icy conditions, at night, in a vehicle without proper safety devices (seat belts).

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Miami Air Travel's inability to secure a professional and proper company to transport crew members. The company's inability to ensure safety standards are required and adhered to during company scheduled transportation.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: The company should have established safety guidelines and requirements for ground transportation companies. If these guidelines are not met, the company should not book transportation on these companies. Company should encourage crews to report issues prior to boarding and not feel obligated to endure dangerous situations.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Dispatching and release went according to plan. Aircraft was departing at the time of shift turnover. After the shift turnover, I looked up one last time before walking out the doors and noticed that the aircraft had made a u turn and was at about 9000 feet. I told the new dispatcher on duty that we should call the ground handling station to find out what was going on. The ground handling station said that the aircraft was doing a air turn back because they could not hold cabin pressure. I informed maintenance on duty that there was an air turn back and I informed the new dispatcher on duty, he gave me a nod to tell me he had it under control as the second dispatcher came in for and I left for the day.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Myself and the crew were being transported from the Miami Air office to Punta Gorda airport (PGD). The van departed at 1am LCL and was scheduled to arrive at 4am. The driver was cruising at speeds upwards of 80 MPH across Alligator Alley and north on I-75 between Naples and Punta Gorda, at night, which in my opinion was too fast and unsafe for a high profile vehicle. He also failed to slow down through construction areas near Fort Myers and was swerving out of his lane. In areas where the road was not illuminated by street lights, he should have used his high beams and did not, ever. The driver was displaying signs of fatigue as we got closer to our destination because he was swerving in and out of his lane. I asked him on a couple of occasions if he was feeling alright. The point is I should have been able to rest on my way to the airport as I was scheduled to operate a flight departing at 6am but could not, due to the erratic and unsafe driving.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: I believe the event occurred because the driver is not properly trained and may have been fatigued.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: It is not my intention to reprimand or accuse any one particular driver of poor or unsafe driving. This is an issue that has occurs frequently and with different drivers, particularly on long trips. If pilots are held to account by operating aircraft at high levels of safety to ensure the safety of their passengers, then the drivers and equipment that transport the crews to and from the airports should be held to the same standards.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Due to hotel renovations got woken much earlier then planned, combined with a two hour delay waiting for passengers to arrive caused fatigue.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Not having layovers at hotels during renovations.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On takeoff roll at about 105 kts the Master Caution and ELEC lights came on, Seeing we were not far down the runway and very light I decided to abort the takeoff. We exited the runway and returned to the Miami Air hangar.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: During the takeoff roll the IDG on the number two generator disconnected.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Some one was trying to store as much paper as possible to save space.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: Boxes were redistributed so that paper is easily accessible now.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: AT 001Z CAPT. SWEITZER CALLED VIA THE SAT PHONE TO INFORM DISPATCH (ALARIC BROWN) THAT HE HAD JUST ENTERED A HOLD PATTERN OVER WPT UCY DUE TO AND AIRCRAFT ON FIRE ON THE RUNWAY AT HAV. HE SAID HE HAD 20MINS OF HOLD FUEL/TIME AND ASKED IF HE SHOULD RETURN TO MIA AS THE LISTED ALTERNATE. DISPATCHER (ALARIC BROWN) ADVISED YES TO RETURN TO MIA.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Rejected takeoff on RWY20 KRIC @1340z. Master Caution- ENG illuminates +/- 60KIAS. F/O was the Pilot Flying, the Captain calls abort, informs tower of the abort and calls out having the controls. Preforms the rejected takeoff procedure. We then taxi clear of the runway and the F/O informs the tower we did not need any assistance. The Ground Controller told us to remain on the U taxiway and let them if we needed anything. We identified the EEC ALTN mode light was illuminated. Referred to the QRH and completed all the appropriate checklist. We then taxied back to the ramp (ANG) with no further incidents.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Master Caution- ENG illuminates +/- 60KIAS during takeoff; resulting in a rejected takeoff.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: BSK322 on descent to KCOU weather mu braking action poor -FZRA unable to land ...received call from a/c N753MA through SFO arinc diverting to ALT-STL...spoke to Phillip G/H gave me radio frequency and G/H to use in STL....pax were bussed from STL to COU

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: The MEL in Trax is not current (last revised in 2011) to the current revision of the MEL in the MEL and GMM manuals, as well as structure, information, etc.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: It was found as part of the daily log page surveillance tasks of the quality assurance department, that aircraft N732MA flew nine (9) flights (legs) with open logbook items. The event took place on February 24th, 2014, during a weekend of heavy flying, where MAI performed a number of flights between Indianapolis and Cancun, Mexico.

category.name: Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
This is an anonymous report received on Miami Air's Business Ethics on March 8th, 17:18.
[unknown caller]: "Today is march 8th, 2014. My complaint is concerning stock clerks, director purchasing, VP (mx), director of HR.
The reason why clerks leave is becuse whenever they go complain, it seems to get back to the VP of maintenance. We figured that one out because the VP of maintenance and director of HR are friendly. They are good friends. I don't know but ethics it seems, applies to other people, but does not apply to management. That's why people leave, not because of money. Because soon as they go complain, the deck gets stacked against them and they have to go look @ the job boards or get _________ [swiped?, wiped?] I think you should look in house first..."
There was a second message from the same caller, but the connection was noisy, broken and we were not able to understand enough to make sense of it.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Task cards were inadvertently marked as "terminated" causing an eventual overfly.

category.name: Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
On Tuesday, August 19, 2014, Mr. Curtis Gravett approached me with an ethics complaint. He claimed that he was being singled out by his manager and that he was sent to travel (work) to Amsterdam on his days off without getting compensated for them in terms of time nor was he paid for the extra days he worked.
On Wednesday, August 20th, Mr. Gravett and I went to set up an appointment with Human Resources to discuss the issue.
On Thursday, August 21, 2014, a meeting was held between Mr. Gravett, Tom Ostendorp (the Vice President of Maintenance), Mirella Quadri (Director of Human Resources) and myself, acting as the companyâ€™s Ethics Compliance Officer.
At the end of the meeting, it was decided that the matter will be elevated to Mr. Jim Proia, President/CEO of Miami Air.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Mr. Gravett believes he is being treated unjustly.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Our crew had to clear customs at GAC building in MIA. As we were walking on the sidewalk that leads to the GAC building (North Side of the Building), there was an area on the sidewalk that had a thin puddle of water and also a thin puddle of a slimy substance (possibly dirt, mud or algae). As we were walking in line, the F/O (Mr. Phillip Cameron) was walking behind me. He slipped in the mentioned area on the sidewalk and lost his footing, falling on his side. When I turned around, he was lying on the ground on his side. The flight mechanic (Mr. John Esposito) and I assisted him in getting him back on his feet. He seemed okay, but a little disoriented as he did hit the side of his face on the sidewalk when he fell. I also saw blood coming from his right hand. Both his index finger and middle finger were swollen.
From conversation with Cpt. Carballosa on 12/18 at the safety office:
Mr. Alejandro Torres of MDAD assisted the crew at the moment. After the event, crew cleared customs. Cpt. Carballosa spoke with Mr. Dino Leonardi of Miami Dade Airport (305-876-7486) who said he would write a report. He took the crew's information and suggested for the crew to call Fire Rescue. Crew was then taken to MAI hangar, where it waited for Fire Rescue. Fire Rescue came and examined Mr. Cameron. They took his vitals, cleaned his fingers and bandaged him. They also suggested for Mr. Cameron to go to urgent care clinic or emergency room. Cpt. Carballosa drove F/O Cameron to Baptist Urgent Care facility in Doral (NW 41st street) F/O Cameron received tetanus shot and x-ray and was then released.
Two days later, F/O Cameron reported his injured hand swollen and visited doctor. The wound was infected. The doctor prescribed antibiotics.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Pictures show dark substance on the cement, probably algae. This caused the F/O to slip.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: During Landing Gear replacement, discovered that parts were swapped from another aircraft in 2005 or 2007. The part exchange was not properly documented and the part was overflown by 3.5 years.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Concern:
Maintenance and flight crew ETOPS checklists "include to ensure that the PDSC was completed"
Not reflected on Dispatch ETOPS ck list: Suggestion that this be included in our ETOPS checklist.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: @ BOS, fueler forgot to put fuel truck in park. When fueling, truck jumped wheel chock and rolled forward about 6 feet.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Right after takeoff, crew called on the radio and said the nose gear was not coming up. Returned to airport.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: 1210Z NOTIFIED BY TUI THAT ACFT WAS DECLARING AN EMERGENCY. 1215Z SPOKE WITH TUI TO CONFIRM ACFT WAS LNDG. 1220Z CREW CALLED TO SAY THEY WERE ON THE GRND. 1225Z SENT MSG TO TUI ADVISING THEM THAT ACFT WAS ON GRND AND OUT OF SVC. 1245Z JIM PROIA BRIEFED BY CREW ON EVENTS. 1250Z JIM PROIA BRIEFED EJ (OCC MGR) OF ALL EVENTS AND CREW ACTIONS.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
At 0600z/05jul2013, saw that SUMU airport was falling below landing MINs, called Capt and advised him about status of WX in SUMU. At 0634z Capt called and we agreed to divert to EZE.
EZE was the best Altn instead of MDQ, due to gr.handling setup. INfo from UAS
At 0710z ACFT landed safely at EZE ETD: 1310z for SUMU

attribute.name: fatigue_contributing_factors
attribute.value: Accumulated Fatigue;Arrangement of Pairing Duty Periods;Dead Head;Insufficient Rest Period;Long Block Time;Tried Prior to Start of Duty Period

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
I previously left for a trip Sunday, August 24 where I deadheaded to Milwaukee, Wisconsin. The next day, August 25, I flew a 2 pilot ferry from Milwaukee (MKE) to Gander, Newfoundland (YQX) and then on to Groningen, Netherlands (GRQ). Due to the late inbound flight, my duty day officially started at 3pm local and ended at approximately 11am local the next day. With no relief pilot, I work (~14 hrs) through the night without so much as a 5 minute break. Predictably, I sleep in 2 different spurts until my next show time, each lasting for between 3-4 hours. I'm tired.
On August 27, I show at 9am local for a live flight from Groningen (GRQ) to Gander (YQX). We depart GRQ, again with no relief pilot, fly another crossing and arrive in YQX at about 12:30pm local. We depart YQX, still in uniform, and deadhead back to Miami on the continuation of our live flight and block in at 5:05pm local. Some almost 90 minutes later I'm back at the office and informed, incredibly, that I'm to be on short call starting early the next morning. I'm very tired.
On August 28, I wake up and am advised via email that I'm on short call yet again the following morning. Shortly thereafter (9:51am) crew scheduling calls to assign me a 1pm report for a Curacao turn. My sleep that night was fair and I felt slightly better but I recognized the cumulative effects of fatigue creeping in. Knowing I was facing another 10 hour day, I nonetheless accept the assignment. I arrive home after my turn at approximately 12:30am, fall asleep by 1:30 and am up automatically by 7. I am exhausted, unequivocally fatigued, and can not safely accept another flight assignment if called upon again.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: While the breadth of things that I feel should be considered are beyond the scope of whatever comments I leave here, I think common sense needs to prevail. Crew scheduling must take a rational approach to every trip or schedule it hands out. They need to look at the pilots most recent duty. In this case, adding the first short call assignment immediately following the overseas trip was imprudent. Adding the second was unreasonable. Moreover, it was dangerous. Its not enough to determine whether an "assignment" is legal or not. Safety must rule over all other factors.

category.name: Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Yesterday afternoon around 2:00pm I fell in the hallway near the bathrooms, and I landed on my wrists. My right arm feels and looks swollen and it hurts since yesterday afternoon. I am wearing a brace for the right wrist to help it feel better.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: I was walking and I just tripped and fell.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: IN THE OPERATIONS OFFICE MY ROLE WAS TO PROVIDE THE DISPATCHER COORDINATING THE DELAY WITH INFORMATION AND TO PREPARE THE FLIGHT PLANS AND RELEASE FOR THE AFFECTED FLIGHTS. I WAS INFORMED BY THE MAINTENANCE CONTROLLER ON DUTY THAT THE MEL ITEM ON N752MA RESTRICTED OPERATIONS TO VMC AND WITHIN CIVIL TWILIGHT. TO ASCERTAIN WHAT TIME WAS CIVIL TWILIGHT FOR BUFFALO I WENT TO THE MIAMI AIR DISPATCH HOME PAGE AND SELECTED UNDER CALCULATORS TABLES AND CODES THE SUNSET,SUNRISE & TWILIGHT CALCULATOR. THIS TOOK ME TO A PAGE WHERE IT APPEARED TO ME THAT THE LINK HAD EXPIRED. I CLICKED ON THE TAB THAT SAID "CLICK HERE TO PROCEED TO THE AVIATION CAMERA PROGRAM WEB SITE" JUST TO SEE WHERE IT WOULD TAKE ME. IT DIRECTED ME TO AVIATION CAMERAS HOME WERE I WAS ABLE TO SELECT THE SUNRISE/SUNSET CALCULATOR TAB. TO GET THE LAT/LONG FOR THE AFFECTED STATION BUFFALO (KBUF) I WENT TO THE NAVTECH PAGE 105 (AIRPORTS) TO GET THIS INFORMATION. I TRANSFERRED THE LAT/LONG TO THE SUNRISE/SUNSET/TWILIGHT CALCULATOR PAGE THEN SELECTED CALCULATE AND HANDED THE RESULT TO CATALINA DIAZ WHO INFORMED THE CAPTAIN OF THE CIVIL TWILIGHT TIME FOR BUFFALO. AFTER DEPARTURE WHICH WAS UNKNOWN UNTIL WE SAW IT ON THE FLIGHT TRACKER, WHILE I WAITED I HAPPEN TO LOOK AT THE CAMERA IN THE DISPATCH OFFICE AND SAW THAT IT WAS FAIRLY DARK OUTSIDE. THEN I SAW THE FLIGHT POPPED UP ON THE FLIGHT TRACKER WITH AN INITIAL ETA OF 0050Z FOR KBUF. I THEN GOT THE MEL AND SAW WHERE THERE WAS REFERENCE TO THE AMERICAN AIR ALMANAC, I ENTERED THIS IN GOOGLE AND IT BROUGHT ME TO A PAGE SUN OR MOON RISE/SET TABLE FOR ONE YEAR. I DECIDED TO USE JEPPESEN TO GET THE LAT/LONG FOR BUFFALO ONLY FOR COMPARISON. JEPPESEN GAVE ME A BETTER DISPLAY OF THE COORDINATES WHICH WHEN ENTERED INTO THE CALCULATOR IT GAVE ME A DIFFERENT CIVIL TWILIGHT TIME WHICH WAS NOW 44 MINUETS LESS THAN THE TIME GIVEN TO THE CAPTAIN SWEITZER BEFORE HE DEPARTED TORONTO FOR THE 17 MIN. FLIGHT.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
BSK8808 departed KJQF for KITH with forecast condition at landing minimums at the destination at the ETA.
Whilst en-route, dispatch monitored Metars and Specis for KITH and noted FG was not lifting.
Capt Lawson called via Arinc and advised that he was holding due to field conditions being below landing minimums.
Call was made to Alternate Station (KROC) advising of the possibility of a diversion.
Capt Lawson called back and with no change to the current field conditions, BSK8808 diverted to KROC and landed without any further incident.
Flight was fueled and arrived KITH with a delay of 2 hours 10 mins.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
The safety department received an anonymous hotline report specifying that one of the moveable aircraft stairs at the hangar is damaged. The joint of one of the wheels is cracked, which causes the whole stair to vibrate when being moved. The vibration from prolonged use will continue to worsen the crack.
Also, the platform does not go up or down--we are unable to adjust for the height difference between -400 and -800 model, which in turn may cause damage to the aircraft door on the -400. This also leaves a gap between the airplane and the stair on the -400 model.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: @ PBI, Miami Air ground support people (drivers) need to be trained and comply with FOM Ramp Operations procedures. The supply van pulled in between the air stairs and the #1 engine within 4' of the fuselage and 2' to 3' of the engine inlet.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Aircraft was struck by a belt loader damaging the #1 DME antenna with minor scratches. A verbal statement was received from Mr. Christopher Ash (airport manager & FBO operations). - The belt loader operator (Chris Brady) parked the belt loader to the forward cargo compartment - The belt loader engine was operating while not being attended when the baggage was being unloaded - A bag fell off of the belt loader pushing the shifter to "drive" casusing the belt loader to move forward damaging the #1 DME antenna No MAI employees witnessed the above events. Mr. Ash confirmed that video tapes are available to MAI in need be. No other security cameras are available. Mr. Brady was sent to be screened for drugs/alcohol. Mr. Ash has accepted full responsibility fro the incident.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: At 1820z left Terminal 3 Gate C31 to taxi A/C to Landmark per ground handling sheets. Contacted Landmark via radio (122.95) and were told they had no idea we were parking there today and the would have to call someone in to park us at the North Lounge. Taxied down taxiway K to end to wait for a marshaller. Waited on Taxiway K till around 1930Z and asked Landmark for an update. They said we could self park as close to the North Lounge as we were comfortable with on the North side of the ramp. Taxied to the north side of the ramp and made a right 90 degree turn to the west moving toward the north lounge. Checked clearance of left wing with GSE (air-stair trucks) through very glazed L3 window and began turning right to park. Diverted attention to the front of the A/C and the L wing struck the movable partition at the top of the 3 air-stair trucks. Looked out the L3 window and saw the L wing was in contact with the top of the third air-stair platform and immediately shut down A/C and set parking break.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: This event occurred because Landmark was not notified of our arrival by Ground Handling and Landmark did not have enough staff to provide a marshaller. Also, while attempting to self park, I misjudged the clearance of the left wingtip.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: It was determined that this event occurred by visually seeing the left wingtip in contact with the platform of the air-stair truck.

attribute.name: once_the_event_was_identified
attribute.value: Once the it was determined the event occurred, the A/C was shut down, the parking brake was set and the A/C stairs were lowered to assess the damage. Operations was called and I requested to speak to the duty officer.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: An event like this can be avoided by making the proper notifications to necessary parties and assuring that a marshaller is available. In this instant, the A/C should have been shut down, the mechanic let off the A/C to assure that the proper clearance was available operating on a tight ramp.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
I was scheduled for a 0415L show time on 5/18/13. Capt. Robinson and I were to operate MIA-LIR-IAH to be followed by a lengthy layover in IAH. Total duty was to be 950. At 1828L on 5/17/13 an updated itinerary from Sched. Tapias was sent indicating that in lieu of laying over in IAH, we would be ferrying back to MIA for a total scheduled block of 850 and a duty time of 1320. I saw this at approximately 2030L as I was getting ready for bed. I immediately contacted Capt. Robinson and asked if he would contact Crew Scheduling and request a crew augmentation due to the longer duty day and early show time. He agreed. I went to bed at about 2130L and the last time I looked at the clock it was about 2230L.
Sometime in the night, my phone rang. I got out of bed assuming it was my alarm. When I went to silence the alarm, I noticed that it was Crew Scheding, specifically, Sched. Pacheco. The time was 0158L. He told me that the a/c was broken and that I should not report as checked for my trip. He then stated that it might go at some point later. Thinking the delay would be minimal, I told him I would turn off my alarm and just wait to hear from him. I lay back down and tried to sleep. While at some point I did fall asleep, I continually woke up. I don't believe that for the rest of the night, until finally getting up at 0615L that I had more than 15 or 20 minutes of uninterrupted sleep followed by the same amount of time of being awake.
At 0752L on 5/18/13 an itinerary for a new trip was sent by Sched. Velasquez. This new trip had a show time of 1240L on 5/18/13 and the first duty day ended in ATL at 0130L on 5/19/13 for a total scheduled block of 850 and a duty time of 1330. Based on the fact that effectively I had been awake since approximately 0200L after receiving less than 4 hours of sleep, I realized that I would be unsafe to operate this trip. Not wanting to call in Fatigued, I decided to contact scheduling and inform them that I believed I'd been placed on this trip in error, as my original trip for which I was checked at 0415L was no longer operating and that Scheduling needed to use a pilot from the Short Call list. They refused.
I indicated to Sched. Velasquez that while I appreciated Sched. Pacheco's call to cancel my 0415L showtime and save me from leaving my house, it had interrupted my sleep cycle to the point that I had been unable to achieve any meaningful rest after that time. I again stated that I should be replaced with one of the pilots on the Short Call list as that is what it was for and as the shift supervisor, she had the authority to do so. She refused and instructed me to call Capt. Passwater.
At this point, I decided that there was no reason to speak to anyone else as I realized that the whole reason I didn't feel fit for the new trip was that I was fatigued. Speaking with anyone else wasn't going to change that and having remembered the numerous occasions when Capt. Kamrad has vociferously stated that "if pilot's are fatigued, they need to call out fatigued", I elected to do so.
I was fortunate that as I became more alert this morning, I could make a sound judgement call admitting that while I might be able to operate from MIA to LIR and potentially even onward to IAH, I would be in no position to continue beyond that safely. I recognize that a Fatigue Call can trigger schedule changes, and I am sorry for the inconvenience, but knowing that I could be replaced by a pilot available on the Short Call list for a new trip originating in MIA made the decision easier and allowed me to make the truly safe choice.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value:
When a trip sequence changes to the degree that the one above did, the first thing that a Crew Scheduler should look at is the Safety of the operation In order to be prepared for an early AM departure most crews will try to adjust their sleep cycle. Changing that departure can result in the crew member not being fit for the new duty period. Schedulers must recognize this and consider all the options available to ensure that the crew that will operate a trip sequence is the safest, most rested they can muster.
Consequentially, one of the first questions that should then be asked of the crew member when trying to assign a new trip sequence after interrupting rest is whether or not they are rested and able to safely operate the next duty sequence in it's entirety. Trying to force a trip change on a crew member, particularly after they have noted that their rest was compromised when other crew members are available is not only inappropriate, but also unsafe.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Reported to duty at 8:40 pm Local (7th). Flew two flights and released at 3:35 am Local (8th). Had to winterize and secure the a/c. Checked into the hotel at approximately 4:15 am Local (8th). Scheduled next report time was 4:30 pm Local (8th). The 4:30 pm Local report time was cancelled due to the commercial flight out of SCE being cancelled. We were told to "standby" for an update. At approximately 7:30 pm Local (8th) we were advised of a new report time of 3:15 am Local (9th). After a report time change from 4:30 pm Local to 3:15 am Local, we took a three hour limo to Pittsburgh (PIT). The limo was followed by a 2 hr 15 min sit to commercial to Atlanta (ATL). The first commercial was scheduled to be followed by a 3 hr 34 min sit to commercial to Miami (MIA). My sleep schedule was severely interrupted by having a 2:30 am Local wake up call to transport back to Miami after being up until 5:00 am Local the night before for work.
I was able to sleep about seven hours from 5:00 am Local (8th) till noon. I was unable to sleep (except a fast nap on the two short commercial flights) from Noon (8th) until being released in Miami (9th), a period over 26 hours long.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Take into account the rest schedules for crews. Try to limit the flip flop of schedules when possible. It is very difficult to schedule rest when last minute changes are made involving Limos and Commercials.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: I woke up at 8:30 zulu (3:30 L) after being able to get about four hours of sleep. Scheduled to report at 9:30 zulu (4:30 L) at Miami. Scheduled to LIMO to FLL at 9:30 zulu (4:30 L), arrive at 10:30 zulu (5:30 L). Scheduled to commercial on US Air at 12:00 zulu (7:00 L) to DCA, arriving into DCA at 14:28 zulu (9:28 L). Scheduled to commercial from DCA at 18:05 zulu (13:05 L), arriving into CMH at 19:33 zulu (14:33 L). Scheduled to LIMO to hotel for a layover near LCK with a 20:33 zulu (15:33 L) arrival. Scheduled to layover for 14:17 in LCK for a 10:50 zulu (5:50 L) report time the next morning to operate LCK-YYZ-MIA. Once arriving into CMH, crew scheduling advised that we would drop off the flight attendants at the hotel in LCK and the pilots would continue to the airport (LCK) to operate an aircraft from LCK-MIA. Since there had been no live flights, it was considered Part 91 and no 117 rules applied to the pilots. We waited on a mechanical delay before departing from LCK and arrived/blocked into MIA at 00:55 zulu (7:55 L), and were released at 01:25 zulu (8:25 L). A 15 hour and 55 minute duty day that started in the middle of the night, with two LIMOs, two oversold commercial flights (one of which had a medical emergency), a lot of waiting around in terminals and FBOs, five airports (MIA-FLL-DCA-CMH-LCK-MIA) and a ferry flight on a Miami Air aircraft.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: If 117 had applied to this duty day, the crew would have had a maximum duty period of 10 hours. (5 hours and 55 minutes less). I recommend that when giving a crew a report time in the middle of the night (4:30 am local) with limos and commercials all over the place, the crew not then be expected or required to fly an aircraft. The crew was assigned to operate the aircraft after already being on duty for over twelve hours. A last minute change like this provides no ability for the crew to attempt to properly rest for such a day. More direct commercials (reducing the stress and fatigue on pilots and reducing the time spent going from airport to airport to airport) would keep crews fresher and provide more flexibility for the company to make changes when they are required without crews becoming fatigued. (Example: SouthWest 2645 departs FLL at 11:35 Local arrives into CMH at 14:20 Local. This commercial as an example would have had a report time of 9:05 Local. This would have provided a better sleep schedule for the pilots and reduced the duty time for the day). Until travel (and crew scheduling) begins to consider and look into pilot fatigue and report times in the middle of the night instead of just going with the transportation need that is five dollars cheaper, pilots will continue to be placed into duty days that result in fatigue. Waiting until the day prior to look for transportation means many options are not available. Waiting until 00:00 zulu (19:00 Local) to confirm/pay for the commercial for the next morning reduces the available seats for crew members to select from often resulting in only middle seats being available which are not comfortable or easily used for resting. Just because it's legal does not mean it is not fatiguing.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
I was acclimated to Amsterdam, The Netherlands after completing a TDY/trip in AMS for approximately six weeks (departed Miami for Amsterdam on July 29th, 2014). I conducted numerous trips from Amsterdam during the TDY throughout Europe.
On September 05th, 2014 I was checked in and reported for an assignment in Amsterdam, The Netherlands (AMS) at 10:45am local. (The transportation from the hotel to the airport left at 10:00am local). Assignment was a Part 91 operation: deadhead from Amsterdam (AMS) to Gander (YQX) to Portsmouth (PSM). Flight times for the two deadhead flights were 5:45 and 2:30 respectively with one hour on the ground in Gander. Upon arrival in PSM I would be the operating pilot (PM) for a flight from PSM to MIA, scheduled at 3:20 block. Our arrival time in Miami was 7:20pm local, we were released from duty at 7:50pm local. Scheduled duty day was 15:50. Miami had a six hour time difference from Amsterdam. The company (crew scheduling) contacted me at approximately 8:33pm local on Sept 5th and placed me on a thirty-six (36) hour break starting at 9:00 pm local. The company said this would acclimate me to the time zone again (Miami) and additional rest was not required as per their interpretation of the FAR 117 even though I had been more than 4 times zones away during a serious of FDPs for more than 168 hours. The company states that the required 56 hours of rest including three consecutive nights was not applicable.
My company assigned rest period began at 9:00 pm local on Friday, Sept 5th and would end on Sunday, Sept 7th at 9:00 am local. This was intended to be an uninterrupted 36 hour rest period free from all duties.
The company (crew scheduling) made multiple phone calls to my primary contact number during my assigned rest period.
First phone call was received on Saturday (6th) at 6:56 pm local. Second phone call was received on Saturday (6th) at 9:44 pm local. Third phone call was received on Sunday (7th) at 5:28 am local.
Each phone call was unanswered and the company left a voicemail after each call instructing me to contact the company/crew scheduling. The company assigned a duty during an assigned "rest period" which is supposed to be "free from all duty". (Duty assigned was to contact the company for a trip assignment and receive details about the trip).
The first phone call's voice mail stated: "...contact scheduling, we need to check you in..." The second phone call's voice mail stated: "...give us a call back". The third phone call's voice mail stated: "...give us a call back".
The clear intent of every phone call's voice mail was for me to return the call and perform the required actions to be checked in for a duty assignment.
The multiple phone calls that were received during the assigned rest period, as well as the voice mails interrupted my rest. I contacted the company (crew scheduling), still during my assigned rest period, and advised them that due to their continuos phone calls and attempts to contact me, my rest had been interrupted. I was advised by the scheduler that since I had not answered the phone calls, the company did not recognize the phone calls as an interruption of rest. The company also stated that they had a good reason to attempt to call me, they were attempting to reach me so that I could be checked-in for my flight that was scheduled to depart on September 7th. The company advised they would look into this and contact me with further instructions once the lead scheduler had been spoken to.
The company attempted to call me shortly later (approximately 9:07 am local) but the phone call did not connect properly. I called the company back and spoke to the lead scheduler (approximately at 9:07 am local) and she advised me that the company only provided additional rest if a "ten hour period" before an FDP was interrupted. This assigned rest period (36 hour rest period) did not meet that and therefore they would not take any action. I asked t be placed on a new rest period free from all duty and un-interrupted. The response was that they don't do that and there was nothing that the company would do in this situation. I was informed that if I disagreed with the lack of action from the company, my option was to contact my supervisor or my Union representative. Additionally, they were assigning me to a Short Call assignment starting at 11:00 pm local on Sept 7th. I informed the scheduler that I had not received uninterrupted rest as required by FAR 117 and had notified the company as required that morning (still during my 36 hour rest period). Therefore, since my last uninterrupted 30 hour rest period was on September 01, 2014, I was unable to accept any FAR 117 FDP assignments until such time that I received a true uninterrupted 30 hour rest period as required (pilot must receive a 30 hour break within the last 168 hours in order to accept an assignment). The company once again advised me that there was nothing that they could do and they did not deem the rest period to be interrupted and I would have to contact my supervisor or Union official and they would show me checked in for my next Short call assignment as scheduled. During this conversation, a different scheduler also contacted me and left a voice mail that was to inform me that I was being checked-in for a short call assignment.
I respectfully once again advised the scheduler that as per FAR 117 I would not be able to accept an assignment until such time I received the required rest and would not be fit for duty. The company violated their responsibility to ensure I received uninterrupted rest, and as a result I endured a disruption in my rest.
After speaking to the company/lead crew scheduler, I submitted an email to the Chief Pilot (Captain John Passwater) and the Director of Scheduling (Mr Scott Karol) outlining the issue I had encountered with a request to correct this situation. As of the writing of this report, I have not received a response from either.
I understand that the company currently shows me as having completed a 36 hour rest period and as being checked in for my next Short Call assignment even though I have advised them that their actions and multiple attempts to contact/call me interrupted my rest period and caused additional fatigue. I did not receive the required rest that I was checked in for.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value:
FAR 117 clearly states that a rest period should be uninterrupted and free from all duty. The company should not make attempts to contact a crew member (via telephone, text, email, etc) during this rest period. The company has no regard for the rest period and when advised of the fatigue issue has no regard to correct the situation. Should the company break this rest period, and be advised by the crew member that there was an interruption of rest, the company should reassign the crew member to a rest period to provide the required uninterrupted rest period as required by FAR 117.
FAR 117 is clear that the company cannot assign duties or contact the crew members during rest periods. The company should review FAR 117 and provide additional training to crew schedulers to ensure that the requirements of FAR 117 are met and followed.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
We were completing our preflight duties on the flight deck for BSK 8619, JQF-MDW on 9-11-14. I looked out the right side window and saw several passengers cross over the Jersey Barriers separating the car parking area from the sterile area on their way to the screening building. Effectively, they elected to take the shortest route to the screening building and in so doing, entered the sterile area around the aircraft prior to having their ID's verified or being screened. I was however, able to maintain visual contact with them and ensured that they did not approach the aircraft as they passed through this area.
Once they were clear, I exited the flight deck and approached the GSC to discuss it with him. He brought me to the gentleman in the screening building and I spoke to him about it. I told them both that it was not acceptable for passengers that had not yet been screened to be entering the sterile area and that it was also not appropriate for any passenger to be in any location around the aircraft while unaccompanied unless they were approaching the air stairs to board. I was told that this had happened in the past and that the passengers had been told to walk to the screening building outside of the sterile areas but that occasionally some still tried to take the shortest route.
I let them both know that we did not feel this was acceptable and that better attention needed to be paid to prevent this happening in future. I also told then that I would be following up with Miami Air. Capt. Curtis left a message for Theresa Singleton about this and he and I spoke to her on Saturday, 9-12-14 at which point she requested a follow up through the company reporting system.
I would like to note, though, that after speaking to the GSC, I did see him redirect a passenger that attempted to enter the sterile area prior to being screened.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Shortly after initiating descent, cabin crew notified us that a passenger (Clinton Warnock) was not feeling well and that oxygen was being administered. Passenger was being attended to by EMT's onboard (Honor Flight). Notified arrival handler and approach control to have additional medics meet the aircraft at gate B4.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: @ LAN, Fuel truck initially parked under the wing.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Please see the attached airfield diagram and picture indicating the deteriorating ramp in BNA on which a ground handler attempted to park our aircraft. Football season always takes to small airports often with questionable, congested ramps. Please beware.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: From looking at the pictures, it would appear that the ramp is this way due to weather, wear and tear.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
The safety department received an anonymous report through the safety hotline on September 29th, 2014. Below a transcription of the message left by the individual:
"753MA â€“ Aircraft is outside, No safety belt around in order to secure
752MA â€“ Aircraft in hanger, was left without belt attached. Safety belt secured by an employee
[I choose to report this] anonymous as I believe contractors are tired of me asking them to put warning belt at door when doors are left open.
Side Note: Miami Air Employeeâ€™s are usually good at securing these when working on aircraft. 99% of the time itâ€™s the contractors who leave them unsecured."

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Mechanic Lucus told me in PHl that two noses would be in KSHD.and needed to be changed due to cord showing. I called MC who told me it's ok until the second cord shows which was not the case. I told him too hold off and wait until we got to SHD and see if we had time. We arrived early, I asked if they were already inflated which they were. The wind was blowing up to 20 kts and asked him if this was a good idea with that strong a wind. His reply "no problem.". I SUGGESTED we do it in BGR were we ended up for 20plus hour layover and I told him I would help him With the aircraft jacked up,both tires deflated, and the right nose off as he was putting the new right nose on wind blew and moved the A/C because it wasn't chocked right. At no time did he check that the aircraft was chocked properly The jack shifted to a 20 degree angle wedged against the left nose. The jack was wedged against the tire on one corner of the jack.We were lucky it didn't come totally off the jack, hurt him and end up with the left deflated Â tire resting on the jack. The Right nose stayed on and he tightened the lock nut. Now he wanted a tow bar. At that time I stepped in an made him lower the jack which came down wedged on the rim of the left nose tire. Now the a/c was resting on the right nose tire with the jack wedged on the left nose tire rime. He took the nut off the left tire and hammered the tire until it came of and freed the jack. Jacked the nose gear up and put the new left nose on. Ron Edmonds witnessed this also. We were lucky. Mr Lucas doesn't listen to anyone,he's not a team player, and does what he wants.Reality he rushed because he didn't want to change the tire in BGR or come out the next day. So he rushed and as he said that was close it scared me. He all most hurt himself or could have cost Miami Air a lot of money.

category.name: Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Upon returning from lunch on 10/07/14, Millie (Pan Am Front Desk) asked if I could help her with a problem they were having. She stated several Miami Air Employees were smoking in non-designated areas, including the 2nd and 3rd floor balconies (in the stair wells) and the metal door behind the Pan Am Front Desk. She stated the employees were propping the doors open and, standing just outside of them, smoking. She stated that she had asked the employees several times to quit and had posted a no-smoking sign on the 1st floor door in an effort to resolve the issue. She also stated that the smell is carrying thru the open door and into the building. I have noticed the smoke smell several times as well. Human Resources Department has sent several messages to Miami Air employees stressing the importance of not propping the doors open and the rules on smoking in designated areas only. Millie has asked us to do something about the continued problem.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: My opinion: The event continues to occur because the employees are either trying to hide their smoking or the amount of smoke breaks taken, or they do not want to walk to the front of the building each time they need a cigarette.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On October 24th, 2014, Cpt. Neborski reported a bird strike while descending into Offutt Air Force Base in Omaha, Nebraska. Cpt. Neborski reported that it looked like three(3) minor hits on the wing and Engine No. 2 from small birds. According to the Captain, there was no effect on the flight. The bird species is unknown. FAA Form 5200-7 has been filed.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Mechanic Lucas Flight 681 MAO EZE I came out to fly this leg. Aircraft came from PAP with Lucas as the mechanic. As I reviewed the log book a fuel audit had already been filled out on my blank page as being accomplished. How do you do a fuel audit if your in the van going to the hotel? Â Even better I fueled the aircraft and signed the fuel slip. Â Aircraft 733. Log page 243751. So he falsified the log page by saying he did a fuel audit for my flight that I fueled while he was in the van going to the hotel. If he falsifies basic fuel audits, what does he sign off in the log book as a mechanic that he does not accomplish?

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Rejected takeoff KEWR RWY22L due to no N1 spool up (#2 engine) during a rolling takeoff. On taxiway advanced thrust level on #2 engine verifying no N1 spool up with no auto-throttle. The pervious segment had a write-up referring to an auto-throttle issue. The N1 remained at idle 20-23%. Therefore, we returned to the ramp terminating the flight.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: No N1 spool up (#2 engine) above idle.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: While on extended delay (due to Pax not arriving on time), took a walk around the hanger and ramp to assess conditions. Noted the following findings: 1) Fire Extinguisher and Fire Hose in SW corner of hanger partially blocked to prevent rapid access (see photo #1). 2) Ramp in need of sweeping, lots of FOD. 3) There should be a setback line on the East side of the ramp to deliniate limits of equipment storage for safe A/C clearance. 4) The fuel oil cart parked on the ramp does not have a fire extinguished attached to it for imediate use in the event of a fueling incident. 5) Area directly outside of the SE corner of the hanger needs policing. Palets and other scrap is piled up creating possible hazard and just looks bad (see photo #2).

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: This is not an actual event, just observations with no Ground Safety Report form available to use to report findings.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: No event, just observations reported to prevent an event.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Regular walkthru inspections, scheduled ramp sweeping.

MX control was
Kurt Kamrad and Armando Martinez was notified.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Statement from Stacy Lebrija after speaking with Captain Peters regarding Mr. Bruzzone's injury: "Captain Peters just called to report that Flight Mechanic Fabian Bruzzone has broken his wrist and will not be able to depart on Panther's FLT 394/21 departing SJC in 45 min. Medical assistance requested through the Handler."
Statement from Mx Controller John Detrick regarding Mr. Bruzzone's injury: "[Fabian] was helping to load items in the FWD cargo bin and fell off the belt loader. He attempted to break his fall by putting his hand down and broke his wrist. He was taken to O'Connor hospital in San Jose via ambulance. As of 14:15 EST, Fabian was at the hospital waiting to be seen by a doctor."

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Mechanic Fabian Bruzzone sustained an injury to his wrist. While climbing down from the belt loader, he slipped and broke his fall against the belt loader with his right hand. Due to the immediate swelling and pain he suspected a broken wrist. Atlantic Aviation immediately called the Airport Fire Rescue and paramedics arrived about 5 minutes after the incident. He was transported by ambulance to Conner Hospital which is close to San Jose Airport.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: During preflight loading of the aircraft the mechanic slipped and fell.

attribute.name: observation_comments

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
The following is a statement from an employee who wishes to remain anonymous. This employee approached the Sr. Director of Safety and Security on Thursday, November 20th, 2014 with a concern.
"The work environment is continually being interrupted by loud, heated conversations between Joe Roche and Curtis Gravett. Every morning, Curtis comes to the office to "check-in" with Joe and most mornings they end up in a heated conversation with each other. This morning, Curtis came in the office and Joe had not come in yet. Walter asked Curtis a question about the work being completed in the hangar and Curtis stated he had not been to the hangar yet. Walter was upset with the answer given and said he would take care of this and left. Several minutes later, Joe came in and accused Curtis of "throwing him under the bus." Curtis replied that he had only answered the question asked of him. Once again both Joe and Curtis became loud and abusive in their conversation. I heard what was asked by Walter and the answer Curtis gave and Curtis, in my opinion, said nothing out of line. After several minutes of loud conversation with accusations and sarcasm from both, Curtis left. During this argument no one in the office was working. They were all focused on the conversation. I think this has gone on long enough and something needs to be done. "

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: The two persons mentioned do not seem to get along.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
On October 28th, 2014 Miami Air properly shipped three APU fire bottles to BizJet International Sale and Support, a repair station in Tulsa, OK so that they could be installed on one of our aircraft. The facility installed the three units we sent and used the same shipping box to return the three APU fire bottles removed from the aircraft. The previous hazmat labels were covered with a fragile sticker and the paperwork did not reflect that this was a hazmat shipment. The repair station shipped hazmat items to Miami Air without the proper paperwork and labeling. Friday, December 12, 2014, at 10:30 am EST, Armando Martinez, MAI's Sr. Director of Safety and Security, who is also MAI's Ethics Compliance Officer, received a call from Mr. Joseph Bernard, a Miami Air Stockroom employee, who had just received a parts shipment (APU fire bottles), notifying him of an apparent Hazmat shipping violation.
Mr. Martinez immediately went to the stockroom, took pictures of two improperly labeled boxes and gathered a copy of the paperwork that Miami Air used for shipping the original three APU fire bottles. While he was examining the two boxes, a third improperly labeled box arrived. When the first box was examined, it was noticed that the squibs had been removed.
At 11:50am EST, Mr. Martinez called Ms. Deborah Kennedy at the Southern Region Office in Atlanta, GA to report this event.
In addition to this email, FAA form 5800.1 was submitted via web. Tracking #606975, Report # E-2014120259.
Additional supporting documentation and pictures are attached.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: While at a cruising altitude of 37,000 ft we received a TCAS Fail indication on both of the PFD's. After mutable attempts of changing between the transponders, I notified ATC we had a failure of are TCAS system. They issued a decent clearance to FL 270 to depart RVSM airspace. I notified the company via Airink of the mechanical failure, the new assigned altitude, expected fuel burn and are en-route estimate of fuel on board when landing at IAD. A coordinated decision was made between the flight crew, dispatch and MOC that the flight could be completed safely to the planed destination.

ALLEGIANTAIR INFORMED AND ARRANGEMENTS WERE MADE TO ACCOMMODATE LANDING AT PIE. ALLEGIANT AIR ARRANGED TRANSPORTATION FOR PASSENGERS BY ROAD TO PGD

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On July 14, 2014 at 0130Z, N732MA (BSK514 FERRY FLIGHT) was involved in a fuel spill while fueling at LANDMARK AVIATION in San Diego, California. Fueler Manny from LANDMARK AVIATION (very experienced on 737 fueling procedures) came up and advised me that fuel from the main tank #1 (left wing) overflowed and exited the aircraft via left fuel vent onto the ramp. As I exited the aircraft, I noticed the 15X15 fuel puddle under the left wingtip/fuel vent. Fueling was suspended, and LANDMARK AVIATION proceeded to clean up the spill with their solid chemical solution. As cleaning was taking place, I proceeded to the fueling station to asses the fueling problem. As the Fueler resumed fueling the center tank with main tanks valves CLOSED, the #1 main tank was taking fuel. This was a clear indication that the #1 main tank valve failed open, therefore, no auto shutdown feature would be available allowing fuel to overflow and spill over. (I do have video of the tank Receiving fuel with valve switch in the CLOSED position) In order to accomplished fueling, fuel was transferred from main tank with failed valve in order to fuel the remaining tanks without a subsequent spill. Fueling was successfully accomplished and aircraft and crew departed San Diego to Miami. Supervisor advised me that LANDMARK AVIATION will DIRECT BILL Miami Air for clean up efforts from the incident. item was noted in logbook to avoid subsequent spills from N732MA.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: During push back the person on the headset failed to tell me that she was disconnecting the tug. She did not say set brakes or that she was disconnecting the headset. The tug visually looked like it was pulling the plane forward. The aircraft was rolling forward with it. I saw the woman off to the left side with the pin and handset in hand. At that moment I stood on the brakes. Report from Capt. Rhatigan.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Just prior to V1 a bird flew into the #2 engine. Lifted off engine started to sputter. I noticed a High VIB on the engine vibration gauge. Called for engine vib QRH checklist. Retarded the #2 throttle to idle. Completed all checklist. Landed back in KNGU.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On the morning of 02-19-16 I was working aircraft N738MA. The fueler arrived and was waiting for me to come down and move the work stand. It was positioned in front of the right wing tip so he could not pull up into fueling position. I moved the work stand under the wing and watched the driver approach the aircraft. I observed him driving too close to the wing and gave him a hand signal to turn away from the aircraft. I looked at him and he shook his head no. At that point I made an emphatic hand gesture, motioning him away from the wing, at which point he did. In over 30 years of working around aircraft, I have never had anyone attempt to or defy a directive while marshaling them around an aircraft. This was a first. I am not happy about this. I gave this driver a directive to move away from the aircraft and he tells me no. This is a serious safety issue. This is very disconcerting that a driver would deliberately defy my direction and jeopardize my safety as well as those around me. Not to mention the potential damage to my aircraft.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

I opened the oven and discharged the fire extinguisher that was located in the file room and unplugged the toaster oven. All of this was done with assistance from Lizette Hernandez."
