attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
During the arrival into KLAF, we received a RA-climb command. We had received a clearance from GRISSOM Approach to descend to 3,000'. We were approximately 8 miles northwest of the airport. GRISSOM pointed out the position of the airport, and we requested a visual for a right downwind RWY28. Approach cleared us for a visual RWY28 and to contact Lafayette tower. Lafayette tower advised us of VFR traffic at 2500',12 o'clock. At that time we were at +/-4000' descending when we received a RA-climb. Additional VFR traffic was at 3500', we climbed to 4200' having traffic insight leveled off. Told the tower we had a RA. We continued the approach and landed at Lafayette with no additional incident.
I called the tower via cell phone to discuss the RA. I was informed they do not have radar. Therefore, heighten awareness while flying into class D, non-radar towers is crucial.

HE CALLED THE BASE OPS AND THEY TOLD HIM THE CAT 2 ILS HAD JUST GONE DOWN AND A C-17 HAD DIVERTED TO SEA. CALLED CREW TO REPORT. ATIS STILL NOT REPORTING ILS FAILURE. GAVE SEA WX ABOVE LANDING MINS. attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: A/C delayed departure to arrive after 0800Z due to TAF showing below mins until 0800Z. When a/c came in range wx was reporting below mins and a/c went into the hold (the forecast changed after departure). A/C had additional fuel to hold so there was no issues with fuel. After consulting with Kurt and seeing the METAR had gone from 1/4 SM to 1/8 SM, dispatcher, pilot and Kurt all agreed to divert to RDU and wait until the fog lifted and the a/c could legally return to NGU.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: Catering at MIA, was advised by Purser that meals were dropped off, but no supplies (2043L). Called company, they said that they would call caterer. Received call from Dispatch at 2050L saying that the A/C was re-stocked yesterday. Advised them that the A/C made 4 live legs since then and that the Purser needed the A/C re-stocked. At 2102L Dispatch said MAI catering was on the way, to wait and take the delay. Called at 2122L an 2132L and was told caterer on the way. They arrived at 2139L. Comments from Capt. Lewis.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: A/C had diverted to RDU due to WX below mins at NGU. I was looking at the weather and how soon we could get in and missed an airport notam for a closure. I sent the paperwork during the turnover and briefed Geoff about the WX conditions and the possibility the weather would not come up at the forecast time. (I had spoken to an EWINS meteorologist about the NGU taf). Geoff had a lot of flights to dispatch at 1500Z and he had to work on them as well as monitor the weather for the departure.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
BSK3260/TFL260 CHQ-KGS FLT TOOK OFF 40 MIN FLT-
RECEIVED CALL FROM A/C HOLDING DUE TO LOW VISIBILITY AT DESTINATION AIRPORT(KGS)
A/C HELD FOR 20 MIN LOW ON FUEL-A/C RETURNED TO (CHQ) (DIVERTED)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: AIRCRAFT N733MA WAS DISPATCHED TO RESCUE PASSENGERS OFF N753MA IF THAT AIRCRAFT WAS DETERMINED AOG. WHILE N733MA WAS ENROUTE TO TUL THERE STILL EXIST THE POSSIBILITY OF DIVERTING TO YYZ IF N753MA BECAME SERVICEABLE. AFTER THE WINDOW OF OPPORTUNITY TO DIVERT TO YYZ HAD PASSED, N733MA WAS NOW DIVERTED TO DESTINATION TO MEM INSTEAD OF TUL, SINCE N753MA NOW DIVERTED TO MEM.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: Flight 549/01AUG NGU-JQF. Scheduled departure time 1350Z. Quiet hours: 1330Z-1600Z. NGU was scheduled for quiet hours 20 minutes before our scheduled departure time. Comments from Capt. Neborski. We could have been stuck there until 1600Z if Capt. Neborski had not been able to depart early and it would have affected our live leg behind.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: Flight 633/29JUL TER-IAD. Catering arrived at A/C without water and A/C had none on board. Ready to go at 2220Z but caterer had to leave airport to go to a store to purchase water. Took an additional 50 min delay. Comments from Capt. Lewis.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: Flight LL293/31AUG VQQ-NGU. Non military fuel @ VQQ. Shell has contract. Need to do a fuel audit. Comments from Capt. Neborski.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: Flight 1403/26JUL STI-MIA A/C N753MA. Jeppesen library needs to be reviewed. Many revisions either missing or not signed off. Comments for Capt Rhatigan / F/O Sosa.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Parties involved include the Senior dispatcher Alaric Brown, Catalina Diaz, and Mike Shin. The event occurred over KADW just after the turnover, so around 3:15 pm Pilots involved was Capt Wayne Smith with Aircraft 753MA
Per request of Senior Dispatcher on duty, I was given the task of filling out the WBAT. The flight follower program that we dispatchers usually use was down. Morning shift emailed the MIS person on duty but was not able to get any action. I later then called the MIS duty person for another computer reason (my programs were not installed on the back computer which made it hard to function) and asked him if there was anything they could do but to no avail. We were doing our duty monitoring the flights as best we could. Everything seemed ok as flights were dispatched with legal wx. About 15 min after the turnover between morning and afternoon shift, we got a call from Capt Wayne that he landed in PIT and needed the information for Atlantic Aviation as he diverted to PIT due to wx over ADW. He held over ADW as much as he could but had to divert to PIT before his fuel became critical. He was on the 400 so he did not have a Satphone to communicate with us readily

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: Flight 672/31JUL CHS-YQX-EDI. The aircraft was not loaded correctly @ CHS by Delta ground crew. I had to unload the A/C and reload per Miami Air procedure. Comment by AJ DIAZ.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: @ CLT, Wilson Air "over serviced" the Lavs.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On departure out of KJQF, Capt Simons phoned in VIA SatPhone advising that he was Air-Returning back to KJQF. He request maintenance to meet him upon arrival. To my knowledge the captain did not declare an emergency. Message was passed on to Maintenance Control and they contacted the mechanic in JQF and advised him that the aircraft was returning from the air and to meet it on arrival.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: I was called at 11:45z by ArkeFly flight attendant telling me that PR Brown has found a lady unconscious in seat 16C. He will call me back as soon as they assess the situation. At 11:55z he called me back and said they have 2 nurses taking care of the lady and requested permission to open the first aide and medical kit. I said "yes" and let me know what the nurses find out. Shortly after that he called again saying the lady was 52 years old and had low blood pressure 90/60, they had started her on O2. At that time PR Brown requested to enter the flight deck. She said the lady's blood pressure is now 110/70 and her blood sugar was 7.0. I asked if the nurses thought is was necessary to land as soon as possible. At that time we only had 0:40-45min. left to AMS. We declared a medical emergency and continued to AMS. Believing that would be the quickest time to get medical treatment for the passenger. We arrived at gate G07 in AMS at 12:45z with the paramedics waiting for us.

attribute.name: equipment_malfunction
attribute.value: Garlock seal on Fuel Pump Package, Number 1 engine, aircraft 732

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: 08-14-15 began with an1100Z flight from JQF. A 0900Z show time. JQF-CMH-AEX-ALO, arrived in ALO at 1920Z. Sat in ALO for 4 hours then ferried 733 to ANC to replace 732. Arrived in ANC at 0540Z. A 20 hour 40 minute day. We got to the hotel and I was finally able to sleep. After 6:30 of sleep, I received a phone call from Maintenance Control, 1325Z or 0525L, "Luis Berrios is on his flight from ORD-ANC, get out and start taking 732 apart so we can get this plane fixed". I got up, dressed, packed up and went down and had breakfast. I checked out of the hotel and went out to repair 732. Luis and I got the plane fixed and ready for a 0300Z, 2100L departure. 15 hours and 35 minutes after my wake up. At approximately 1300L it started to rain. It rained off and on for the rest of the day. After the repair was complete and an engine run for a leak check, the cowlings had to be closed. I laid under the engine to close the C-Cowls and main engine cowling. Now I'm soaking wet from head to toe on my back. Wet ramp. We closed up everything, put the tools away, returned borrowed tools to Pegasus Aviation and I boarded the plane for a Ferry to YIP. I changed my clothes in flight. A 6.5 hour flight from ANC-YIP, 1210Z arrival. I secured 732 and went to hotel. A 22 hour and 45 minute day. On arrival at the hotel on Sunday, 08-16-15, I was told that our reservations were for 08-15-15 and since we did not check in, our reservations were cancelled. The Crew rooms were re-booked, but mine was not. Since mine was not, I had no room. I had to wait for a room to be available and cleaned before I could get a room. 2 hours later I got a room. 3 hours of sleep and I'm back out on 732 to do a PT before we go to JQF. A scheduled 2230Z departure. We were late. We left at 0030Z, 08-17-05. On arrival in JQF, I called the hotel and find out that my reservation was for 08-16-15. Cancelled again. I called Crew Scheduling and they re-booked my room at the Hyatt Place CLT. So I limo'd to the hotel. I arrived at 0000L. After 2 hours of sleep, I woke up for my commercial home. I tried to check in on-line. There is a problem, I must call the airline, Delta. Once again my flight reservation was for 08-16-15, not 08-17. It was cancelled. I had to pay a $50.00 re-booking fee. My flight was re-booked and I was on my way home.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: @ EWR, no belt loader until 25 minutes after scheduled block out. Equipment truck had been at the aircraft for almost 40 minutes before belt loader arrived. Also lack of staff. Customer (Penguins) not happy at all. 45 minutes delay code 39.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: A little girl was fainting in the cabin, we were at approximately 7000 feet and talking to approach control when the purser informed me of the situation. There was not time to make a determination as to how serious the condition was. We informed the approach controller and requested that paramedics met the airplane on arrival as a precautionary measure. After arrival at the gate, the Paramedics came on board and after a short examination determined that she was OK.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: The little girl turned out to have a minor ear infection.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: While closing the L-1 door the purser said the door is very hard to close. I went back to cycle/open&close the L-1 door twice. I closed the door, it appeared to be closed correctly- no gaps closed easily. The flight deck door light extinguished. We took off from RWY02 cleared to 8,000'. At 4,000' the "after take-off checklist" was accomplished, noticing the cabin climbing +1,200 fpm. We received additional climb clearance to 16,000'. The cabin was still climbing +1,200fpm, we leveled off at 10,600'. I called the purser and asked if the L-1 door was leaking. She replied it was noisy. I asked her to open the flight deck door, the L-1 door was unusually loud. Therefore we returned to JQF. Landed on RWY20 and taxied to the ramp. The L-1 door was jammed, unable to be opened. Logbook entry was made and maintenance notified.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: Flight LL617/22SEP CCS-MID A/C N738MA. Only ground services set up in MID. No de-catering/catering. Unable to have trash removed, unable to have meals rotated up from pit. Unable to obtain ice for next leg. Zero support from catering department. Comments by Capt. Heller.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: Flight LL376/24SEP BTR-SYR A/C N739MA. 50 minutes delay caused by catering. Late arrival to airplane at gate, then only dropped off the food in the jetway. Could not get approved for F/A's to cater so Delta ground handlers catered the airplane. Also caterer shorted us on passengers meals, only 158 for 166 pax. Used crew meals for passengers. Comments by Capt. Sereix.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: Flight LL570/19SEP JQF-MDW A/C N733MA. Did not notify crew of late aircraft arrival. Both Dispatch and Scheduling knew about delay. Also had to call Duty Officer to get travel to extend hotel rooms for late check out. Captain had to find rooms and arrange transportation in JQF. Not done by travel. Comments from Capt. Sweitzer.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: At 85 KIAS on Takeoff roll received a Takeoff configuration aural warning with the LE FLAP TRANSIT light flashing on and off.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: At 85 KIAS on Takeoff roll received a Takeoff configuration aural warning with the LE FLAP TRANSIT light flashing on and off.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: On descent into LUK a passenger passed out in the forward galley. Our flight attendants tried to administer oxygen at that time he awakened and refused. Airport Medical staff and equipment was requested. Upon arrival the passenger received first aid and taken to the hospital via an ambulance. An emergency was not declared.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: It occurred because the passenger's sugar levels were too high.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: The A/C was blocked by 738 & 739 to the point it could not be catered or fueled. 738 left 45 minutes late which delayed our catering, fueling and baggage loading. Had to ride the brakes to move 739 so we could begin servicing as crew for 738 was not scheduled to show until 0830L. Also aircraft parked too close to obstruction. A fuel vent from the fuel farm where we were parked was within 1' of the right wing.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: Due to congestion at Landmark south we were advised to park at Landmark north. Ramp cleaner (no FOD) in comparison to Landmark south, however entrance to Landmark north is extremely narrow with no room to over steer. Taxi lights are in very close proximity to narrow taxiway resulting in reduced clearance between engines and lights. Also only taxiways C, B and half of A + runway 21L/3R are approved surfaces for B737 ops. Please advise crews on restrictions and caution on limited/restricted taxi space + FOD.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: Landmark Aviation South ramp @ LUK has FOD on ramp. Tim of Landmark Aviation was notified along with Chief Pilot Miguel Martin.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: Fueler at BIF arrived at 0740L for a take-off scheduled at 0800L. Called for fuel 2 hours prior to departure. Was advised by Biggs Operations that fuel usually is not available until 0800L.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: The air stairs provided by Signature at EWR: The lighting on the air stairs was inoperative. On the other hand the aircraft parked next to us (Swift B737-400) was provided with air stairs that had good lighting, in working order. The ramp we were parked on was rather dark. It would have been better if the "home team" (our Customer, NJ Devil's) would have had illuminated air stairs.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: During the landing roll as the brakes were being applied, the middle oven in the aft galley slid forward from its position and hit Flight Attendant Harry Serrano while he was sitting in his jumpseat. The Purser stated that it was a smooth landing and there was no abnormal sudden jolt as the brakes were applied. The oven hit FA Serrano near his right ear and on his right shoulder. FA Matz strained her right arm trying to stop the ovens momentum. Both FA's are sore in the above mentioned areas. No medical attention was given or requested. Captain inspected the oven; a screw which should secure the oven in place was found on the floor; it had worked its way loose and fell behind the galley.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Screw which holds the oven secure worked its way loose allowing the oven to slide forward.

attribute.name: that_an_event_had_occurred
attribute.value: Oven was not secure and slid forward.

attribute.name: avoiding_recurrence_of_this_event
attribute.value: Mainteanance advised all flight mechanics to check all oven screws to ensure they are not loose.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: *At departure time the L2 door could not be closed as it was the air stairs wedge the bottom of the L2 door. -Front tire pressure released from the air stairs truck and 2 ground personnel standing on the top of the air stairs in order to lower the air stairs enough to close the L2 door. â€¢Door inspected by mechanic Mirucki no defects found.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: @ YEG, handler parked A/C next to a fence and had busses pass way too close to nose of A/C.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Flt LL657 departed IND Enroute to PVR. One hour into the flit Capt called to say, Diverting to STL, a pax onboard had a seizure. ETA was in 9 mins. Arrived 1420z, deplaned pax and his wife, they received medical assistance.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: The first two days of the trip assignment followed normal sleep/wake cycles. The third day was a complete reversal of the normal sleep cycle. This made it extremely difficult to get good rest.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Give longer prior notice when a schedule includes a complete sleep cycle reversal.

attribute.name: fatigue_contributing_factors
attribute.value: Accumulated Fatigue;Dead Head;Insufficient Rest Period;Long Block Time;Long Duty Period

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
On 8/25/14, I flew Milwaukee (MKE) to Gander, New Foundland (YQX) and then on to Gronningen, Netherlands (GRQ). It was a ferry flight with only 2 pilots-- no flight attendants and no opportunity to rest. Our showtime in MKE was 3pm (2000Z) and we arrived in the Netherlands at 10 am local (0800z) on 8/26 (Total flight time 9 hours). It was almost another hour after our block in by the time we arrived at the hotel. With our "back side of the clock" schedule and no relief pilot, I got no sleep that night.
The next day (8/27) , I did a live Etops flight with just 2 pilots. We showed at 700Z (0900L). This time we returned to YQX after 5:55 flight time. We blocked in at 1455 Z (1225L). Then, while still in uniform, we sat in a passenger seat during a revenue flight back to Miami. The block time was 5:00 and we arrived at 2105Z (1705L). It took more than an hour to clear customs/immigration and arrive in the van back to the parking lot.
I was told I was on short call the next day. When I woke up, I still felt exhausted and I advised crew scheduling of my condition.
I believe that 2 atlantic crossing in a couple days is enough to make anyone fatigued. In the interest of safety, it is better that I rest until felling better.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: Scheduling needs to be concerned about the previous duty performed by pilots and understand that pilot fatigue is dangerous. They need to go beyond looking at simply whether an assignment is legal.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: @ AVB, Military did not provide actual weights. Had to weigh all personnel and equipment.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Crew was on approach to INT when the approach controller asked them if they were supposed to go to INT instead of GSO because he could see the busses at GSO. Crew checked with coach and they were expecting to arrive GSO. A/C went to GSO and continued on to MIA after the pax deplaned. Weather was good at both stations and no other problems.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: As everyone knows from time to time we [mechanics] are asked to handle bodily fluids. I would like to request to receive hepatitis a & hepatitis b vaccinations. This request was denied in the past. This is common place in the major airlines. Our first priority should be kept our people safe and healthy. I'm not sure what the cost would be or if our med insurance would pay for.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: During approach into rwy 10 at Gantanamo Bay, I called for gear down flap 15 landing check list, as the First Officer was reaching for the check list, I called for flaps 30, as all this was happening I continued flying the approach and descending toward the runway, when the FLAPS item in the check list was called, I looked at the instrument and noticed the flap position indicator pointing at 1 with a split needle, this was confirmed almost at the same time by First Officer Mendoza, I looked back outside toward the runway and asked FO Mendoza to confirm what I just saw, he stated again that the position indicator was pointing at 1 with a split needle, I took a final look and right after I stated I'M GOING AROUND, at that exact moment during the transition from approach to go around the warning TOO LOW FLAPS sounded, flew the go around and reported to the tower that I have a non normal indication and I needed to run a check list before attempting another approach, tower instructed us to fly to SOUTP and hold, I made a PA announcement to the passengers then I gave the Purser the "NTSB", we run the TRAILING EDGE FLAP ASYMMETRY non normal check list, double check the performance, and set up for another approach, the second approach and landing was uneventful.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: @ YYZ ground crew was late, showed up with no by-pass pin & no headsets. Completely unprepared and unprofessional. Called @ 19:25. Push back with hand signals not permitted @ YYZ. Also due to Swissport complete incompetence the A/C was on the gate longer than 90 minutes, in violation of Canadian Customs, max ground time for not clearing Customs.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value:
On the morning of 02-19-16 I was working aircraft N738MA. The fueler arrived and was waiting for me to come down and move the work stand. It was positioned in front of the right wing tip so he could not pull up into fueling position. I moved the work stand under the wing and watched the driver approach the aircraft. I observed him driving too close to the wing and gave him a hand signal to turn away from the aircraft. I looked at him and he shook his head no. At that point I made an emphatic hand gesture, motioning him away from the wing, at which point he did. In over 30 years of working around aircraft, I have never had anyone attempt to or defy a directive while marshaling them around an aircraft. This was a first. I am not happy about this. I gave this driver a directive to move away from the aircraft and he tells me no. This is a serious safety issue. This is very disconcerting that a driver would deliberately defy my direction and jeopardize my safety as well as those around me. Not to mention the potential damage to my aircraft.
I do not know why this fueler ignored my directive. He was within three feet of the leading edge of the wing. I did not want a 10000 gallon fuel truck that close to my wing. He wanted to pull close to the wing and drive forward to the engine, then turn forward to the front of the aircraft. I guess this gets him closer to the wing so he does not have to drag the hose as far.
As soon as the fueling event was complete, I spoke with the Agent at NGU: Crystal Wikoff. She informed me that she would be contacting the Manager in charge of the fueler to see what is to be done. When I returned to NGU at 1900L, I again spoke with Crystal. She said that the manager wanted me to write up a report as to what happened, so that they have documented proof as to what happened. I wrote up a report and emailed it to Crystall last night (02-22-16). She informed me today (02-23-16) that she printed out my report and turned it in along with my phone number and email address. The narrative above is the report I sent.

attribute.name: other_phase_of_operation
attribute.value: Off loading bags from forward bin

attribute.name: when_was_the_event_detected?
attribute.value: ;Ramp;While Aircraft was in Service at Gate

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: When aircraft 733 returned to NGU the ground crew began to off load the bags. I was not able to be downstairs immediately. When I did get down to put the locks and covers on, I noticed that they were not using a belt loader to off load the forward bin. They use a large wooden box to put the bags in, then they use a forklift to move the box around. They put the box up close to the aircraft to load and unload bags. This is how they damaged one of our -400's in the past. They moved the box and it struck the fuselage. They have been advised since that incident to use a belt loader.

category.name: Other Types of Event (Check all that apply)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: An individual called the safety hotline to report that RAMP markings for pushback/towing of aircraft into the Miami Air Hangar are painted in such a way that, if followed, the aircraft wingtip would run into the fence bordering the east side of the property.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: The current painted markings were either painted incorrectly.

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Over the past several weeks, I have received several (more than 8) flight reports for routes being filed into and out of Chania (CHQ) to the south. These flight plans have consistently been filed the wrong way on oneway airways. This has happened on flights to and from Kuwait, as well as Djibouti.
Perhaps we can run some test flight plans and compare them with the charts to see what is going on and notify Jeppesen if necessary

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value:
Company scheduled pilot crew for greater than 8 hours in a 24 hour consecutive period. Our pilot crew flew 9+28 hours in a 24 hour consecutive period. Company had us scheduled for 9+22 hours in a 24 hour consecutive period.
CREW Route 4514 29FEB16 thru 04MAR16
1800z 27FEB16 to 2400z28FEB16 was my 30 hr break prior to beginning this trip assignment.
SCHEDULE:

MIA to GNV (AA3436) 1930z/1430L to 2041z/1541L (commercial travel on company time on duty)
Scheduled Off Duty Release time 2041z/1541L (29FEB16)

Despite a 3 pilot crew assignment to reduce the total flight hours for the CLT-LAS-CLT flights on 02MAR16 thru 03MAR16, our next nights' flights were still scheduled in excess of 9 hours total flight time within the 24 hour consecutive period. The Actual total flight time came to 9 hours 28 minutes.
At around 0250z on 04MAR16 while in flight I became extremely fatigued.
Each new flight day we were scheduled for and conducted operations at earlier than the next day's Hotel Lobby report time. Each Report at the aircraft FDP start time ( a later time than show time) was also scheduled for and conducted at an earlier than the next days' FDP start time.
Here they were again in short:
01MAR16 local times Hotel Lobby: 2045 FDP start: 2100 Hotel Return: 0325 next day
02MAR16 local times Hotel Lobby: 1400 FDP start: 1430 Hotel Return: 0220 next day
03MAR16 local times Hotel Lobby: 1230 FDP start: 1300 Hotel Return: 2245 (different time zone) effectively 2345

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value:
Recommend the company consider back side of the clock flying 3 nights in a row with reduced rest each subsequent night. The schedule was brutal on the pilot body.
Another factor to consider is that the Hotel in Charlotte did not have room service. With two overnights after back side flying and day resting, pilot crews have to steal from one's sleep to go out to eat between flights or take away mealtime to remain in one's room to prevent loss of sleep.
FAR 121.505 permits the company to fly a pilot greater than 8 hours within a 24 hour consecutive period PROVIDED an intervening rest period at or before the end of the 8 hours of scheduled flight. In our case the company scheduled us for over 9 hours within a 24 hour consecutive period on the last night. The caveat here is that the company needed to move us to home base immediately after this and as such there is no violation but in essence our pilot bodies did not get twice the hours flown in rest before the commercial travel on the very next day. As such I fell ill upon my return home. It appears that I was flying that last night's event on pure adrenaline alone.
Respectfully, Patrick Keane

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: occurred,_and_who_was_involved
attribute.value: Upon landing at VQQ the flight was met by CBP with a an explosive detecting K-9. Shortly after we were informed that the K-9 had signaled a problem with a piece of checked luggage. We were instructed to deplane, shut down, and clear the area. No further information was provided to the crew. Our duty time to complete the mission expired and we were released to required rest.

attribute.name: outlining_why_the_event_occurred
attribute.value: This information is not available to us. I suggest inquiring with the authorities who initiated and carried out the actions resulting in this delay.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: @ RDU, marshallers left the aircraft to start and taxi on our own, not following SOP's.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: Lav service performed @ EWR UPS ramp. Lav was incorrectly serviced with blue water. Apparently not enough was put back in both front and rear service ports. Lavs did not operate properly. Cabin Crew noticed the problem during push back / engine start.

category.name: Cabin Event (Including Fire/Smoke, Turbulence, Decompression, etc.)

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: @ VQQ, ground crew left huffer access panel open after huffer start. Crew alerted on taxi by navy crew. No communications on 122.95 with Jetport.

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: @ KADW, Aft stairs stuck to the aircraft after fueling. A/C settled onto stairs too firmly. Ground crew needed extra time to wiggle the stairs loose "cautiously"

attribute.name: observation_comments
attribute.value: @ CYYZ. Additional 15 minutes delay because push-back crew did not have a gear pin. Ended up using our own and passing it through the window. They would not push without it.
